So is he that layeth up treasure for himself, and is not rich toward God.

2025-12-30.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the blessings you have bestowed upon me. Help me to avoid the pitfalls of pride and to resist placing my trust in the fleeting nature of earthly riches. Guide me to use my resources in a way that honors you, by being generous, compassionate, and willing to share with those in need. Grant me a heart that is rich in good works, and help me to lay up treasures in heaven, where my true wealth lies. Give me the wisdom to discern the true value of things, and to invest in the eternal rather than the temporal. Help me to be a faithful steward of all that you have entrusted to me, always remembering that everything comes from you. I pray for the strength to live a life that reflects your love and generosity, and to leave a legacy of good works. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-31.versiculo: 2 Peter 3:9 KJV: "The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance."
2025-12-31.reflexion: As the year draws to a close, 2 Peter 3:9 offers a powerful reminder of God's character and His heart for humanity. The verse directly confronts the misconception that God is slow or indifferent to His promises. Instead, it reveals a God who is patient, merciful, and desires the salvation of all. The 'longsuffering' of the Lord is a testament to His enduring love and willingness to give everyone the opportunity to repent. This isn't just a delay; it's a deliberate act of grace, an extension of time for us to turn towards Him. This verse speaks to the heart of the gospel, emphasizing that God's primary concern is not judgment but redemption. It challenges us to reflect on our own impatience and to cultivate a heart that aligns with God's, embracing His patience and extending grace to others. As we face the new year, let us remember that God's timing is perfect, and His love is unwavering, urging us to live in a manner worthy of repentance and leading others to the same realization.

para_meditar.texto: Or despisest thou the riches of his goodness and forbearance and longsuffering; not knowing that the goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance?
Have I any pleasure at all that the wicked should die? saith the Lord GOD: and not that he should return from his ways, and live?
Who will have all men to be saved, and to come unto the knowledge of the truth.

2025-12-31.oracion: Heavenly Father, as we reflect on Your patience and longsuffering, we are humbled by Your immense love for us. We thank You for not being willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance. Help us to understand the depth of Your grace and to embrace Your timing in all things. Grant us the wisdom to discern Your will and the courage to share Your message of salvation with others. May we be patient with ourselves and others, extending the same grace and mercy that You have shown us. Guide us to live lives that are worthy of Your calling, always striving to love and serve You with all our hearts. We pray for those who have not yet come to know You, that they may find their way to Your loving embrace. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-01.versiculo: Luke 9:23-24 KJV: "And he said to them all, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me. For whosoever will save his life shall lose it: but whosoever will lose his life for my sake, the same shall save it."
2026-01-01.reflexion: Today's passage from Luke 9:23-24 presents a stark yet liberating truth: the path to true life involves denying oneself and embracing the cross. Jesus calls us to a radical commitment, a daily surrender of our own desires and ambitions to follow Him. This is not a call to self-flagellation, but to a deliberate choice to prioritize Christ above all else. It means recognizing that our 'life' as defined by the world – success, comfort, and self-preservation – is often a barrier to the abundant life Jesus offers. Taking up our cross daily is a willingness to bear the weight of suffering, hardship, and even rejection for the sake of the Gospel. It's a commitment to dying to our own will and living according to God's will. The promise is clear: those who cling to their lives will lose them, but those who lose their lives for Christ's sake will find true, eternal life. This is a call to faith, a call to action, and a call to a life transformed by the love of Christ. It's a challenge, but it's also a promise of immeasurable reward.

para_meditar.texto: Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service.

I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.

2026-01-01.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the challenging and life-giving words of Jesus. Help me to understand the depth of what it means to deny myself, take up my cross daily, and follow You. Grant me the strength to resist the temptations of the world and to prioritize Your will above my own desires. Help me to see the eternal perspective, and to understand that true life is found in laying down my life for You. Give me the courage to embrace suffering and hardship for the sake of the Gospel. May I live a life that reflects Your love and grace, and may I be a faithful witness to Your saving power. Guide me each day to live a life that honors You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-02.versiculo: James 1:12 KJV: "Blessed is the man that endureth temptation: for when he is tried, he shall receive the crown of life, which the Lord hath promised to them that love him."
2026-01-02.reflexion: Today's verse, James 1:12, offers a profound perspective on the trials and temptations we face in life. It doesn't shy away from the reality of hardship, but instead, it reframes it as an opportunity for blessing. The key lies in 'enduring temptation.' This isn't merely about avoiding sin; it's about persevering through the challenges that test our faith, patience, and character. The verse promises a 'crown of life' to those who endure, a reward reserved for those who love the Lord. This crown symbolizes eternal life and the ultimate blessing of being in God's presence. The trials we face, the temptations we resist, are not in vain. They are a crucible, refining us and making us more like Christ. They are the very path that leads to the ultimate reward. This understanding should fill us with hope and encouragement. Embrace the struggles, knowing that they are opportunities to grow closer to God and to claim the promise of eternal life. It's a reminder that our faith, when tested, produces endurance and, ultimately, a deeper love for God. Let us strive to endure, knowing that the Lord has a crown waiting for us.

para_meditar.texto: And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience; And patience, experience; and experience, hope:

Wherein ye greatly rejoice, though now for a season, if need be, ye are in heaviness through manifold temptations: That the trial of your faith, being much more precious than of gold that perisheth, though it be tried with fire, might be found unto praise and honour and glory at the appearing of Jesus Christ:

Fear none of those things which thou shalt suffer: behold, the devil shall cast some of you into prison, that ye may be tried; and ye shall have tribulation ten days: be thou faithful unto death, and I will give thee a crown of life.

2026-01-02.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts filled with gratitude for your unwavering love and grace. We acknowledge that life is filled with trials and temptations, but we trust in your promise of strength and guidance. Help us to endure the challenges that come our way, to resist the allure of sin, and to remain steadfast in our faith. Grant us the patience and perseverance to run the race set before us, keeping our eyes fixed on the crown of life you have promised. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, so that we may overcome every obstacle and glorify your name in all that we do. Thank you for the trials that refine us and make us more like Christ. We commit ourselves to you, seeking your will and trusting in your perfect plan. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-03.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 7:23 KJV: "Ye are bought with a price; be not ye the servants of men."
2026-01-03.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in 1 Corinthians 7, addresses various matters related to marriage and singleness, providing guidance to the believers in Corinth. Verse 23 offers a powerful and liberating truth: we have been bought with a price. This price is the precious blood of Jesus Christ, shed on the cross for the redemption of our sins.  To be bought with a price signifies our freedom from the bondage of sin and the dominion of the world.  It declares that we no longer belong to ourselves, but to God, who has claimed us as His own. The second part of the verse, "be not ye the servants of men," is a direct consequence of this truth. If we have been bought with the price of Christ's sacrifice, we are no longer to be enslaved to the opinions, desires, or commands of men. Our allegiance belongs to God alone. This verse calls us to live lives of freedom and obedience, acknowledging the Lordship of Christ in every aspect of our lives. It challenges us to resist the temptation to please men above God, and to instead seek His will and glorify Him in all that we do. This freedom, however, is not a license for selfishness or irresponsibility, but an invitation to serve God and others with a grateful heart, reflecting the love and grace we have received.

para_meditar.texto: Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free, and be not entangled again with the yoke of bondage.
But now being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness, and the end everlasting life.
If the Son therefore shall make you free, ye shall be free indeed.

2026-01-03.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the immense price you paid for my freedom. Thank you for the sacrifice of Jesus, through whom I am redeemed and made your own. Help me to fully grasp the truth that I am not my own, but bought with a price. Grant me the strength to resist the temptation to serve the desires of men, and to instead live a life wholly devoted to you.  Give me the courage to walk in the freedom that Christ has won for me, and to use that freedom to serve you and to love others. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I may be guided by your will and live a life that glorifies you in all things. Help me to remember that I am a servant of Christ, and that my ultimate allegiance is to you.  In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-04.versiculo: Matthew 12:31-32 KJV: "Wherefore I say unto you, All manner of sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men: but the blasphemy against the Holy Ghost shall not be forgiven unto men. And whosoever speaketh a word against the Son of man, it shall be forgiven him: but whosoever speaketh against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven him, neither in this world, neither in the world to come."
2026-01-04.reflexion: Today's verses from Matthew offer a sobering and crucial teaching about the unforgivable sin, blasphemy against the Holy Spirit. Jesus declares that all sins and blasphemies can be forgiven, a testament to God's immense grace and mercy. However, He makes a stark exception: speaking against the Holy Spirit. This is not simply uttering a harsh word but rather a deliberate and persistent rejection of the Spirit's work, denying the divine power behind Jesus' miracles and the very source of spiritual truth. It's a refusal to acknowledge and accept the Holy Spirit's guidance, conviction, and sanctifying work in one's life. This sin is unforgivable because it represents a hardened heart, an unwillingness to repent, and a rejection of the only means by which one can come to know God. It is a state of spiritual blindness where one actively resists the truth of the Gospel. It's a warning to examine our hearts, to ensure that we are open to the leading of the Holy Spirit and not quenching His work in our lives. It is a call to discern the difference between sincere questioning and a deliberate refusal to believe, allowing us to remain open to the transformative power of God's grace.

para_meditar.texto: And when he is come, he will reprove the world of sin, and of righteousness, and of judgment.
But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dwell in you. Now if any man have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his.
And grieve not the holy Spirit of God, whereby ye are sealed unto the day of redemption.

2026-01-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts that seek to be open and receptive to the leading of Your Holy Spirit. Help us to discern the difference between honest doubt and a hardened refusal to believe. Grant us the wisdom to recognize the work of the Spirit in our lives, convicting us of sin, guiding us in righteousness, and leading us to the truth of Your Word. Protect us from the sin of blasphemy against the Holy Spirit, and help us to be ever mindful of the grace and forgiveness offered through Your Son, Jesus Christ. Fill us with Your Spirit, that we may walk in obedience and live lives that are pleasing to You. Give us the strength to resist temptation and to remain open to Your transformative power, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-05.versiculo: 2 John 1:6 KJV: "And this is love, that we walk after his commandments. This is the commandment, That, as ye have heard from the beginning, ye should walk in it."
2026-01-05.reflexion:
Today's verse, 2 John 1:6, offers a profound definition of love intertwined with obedience. It declares that true love is demonstrated by walking in God's commandments. This isn't merely an intellectual assent to the teachings of Christ, but an active, daily practice of living according to His will. The verse further emphasizes the continuity of this call to obedience, reminding us that it's a message we've heard from the very beginning. This implies that the foundation of our faith rests on adhering to the principles of love and obedience. 

We are called to love not just in words or feelings, but in actions, mirroring the love God has shown us. This love is not passive; it's active, engaged, and manifested in our obedience. It's a continuous journey of striving to live in accordance with God's commands, reflecting His character in our interactions and choices. This verse encourages self-reflection: Are our actions aligned with our beliefs? Are we walking in love through obedience, or are we merely professing faith? The call is clear: genuine love is revealed through a life of obedience, a life that honors God and blesses others. It's a walk, a continuous journey, not a destination reached but a path consistently trod.

para_meditar.texto: If ye love me, keep my commandments.
For this is the love of God, that we keep his commandments: and his commandments are not grievous.
Love worketh no ill to his neighbour: therefore love is the fulfilling of the law.

2026-01-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the gift of love and the clarity of Your commandments. Help me to understand that true love is not merely a feeling, but an active choice to walk in obedience to Your Word. Grant me the grace to discern Your will in every aspect of my life and to align my actions with Your teachings. Strengthen my resolve to love others as You have loved me, showing compassion, kindness, and forgiveness. Help me to live a life that reflects Your character, a life marked by obedience and a deep, unwavering love for You and for those around me. May my daily walk be a testimony to Your goodness and Your grace. Guide my steps, and fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may always choose to walk in love and obedience, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-06.versiculo: John 16:7 KJV: "Nevertheless I tell you the truth; It is expedient for you that I go away: for if I go not away, the Comforter will not come unto you; but if I depart, I will send him unto you."
2026-01-06.reflexion: John 16:7 presents a pivotal truth: Jesus' departure was not a loss, but a necessary prelude to the coming of the Holy Spirit, the Comforter. The disciples, likely saddened by the prospect of Jesus' physical absence, needed to understand the divine strategy. Jesus clarifies that His going away was actually 'expedient' or beneficial for them. Without His departure, the Comforter, the Holy Spirit, could not come. This highlights the crucial role of the Holy Spirit in the life of believers. The Holy Spirit would be a greater presence, a constant companion, teacher, and advocate. He would empower them, guide them into all truth, and provide comfort in times of distress. This verse reminds us that even in moments of perceived loss or difficulty, God's plans are often working for our ultimate good. We can trust that His ways are higher than our ways, and His purposes are always for our benefit. The promise of the Comforter offers hope and strength, reminding us that we are never truly alone.

para_meditar.texto: But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, and in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth.
Likewise the Spirit also helpeth our infirmities: for we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered.
And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you another Comforter, that he may abide with you for ever;

2026-01-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the promise of the Holy Spirit, the Comforter. We acknowledge that Your plans are always perfect, even when they seem difficult to understand. We are grateful for the sacrifice of Jesus, which allowed the Holy Spirit to come and dwell within us. Help us to be open to the guidance and wisdom of the Holy Spirit in our lives. Grant us strength, comfort, and understanding in every circumstance. May we be filled with His power to witness and share the Gospel with the world. Help us to rely on the Holy Spirit's presence, knowing that we are never truly alone. Guide us to live in accordance with Your will, allowing the Holy Spirit to transform us into the image of Christ. We pray for a deeper understanding of the Holy Spirit's role in our lives, and to be more sensitive to His leading. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-07.versiculo: Matthew 13:31-32 KJV: "Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is like to a grain of mustard seed, which a man took, and sowed in his field: Which indeed is the least of all seeds: but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof."
2026-01-07.reflexion: Today's passage, Matthew 13:31-32, offers a profound insight into the nature of the Kingdom of Heaven. Jesus uses the humble mustard seed as an analogy. It starts as the smallest of seeds, seemingly insignificant. Yet, with proper care and time, it grows into a large tree, providing shelter and sustenance. This parable speaks volumes about the Kingdom's growth. It often begins small, perhaps unnoticed, in the heart of an individual or in a humble gathering. But like the mustard seed, it possesses the potential for immense expansion. The Kingdom of Heaven is not always about grand displays or immediate results. It is about the quiet, persistent work of faith, the nurturing of hope, and the slow, steady growth of love. Just as the mustard seed requires patience and favorable conditions to flourish, so too does the Kingdom require our commitment and the grace of God. This passage encourages us to embrace the small beginnings and to trust in the power of God to bring forth abundant fruit. We are reminded that even the smallest act of faith, the humblest expression of love, can contribute to the flourishing of the Kingdom, providing refuge and sustenance for others. Let us cultivate the seeds of faith within us, knowing that God will bring forth a harvest far greater than we can imagine.

para_meditar.texto: And he said, Whereunto shall we liken the kingdom of God? or with what comparison shall we compare it? It is like a grain of mustard seed, which, when it is sown in the earth, is less than all the seeds that be in the earth: But when it is sown, it groweth up, and becometh greater than all herbs, and shooteth out great branches; so that the fowls of the air may lodge under the shadow of it.

Then said he, Unto what is the kingdom of God like? and whereunto shall I resemble it? It is like a grain of mustard seed, which a man took, and cast into his garden; and it grew, and waxed a great tree; and the fowls of the air lodged in the branches of it.
And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not.

2026-01-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the beautiful parable of the mustard seed. Help me to understand the power of small beginnings and the importance of nurturing the seeds of faith within my own heart. Grant me the patience to persevere, even when the results are not immediately visible. Give me the strength to trust in Your plan and to believe in the potential for growth in every area of my life. Help me to be a vessel of Your love, providing shelter and sustenance for others, just as the mustard tree provides for the birds of the air. Guide me in my daily walk, that my actions may contribute to the flourishing of Your Kingdom. Help me to be faithful in the small things, knowing that You are working through them to accomplish great things. Thank you for Your grace and for the promise of abundant fruit. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-08.versiculo: Matthew 26:26-28 KJV: "And as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed it, and brake it, and gave it to the disciples, and said, Take, eat; this is my body. And he took the cup, and gave thanks, and gave it to them, saying, Drink ye all of it; For this is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for many for the remission of sins."
2026-01-08.reflexion: Today's passage from Matthew 26:26-28 reveals the profound institution of the Lord's Supper, a moment of immense spiritual significance. Jesus, on the eve of His crucifixion, shared a final meal with His disciples. In this act, He transformed the ordinary elements of bread and wine into symbols of His body and blood, establishing a new covenant. The breaking of the bread symbolizes the breaking of His body, a sacrifice for our sins. The pouring of the wine represents the shedding of His blood, the ultimate price paid for our redemption. This act is not merely a ritual; it is a remembrance of Christ's sacrifice, a communion with Him, and a declaration of our faith in His saving work. The invitation to 'eat' and 'drink' is a call to participate in His sacrifice, to partake in His divine nature, and to receive forgiveness and new life. As we partake, we are reminded of the depth of God's love and the magnitude of Christ's offering. It is a time to reflect on our own sinfulness, to acknowledge our need for a Savior, and to express our gratitude for the gift of grace. The Lord's Supper is a powerful reminder of the covenant we have with God through Christ, a covenant sealed by His blood.

para_meditar.texto: Then Jesus said unto them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Except ye eat the flesh of the Son of man, and drink his blood, ye have no life in you.
And when he had given thanks, he brake it, and said, Take, eat: this is my body, which is broken for you: this do in remembrance of me.
And almost all things are by the law purged with blood; and without shedding of blood is no remission.

2026-01-08.oracion: Dear Lord, we come before you with hearts full of gratitude. We thank you for the sacrifice of your Son, Jesus Christ, who offered His body and blood for our sins. As we reflect on the Lord's Supper, may we be reminded of the depth of your love and the price that was paid for our redemption. Help us to approach this sacred act with reverence, humility, and a deep desire to be in communion with you. Grant us the grace to examine our hearts, to confess our sins, and to receive your forgiveness. May we be strengthened and renewed by your presence, and may we live our lives as a testament to your love and sacrifice. Help us to remember the new covenant established through Christ's blood, and to walk in the freedom and grace that it offers. We pray for those who have not yet experienced your grace and for those who struggle with their faith. Guide them towards an understanding of your love. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-09.versiculo: Mark 11:24 KJV: "Therefore I say unto you, What things soever ye desire, when ye pray, believe that ye receive them, and ye shall have them."
2026-01-09.reflexion: Today's verse, Mark 11:24, is a potent reminder of the power of faith and prayer. Jesus emphasizes that when we pray, we must not only ask, but believe that we have already received what we are asking for. This is not merely a suggestion; it's a foundational principle of Christian life. It’s about aligning our desires with God's will and trusting in His ability to answer. The key word here is "believe." It requires a deep-seated conviction that God is listening and that He will act according to His perfect plan. This belief is not passive; it's active, requiring us to live as though we've already received what we've prayed for. This can involve taking practical steps, expressing gratitude in anticipation, and trusting in God’s timing. This verse challenges us to examine our faith. Are we praying with doubt, or with the unwavering belief that God's power is limitless? Let us cultivate a faith that moves mountains, believing that we have received, and thus we shall have.

para_meditar.texto: Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.
Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.
But let him ask in faith, nothing wavering. For he that wavereth is like a wave of the sea driven with the wind and tossed.

2026-01-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of prayer and the promise of answered requests. I come before you today, seeking to align my desires with your will. Help me to cultivate a faith that believes I have already received what I ask for. Grant me the strength to trust in your timing, and to live each day with gratitude and anticipation. Remove any doubt that may hinder my faith, and fill me with the unwavering conviction that you are always listening and always working for my good. Empower me to believe, so that I may receive all that you have planned for me. Guide me to be bold in prayer and patient in waiting, knowing that you are faithful. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-10.versiculo: Matthew 10:32-33 KJV: "Whosoever therefore shall confess me before men, him will I confess also before my Father which is in heaven. But whosoever shall deny me before men, him will I also deny before my Father which is in heaven."
2026-01-10.reflexion: These verses from Matthew 10 stand as a stark reminder of the importance of our public confession of faith. Jesus makes it clear: our allegiance to Him is not a private matter, confined to the walls of a church or the privacy of our own hearts. It is a declaration that must be made before the world. This is not a call to boastfulness or arrogance, but a call to authenticity. To confess Christ is to align our lives with His teachings, to live in obedience to His commandments, and to reflect His character in our daily interactions. It means being willing to stand apart from the world, to be different, and to be judged by the standards of the Gospel. The promise of being confessed before the Father is a comforting one. It assures us of a divine advocate, a defender who will speak on our behalf. Conversely, the warning against denying Christ is a sobering one. It highlights the consequences of compromise, of choosing the approval of men over the faithfulness to our Lord. It challenges us to examine our lives, to ensure that our actions, words, and attitudes consistently reflect our commitment to Christ. Are we willing to risk disapproval or persecution for the sake of the Gospel? This passage demands a courageous, consistent faith, a faith that is not ashamed to proclaim Jesus as Lord.

para_meditar.texto: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.

Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name: That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.
Whosoever denieth the Son, the same hath not the Father: (but) he that acknowledgeth the Son hath the Father also.

2026-01-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today, humbled and grateful for the gift of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Help me to live a life that openly confesses and glorifies His name. Grant me the courage to speak of Him, to share His love with others, and to stand firm in my faith, even when faced with opposition. Strengthen me to resist the temptation to deny Him, to compromise my beliefs, or to be ashamed of the Gospel. May my words and actions consistently reflect Your grace and truth. Guide me to be a bold witness, a light in the darkness, and a vessel of Your love. Help me to be unwavering in my confession before men, so that You may confess me before Your Father in Heaven. I pray for boldness, wisdom, and the ability to love as Jesus loved, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-11.versiculo: John 1:12 KJV: "But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name:"
2026-01-11.reflexion: John 1:12 offers a profound truth: the privilege of becoming children of God is not earned, but received. It is a gift offered to those who welcome Jesus into their lives. The verse speaks of 'power' – the authority and capacity to be transformed, to shed the old self and embrace a new identity in Christ. This power isn't merely a title; it's an inherent capacity to live a life reflecting God's character, guided by His Spirit. Receiving Jesus involves more than just intellectual assent. It is an active choice, a commitment to believe in His name, to trust in His sacrifice, and to follow His teachings. It's a daily surrender of our will to His, recognizing Him as Lord and Savior. This verse challenges us to examine our hearts. Have we truly received Him? Are we living in the power of our sonship, or are we still trying to earn God’s favor through our own efforts? The promise of John 1:12 is a call to embrace our divine inheritance, to live boldly in the assurance of God's love and the guidance of His Spirit. Let us daily choose to receive Him, to believe on His name, and to walk in the power of our new identity.

para_meditar.texto: The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.
For ye are all the children of God by faith in Christ Jesus.
Behold, what manner of love the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called the sons of God: therefore the world knoweth us not, because it knew him not.

2026-01-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible gift of adoption, that through faith in Jesus, we become your children. Help us to truly receive Jesus into our hearts, not just as a concept, but as Lord of our lives. Grant us the power to live in the fullness of our sonship, reflecting your love and grace in all we do. Open our eyes to see the world through your perspective, and empower us to walk in the Spirit, guided by your truth. Give us the courage to surrender our wills to yours daily, and to live a life that brings you glory. Strengthen our faith, increase our love for you and for others, and fill us with the peace that surpasses all understanding. Thank you for your unwavering love and your promise of eternal life. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-12.versiculo: Colossians 1:27 KJV: "To whom God would make known what is the riches of the glory of this mystery among the Gentiles; which is Christ in you, the hope of glory:"
2026-01-12.reflexion: Today's verse reveals a profound truth: Christ in you, the hope of glory. This mystery, hidden for ages, is now unveiled to the Gentiles – and to us! It's not merely a concept, but a reality. The 'riches of the glory' isn't just a promise of future reward, but a present possession. Christ dwells within the believer, the very essence of glory residing in our mortal bodies. This is not a passive state; it's a dynamic, transformative presence. It offers a hope that anchors us in the storms of life, a glory that illuminates the darkness. It means that even in suffering, in trials, in the face of death, we have a hope that transcends earthly limitations. We are not alone. The very source of glory, the King of Kings, lives within us. This reality should stir a deep sense of gratitude and awe. We are called to live in a manner worthy of this indwelling presence, to reflect His glory in our thoughts, words, and deeds. Let us embrace this mystery and live in the radiant hope that Christ in us provides.

para_meditar.texto: And if Christ be in you, the body is dead because of sin; but the Spirit is life because of righteousness.

I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.
That Christ may dwell in your hearts by faith; that ye, being rooted and grounded in love...

2026-01-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible gift of Christ in me. Thank you that the hope of glory is not just a distant promise, but a present reality that fills my life with purpose and strength. Help me to understand more deeply this mystery, to live consciously of Your presence within me, and to reflect Your glory in all that I do. Grant me the grace to overcome the challenges of this world with the hope that is found in You. Fill me with Your Spirit, so that I might live a life worthy of this great privilege. Help me to love others as You have loved me, and to share the hope that I have found in Christ. Guide my steps and direct my thoughts, that I may always be mindful of Your presence. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-13.versiculo: Matthew 9:12-13 KJV: "But when Jesus heard that, he said unto them, They that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick. But go ye and learn what that meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice: for I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance."
2026-01-13.reflexion: Today's passage from Matthew 9:12-13 offers a powerful lesson on the heart of Jesus' ministry. He states, "They that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick." This speaks to the spiritual condition of humanity. Jesus came not for those who believe they are righteous and need no help, but for those who recognize their need for healing and forgiveness. He then quotes Hosea 6:6, saying, "I will have mercy, and not sacrifice." This highlights the importance of compassion and a transformed heart over mere religious rituals. Jesus' primary mission was to call sinners to repentance, offering them a path to restoration and a relationship with God. This passage challenges us to examine our own hearts. Are we self-righteous, or are we aware of our need for a spiritual physician? Do we prioritize outward appearances over inward transformation? Jesus calls us to embrace mercy and compassion, both for ourselves and for others. He invites us to recognize our brokenness and seek His healing touch, understanding that true righteousness comes through repentance and a sincere desire to follow Him.

para_meditar.texto: For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God.
Come now, and let us reason together, saith the Lord: though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they be red like crimson, they shall be as wool.
I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.

2026-01-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for sending Your Son, Jesus, to heal the sick and call sinners to repentance. We recognize our need for You, our brokenness, and our dependence on Your mercy. Forgive us for the times we have been self-righteous and have judged others. Help us to embrace compassion, showing grace and understanding to those around us. Grant us hearts that yearn for transformation and a deeper relationship with You. Open our eyes to see the needs of others and empower us to share Your love and the message of repentance with them. Help us to prioritize mercy and compassion above all else, allowing Your love to flow through us. Guide us to seek Your healing touch and to live lives that reflect Your grace and forgiveness. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-14.versiculo: 2 Peter 1:5-7 KJV: "And beside this, giving all diligence, add to your faith virtue; and to virtue knowledge; And to knowledge temperance; and to temperance patience; and to patience godliness; And to godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness charity."
2026-01-14.reflexion: Today's passage from 2 Peter presents a powerful roadmap for spiritual growth. It's not a passive journey; we are called to actively 'add' to our faith. This isn't just about believing, but about cultivating a life that reflects that belief. The progression starts with faith, the foundation, and moves towards a series of virtues that build upon each other. Virtue leads to knowledge, which helps us understand God's will. Temperance, or self-control, is crucial in resisting temptation and living a disciplined life. Patience enables us to endure trials and wait on God's timing. Godliness, a reverence for God, informs our actions. Brotherly kindness extends love to fellow believers, and finally, charity, or love, encompasses all, reflecting the very nature of God. This isn't a checklist, but a description of a life transformed by the power of the Holy Spirit. It's a call to action, a reminder that we are called to grow and mature in Christ, striving for a life that reflects His character and love in every aspect.

para_meditar.texto: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.

Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things.
And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.

2026-01-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for this beautiful blueprint for spiritual growth. Help me to be diligent in adding to my faith. Grant me the virtue to overcome temptation and the knowledge to understand Your Word. Cultivate in me temperance, so I may have self-control in all things. Give me patience to endure trials and to trust in Your timing. Fill me with godliness, that I may honor You in all I do. Help me to show brotherly kindness to my fellow believers and to overflow with charity towards all. Guide me, Lord, to live a life that reflects Your love and character. Transform my heart and mind, so that I may be more like You each day. Empower me by Your Holy Spirit to walk in these virtues. Thank you for your grace and mercy. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-15.versiculo: Matthew 16:24-26 KJV: "Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me. For whosoever will save his life shall lose it: and whosoever will lose his life for my sake shall find it. For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?"
2026-01-15.reflexion: Today's passage from Matthew 16:24-26 presents a stark challenge to our values and priorities. Jesus calls upon us to deny ourselves, take up our cross, and follow Him. This is not a call for superficial acts of piety, but a radical shift in allegiance. It means relinquishing control of our lives, our desires, and our ambitions, and surrendering them to Christ. We are reminded that the pursuit of worldly success, the accumulation of wealth, and the gratification of our own desires are ultimately empty if they come at the cost of our souls. The cross represents suffering, sacrifice, and the ultimate surrender of self. By embracing this, we find true life. The world's perspective often contradicts this truth, encouraging us to prioritize self-preservation and self-aggrandizement. But Jesus offers a different path, one that leads to eternal life and genuine fulfillment. It's a call to prioritize our spiritual well-being over worldly gain, recognizing that the value of our souls far exceeds anything the world can offer.

para_meditar.texto: And when he had called the people unto him with his disciples also, he said unto them, Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
And he said to them all, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me.

2026-01-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today with a humble heart, acknowledging the challenge of denying myself and taking up my cross. Help me to see the world through Your eyes, and to understand the true value of my soul. Grant me the strength to resist the temptations of the world and to prioritize my relationship with You above all else. Open my heart to the suffering and sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus, and help me to embrace the path of discipleship, even when it is difficult. Give me the courage to make the difficult choices, to put Your will above my own, and to live a life that honors You. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit so that I may be guided in all that I do, and that I may find true life in You. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-16.versiculo: Romans 12:12 KJV: "Rejoicing in hope; patient in tribulation; continuing instant in prayer;"
2026-01-16.reflexion: Romans 12:12 offers a powerful triad for the Christian life: rejoicing in hope, patient in tribulation, and continuing instant in prayer. This verse doesn't suggest an easy path; rather, it outlines a framework for navigating the complexities of life with unwavering faith. 'Rejoicing in hope' calls us to maintain an optimistic outlook, grounded in the promises of God. This hope isn't a mere wishful thinking but a confident expectation of His goodness and provision, even when circumstances appear bleak. 'Patient in tribulation' reminds us that trials are inevitable. We are called to endure these hardships with grace and perseverance, trusting that God is working all things for our good (Romans 8:28). Patience allows us to learn, grow, and develop a deeper reliance on Him. Finally, 'continuing instant in prayer' emphasizes the crucial role of prayer. It is not a casual practice but a persistent, fervent communication with God. Through prayer, we find strength, guidance, and comfort. It is the lifeline that connects us to our source of hope and resilience. Embracing these three principles allows us to live a life that glorifies God, even in the midst of life's storms.

para_meditar.texto: God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.
Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.
My brethren, count it all joy when ye fall into divers temptations; Knowing this, that the trying of your faith worketh patience.

2026-01-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, I thank you for the hope that you have given me through Jesus Christ. Help me to rejoice in that hope, even when I face trials and tribulations. Grant me the patience to endure these hardships, knowing that you are with me. Strengthen my prayer life, that I may continually seek your guidance and comfort. Help me to be instant in prayer, trusting in your provision and your love. Fill me with your peace, which surpasses all understanding, and help me to live a life that reflects your glory. Guide me to be a beacon of hope for others. Thank you for your faithfulness and your unwavering presence in my life. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-17.versiculo: Revelation 3:20 KJV: "Behold, I stand at the door, and knock: if any man hear my voice, and open the door, I will come in to him, and will sup with him, and he with me."
2026-01-17.reflexion: Today's verse, Revelation 3:20, paints a vivid picture of Christ's persistent invitation. He stands at the door, knocking, not forcing entry, but patiently awaiting our response. This isn't a command; it's a plea, a gentle nudge from the very heart of God. The 'door' represents our hearts, our lives, and the 'knocking' is the call of the Holy Spirit, urging us toward intimacy with Him. The promise is profound: if we open the door, He will come in, and we will share a meal together. This 'supping' symbolizes fellowship, communion, and a deep, personal relationship. It's a promise of solace, guidance, and a life transformed by His presence. We are given the agency to choose – to open the door or to leave it closed. The choice dictates the depth of our relationship with the Lord. This verse calls us to self-examination. Are we listening for His knock? Are we willing to open the door and welcome Him into every aspect of our lives? The invitation is open to all, and the reward is eternal fellowship with the King of Kings.

para_meditar.texto: But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name:
That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.

I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.

2026-01-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You with open hearts, ready to listen for Your voice and to recognize Your gentle knocking. We acknowledge that You stand at the door of our lives, desiring to enter and sup with us. Help us to be sensitive to the promptings of the Holy Spirit, to discern Your call amidst the noise of the world. Grant us the courage to open the door wide, to welcome You into every facet of our existence. May we experience the profound joy of Your presence, the comfort of Your guidance, and the transformative power of Your love. Fill us with Your peace, and help us to live lives that reflect Your glory and grace. Thank You for Your unwavering love and persistent invitation. We open our hearts to You now, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-18.versiculo: Hebrews 8:6 KJV: "But now hath he obtained a more excellent ministry, by how much also he is the mediator of a better covenant, which was established upon better promises."
2026-01-18.reflexion: Hebrews 8:6 speaks of a 'more excellent ministry' and a 'better covenant.' This verse highlights the superiority of the New Covenant established through Jesus Christ, the ultimate Mediator. The Old Covenant, though important, was based on the Levitical priesthood and sacrifices, which were shadows of the reality to come. The New Covenant, mediated by Jesus, offers a direct relationship with God, based on faith and grace, not works. It is established upon 'better promises' – promises of forgiveness, eternal life, and the indwelling of the Holy Spirit. This passage encourages us to embrace the fullness of the New Covenant, understanding that we have access to God through a perfect mediator. We are no longer bound by the limitations of the old system. Instead, we are blessed with a personal relationship with God, empowered by the Holy Spirit to live a life of righteousness and peace. This superior ministry calls us to a life of devotion, gratitude, and constant communion with God, knowing that our salvation is secure in Him. We should strive to live worthy of this new covenant and appreciate the sacrifice of Jesus Christ that made it possible.

para_meditar.texto: But this shall be the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel; After those days, saith the LORD, I will put my law in their inward parts, and write it in their hearts; and will be their God, and they shall be my people.
For the law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ.
Who also hath made us able ministers of the new testament; not of the letter, but of the spirit: for the letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life.

2026-01-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the better covenant established through your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank you for the grace and mercy that allows us to have a personal relationship with you. We praise you for the perfect sacrifice of Jesus that opened the way for us. Help us to understand and embrace the fullness of this new covenant, walking in faith and obedience. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may live lives worthy of the calling we have received. Guide us to share this good news with others, that they too may experience the peace and joy of knowing you. Grant us wisdom and discernment as we navigate the complexities of life, trusting in your promises. Strengthen our faith and deepen our love for you, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-19.versiculo: Ephesians 1:13-14 KJV: "In whom ye also trusted, after that ye heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation: in whom also after that ye believed, ye were sealed with that holy Spirit of promise, Which is the earnest of our inheritance until the redemption of the purchased possession, unto the praise of his glory."
2026-01-19.reflexion: Today's verses from Ephesians 1:13-14 offer a profound glimpse into the transformative power of the Gospel and the securing presence of the Holy Spirit in the believer's life. We are reminded that we 'trusted' in Christ after hearing the word of truth, the Gospel of our salvation. This trust, born of hearing and believing, is then sealed with the Holy Spirit. This sealing is not merely a mark of identification, but a guarantee, an 'earnest' or down payment, of our inheritance. This inheritance is the fullness of redemption, the complete freedom and restoration that awaits us. The Holy Spirit serves as the first installment, assuring us of the totality of what is to come. This truth should inspire us to live with unwavering faith and hope, knowing that our salvation is secure and that we are destined for glory. We are not alone in this journey; the Holy Spirit dwells within, guiding, comforting, and empowering us. Let us live each day in the light of this glorious promise, striving to live lives worthy of the calling to which we have been called.

para_meditar.texto: The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.
Who hath also sealed us, and given the earnest of the Spirit in our hearts.
And grieve not the holy Spirit of God, whereby ye are sealed unto the day of redemption.

2026-01-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the precious gift of the Holy Spirit, the seal of our salvation. Thank you for the Gospel of truth, which has brought us to faith and trust in Jesus Christ. We are grateful for the assurance that we are heirs to an eternal inheritance and that the Holy Spirit is the guarantee of what is to come. Help us to live each day in the power of the Spirit, walking in obedience to Your will and striving to live lives that honor You. Give us the strength to resist the temptations of the world and to remain steadfast in our faith. Fill us with Your love, joy, and peace, as we await the full redemption of our souls. Guide us by Your Holy Spirit, and keep us safe in Your love, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-20.versiculo: John 15:13 KJV: "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends."
2026-01-20.reflexion: Today, we contemplate the profound words of John 15:13, a verse that encapsulates the very essence of sacrificial love. Jesus declares that the ultimate expression of love is to lay down one's life for one's friends. This isn't a mere suggestion; it's a defining characteristic of true love, a love that transcends self-preservation and embraces the well-being of others, even at the cost of one's own life. This verse reflects the unparalleled sacrifice of Jesus Christ, who willingly gave His life on the cross for the salvation of humanity. He considered us, sinners, as His friends, and He loved us enough to pay the ultimate price for our redemption. This act of love sets the standard for how we, as believers, should love one another. We are called to love sacrificially, to be willing to put the needs of others before our own, to offer compassion, forgiveness, and support, even when it's difficult. This verse challenges us to examine our own hearts and to evaluate the depth of our love for those around us. Are we willing to make sacrifices for our friends, our family, and even for strangers? Are we living a life that reflects the selflessness of Christ? Let us strive to embody this greater love daily, demonstrating the very nature of God in our actions and in our hearts. The challenge is not just to understand this verse, but to live it.

para_meditar.texto: But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.

Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves. Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others.

2026-01-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts full of gratitude for the unparalleled love demonstrated by Jesus Christ. Thank you for sending your Son to lay down His life for us, His friends. Help us to understand the depth of this sacrifice and to emulate His selfless love in our own lives. Grant us the strength and the willingness to put the needs of others before our own, to forgive freely, and to offer compassion to those who are hurting. Open our hearts to see the needs around us and to act with kindness and generosity. Help us to be willing to make sacrifices for our loved ones, our community, and even for those we may not know. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may love as You love, and that our lives may be a testament to Your grace and mercy. Guide us in all our actions and words, that we may reflect the love of Christ in every aspect of our lives. We ask all this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-21.versiculo: John 3:17 KJV: "For God sent not his Son into the world to condemn the world; but that the world through him might be saved."
2026-01-21.reflexion: Today's verse, John 3:17, offers a profound glimpse into the heart of God. It declares that God did not send His Son, Jesus, into the world to condemn it. This is a crucial distinction. The world was already in a state of separation from God, lost in sin and deserving of judgment. Yet, God's love was so immense that He sent Jesus not to pronounce condemnation, but to offer salvation. This verse reveals a God of grace and mercy, a God who desires relationship with humanity above all else. It highlights the fundamental purpose of Jesus's mission: to save, to rescue, to redeem. He came to provide a way out of the darkness, a path to forgiveness and eternal life. This verse should fill us with hope and gratitude. It challenges us to see the world as God sees it – not as worthy of condemnation, but as a field ripe for harvest, desperately needing the saving grace of Jesus. Reflecting on this truth should inspire us to share the good news, to be ambassadors of reconciliation, and to live lives that reflect the love and mercy of God.

para_meditar.texto: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.
In this was manifested the love of God toward us, because that God sent his only begotten Son into the world, that we might live through him.
Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost;

2026-01-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the incredible gift of Your Son, Jesus. Thank You that You did not send Him to condemn us, but to save us. Lord, we are humbled by Your immense love and mercy. Help us to grasp the depth of Your grace and to live our lives in response to it. Grant us the courage to share the good news of salvation with others, and to be a light in a world that desperately needs You. Give us the eyes to see the world as You see it, and the heart to love others as You love us. Fill us with Your Spirit, that we may be instruments of Your peace and reconciliation. May we always remember that salvation is found only in You, and that through Jesus, we have eternal life. We praise You and thank You for Your everlasting love, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-22.versiculo: John 14:1 KJV: "Let not your heart be troubled: ye believe in God, believe also in me."
2026-01-22.reflexion: John 14:1 is a comforting balm for the soul, particularly in times of distress. Jesus, knowing His earthly ministry was drawing to a close, sought to reassure His disciples, and by extension, us. The command, "Let not your heart be troubled," is not merely a suggestion; it is a call to action, a challenge to actively resist the anxieties and fears that grip our hearts. The key to overcoming this trouble, Jesus reveals, is faith. He doesn't say, "Believe in God, and then believe in Me," but rather, "Ye believe in God, believe also in me." This suggests a seamless connection between faith in God and faith in Jesus. To believe in Jesus is to believe in the very embodiment of God's love, power, and truth. When we face trials, we can choose to fix our gaze on the chaos around us, or we can choose to believe in the unwavering promises of Jesus. He offers peace that surpasses understanding. Choosing faith in Him allows us to rise above our circumstances, understanding that even in the darkest times, we are not alone, and we have a Savior who has overcome the world.

para_meditar.texto: Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.

Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God. And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.

For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, Nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.

2026-01-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, in moments of turmoil, when my heart is burdened and my spirit feels lost, I come before You. I confess my tendency to worry and to let fear take hold. Help me to remember the words of Jesus, "Let not your heart be troubled." Grant me the strength to cast all my anxieties upon You, knowing that You care for me. I choose to believe in You, and in Your Son, Jesus Christ, who is the way, the truth, and the life. Fill me with Your peace, a peace that surpasses all understanding, and help me to trust in Your unwavering love. Guide my steps, strengthen my faith, and remind me that You are always with me. Thank you for your constant presence and for the promise of eternal life. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-23.versiculo: Romans 12:3 KJV: "For I say, through the grace given unto me, to every man that is among you, not to think of himself more highly than he ought to think; but to think soberly, according as God hath dealt to every man the measure of faith."
2026-01-23.reflexion: Today's verse from Romans 12:3 calls us to humility and a realistic self-assessment. The Apostle Paul, writing under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit, reminds us that we must not think of ourselves more highly than we ought. This is a potent challenge in a world that often celebrates self-promotion and inflated egos. The grace given to us by God should lead us to a sober judgment of ourselves, recognizing our limitations and our dependence on Him. The verse also highlights the 'measure of faith' that God has dealt to each of us. This implies that we all have a unique gifting and calling, and the key is to discover and utilize these gifts with humility and in service to others. Overestimating our abilities can lead to pride and a failure to recognize God's work in our lives and in the lives of others. Conversely, underestimating our abilities can hinder us from fulfilling the purpose God has for us. The balance lies in sober thinking, recognizing our dependence on God and using our God-given gifts to serve Him and build up the body of Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves.
Pride goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall.
Likewise, ye younger, submit yourselves unto the elder. Yea, all of you be subject one to another, and be clothed with humility: for God resisteth the proud, and giveth grace to the humble.

2026-01-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today with a heart seeking humility. Help me to see myself as you see me, neither overestimating my abilities nor underestimating the gifts you have given. Grant me the grace to think soberly, recognizing my dependence on you in all things. May I use the measure of faith you have given me to serve others and to bring glory to your name. Protect me from the snare of pride and fill me with a spirit of humility and service. Guide me to discern my calling and to walk in the path you have set before me. Help me to be a vessel of your love and grace, reflecting your light to the world. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-24.versiculo: Ephesians 4:30 KJV: "And grieve not the holy Spirit of God, whereby ye are sealed unto the day of redemption."
2026-01-24.reflexion: Today's verse serves as a powerful reminder of the sacredness of the Holy Spirit, dwelling within us as believers. Paul urges us not to 'grieve' the Spirit. This isn't a physical act, but a spiritual one. We grieve the Spirit through our actions, words, and attitudes that contradict the character of God. These can include bitterness, wrath, anger, clamor, evil speaking, and malice, as mentioned earlier in Ephesians 4. The Holy Spirit, the seal of our salvation, is a person, not just a force. He is our comforter, guide, and advocate. To grieve Him is to diminish His influence in our lives and to hinder the work He desires to accomplish within us. It is a call to examine our hearts and actions. Are we living in a way that honors the Spirit? Are we cultivating the fruit of the Spirit: love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance? This verse is a solemn warning, but also a promise. We are sealed, secured until the day of redemption. This seal signifies ownership and protection. Even when we stumble and grieve the Spirit, His seal remains. However, we are called to strive to live in a way that pleases Him, allowing Him to work in and through us, leading us closer to Christ and ultimately, to redemption.

para_meditar.texto: But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dwell in you. Now if any man have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.
Quench not the Spirit.

2026-01-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today acknowledging my need for your Holy Spirit. I confess the times I have grieved Him through my thoughts, words, and actions. Forgive me for not always aligning my life with Your will. Help me to be more sensitive to the Spirit's leading and to cultivate the fruit of the Spirit in my life. Grant me the strength to resist temptation and to choose actions that honor You. Fill me with Your love, joy, and peace. Guide me in all I do, that I may live a life worthy of my calling, a life that reflects the character of Christ. Help me to be a vessel for Your glory, always seeking to please You and to be used for Your purposes. Thank you for the promise of redemption and for the seal of the Holy Spirit. I pray all of this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-25.versiculo: John 3:19 KJV: "And this is the condemnation, that light is come into the world, and men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil."
2026-01-25.reflexion: John 3:19 presents a stark reality: humanity's preference for darkness over light. The 'condemnation' isn't simply a decree from God, but a consequence of our own choices. The light, representing Jesus Christ and His truth, has entered the world, yet many choose to remain in the shadows. This choice is rooted in the nature of our deeds. When our actions are evil, we naturally shy away from the light, which exposes our flaws and imperfections. This verse challenges us to examine our lives and the choices we make. Are we drawn to truth and righteousness, or do we find comfort in the darkness of sin and deception? The key is to recognize the light, embrace it, and allow it to illuminate the hidden corners of our hearts. This requires a conscious effort to turn away from evil deeds and to seek the transformative power of Christ's love and grace. It is a call to repentance, a turning towards the light and away from the darkness. It's a reminder that the judgment isn't arbitrary, but a natural consequence of our choices, and the only way to escape condemnation is to embrace the Light.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.
For ye were sometimes darkness, but now are ye light in the Lord: walk as children of light:
This then is the message which we have heard of him, and declare unto you, that God is light, and in him is no darkness at all.

2026-01-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, we confess that we often choose darkness over light, sin over righteousness. We acknowledge that our deeds are often contrary to your will. Forgive us for the times we have hidden from your truth, preferring the comfort of our own self-deception. Help us to turn away from evil and embrace the light of Jesus Christ. Grant us the courage to examine our hearts, to identify the areas where we need to change, and the strength to walk in the light of your presence. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, so that we may reflect your love and truth to the world around us. Guide our steps, illuminate our path, and help us to live lives that honor you. We ask all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-26.versiculo: 2 Timothy 3:1-5 KJV: "This know also, that in the last days perilous times shall come. For men shall be lovers of their own selves, covetous, boasters, proud, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, unholy, Without natural affection, trucebreakers, false accusers, incontinent, fierce, despisers of those that are good, Traitors, heady, highminded, lovers of pleasures more than lovers of God; Having a form of godliness, but denying the power thereof: from such turn away."
2026-01-26.reflexion: The Apostle Paul's warning in 2 Timothy 3:1-5 serves as a stark reminder of the spiritual climate that would characterize the last days. He paints a grim picture of society, highlighting moral decay and a rejection of God's truth. The list of vices – self-love, covetousness, pride, disobedience, and the denial of God's power – reveals a heart turned away from God. We are called to recognize these perilous times and to be vigilant in our own walk with Christ. The key is not to be surprised by these behaviors, but to be strengthened in our faith. We must cling to the Word of God, which provides the power to overcome the temptations of the world. The warning is not just a description; it is a call to action. We are to turn away from those who deny the power of godliness, seeking instead those who live in genuine faith and love for God. This passage challenges us to examine our own hearts and to ensure that we are not merely professing faith, but truly living it out in our daily lives. Let us strive to be lovers of God, not lovers of pleasure, and to be empowered by the Holy Spirit to live a life of righteousness and truth.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world. If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.

2026-01-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are confronted with the unsettling truth of the times we live in, as revealed in Your Word. We see the signs of the last days all around us. We pray for discernment and strength to resist the temptations of the world and the influence of those who deny Your power. Help us to examine our own hearts and to ensure that we are truly loving You above all else. Grant us the grace to be faithful witnesses, shining Your light in a dark world. Fill us with Your Spirit, that we may bear the fruit of righteousness and live lives pleasing to You. Give us the courage to turn away from those who deny You, and the wisdom to seek fellowship with those who love and obey You. We seek Your guidance and protection, trusting in Your unwavering love and faithfulness. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-27.versiculo: Luke 10:19 KJV: "Behold, I give unto you power to tread on serpents and scorpions, and over all the power of the enemy: and nothing shall by any means hurt you."
2026-01-27.reflexion:
Today's verse, Luke 10:19, is a powerful declaration of the authority and protection given to believers. Jesus, sending out the seventy disciples, equips them with divine power. He doesn't just promise safety; He promises dominion. 'Power to tread on serpents and scorpions' is not merely a literal description, but a symbolic representation of overcoming the spiritual forces of evil. Serpents and scorpions were often used in the ancient world to symbolize dangerous and venomous creatures, representing the insidious nature of sin and the devil's influence. 

This verse offers profound reassurance. It assures us that, as believers, we are not left vulnerable to the attacks of the enemy. We have been given authority over the very forces that seek to harm us. 'Over all the power of the enemy' emphasizes the comprehensive nature of this authority. It's not limited to specific situations; it encompasses all the enemy's schemes. The promise that 'nothing shall by any means hurt you' is a testament to God's unwavering protection. This doesn't mean we will never experience trials or suffering, but it does mean that the ultimate power of evil cannot permanently harm those who are in Christ. This is a call to walk boldly in faith, knowing that we are protected and empowered by the Holy Spirit.

para_meditar.texto: Thou shalt tread upon the lion and adder: the young lion and the dragon shalt thou trample under feet.
Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us.
Above all, taking the shield of faith, wherewith ye shall be able to quench all the fiery darts of the wicked.

2026-01-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible promise found in Luke 10:19. Thank you for giving us power over the enemy and for assuring us that nothing can truly harm us when we are in You. Help us to remember this truth daily, especially when we face challenges and temptations. Grant us the faith to walk boldly in Your authority, knowing that we are protected and empowered by Your Holy Spirit. Give us the wisdom to discern the enemy's schemes and the strength to resist them. We declare Your victory over all darkness in our lives and in the world. We pray for the strength to tread on serpents and scorpions, and to walk in Your peace, knowing that You are always with us. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-28.versiculo: Ephesians 1:7 KJV: "In whom we have redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of sins, according to the riches of his grace;"
2026-01-28.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in his letter to the Ephesians, unveils a profound truth in Ephesians 1:7. This verse speaks of redemption, forgiveness, and the abundant grace of God, all made possible through the sacrifice of Jesus Christ. The phrase "in whom" points directly to Christ, the central figure of our salvation. It is 'through his blood' that we obtain redemption. This signifies the ultimate price paid for our freedom from sin and its consequences. The shedding of Christ's blood on the cross is the ultimate act of love and sacrifice, cleansing us from the stain of sin. The 'forgiveness of sins' is the direct result of this redemption. Our past transgressions, our failures, and our rebellion against God are wiped away, leaving us free from the condemnation of the law. This forgiveness is not a meager offering; it is given 'according to the riches of his grace.' This grace is not just sufficient; it is overflowing, abundant, and immeasurable. It is a boundless gift, freely offered to all who believe. Understanding this verse allows us to grasp the depth of God's love and the magnitude of our salvation. It invites us to live in gratitude, to walk in the freedom of forgiveness, and to embrace the abundant grace that is ours in Christ Jesus.

para_meditar.texto: Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus:
In whom we have redemption through his blood, even the forgiveness of sins:
And almost all things are by the law purged with blood; and without shedding of blood is no remission.

2026-01-28.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you with hearts full of gratitude for the sacrifice of your Son, Jesus Christ. We thank you for the redemption we have in Him, for the forgiveness of our sins, and for the abundance of your grace. Help us to fully understand the depth of your love, a love that was willing to pay the ultimate price for our salvation. Grant us the grace to live lives worthy of this gift, lives marked by humility, gratitude, and a desire to share your love with others. Give us strength to resist temptation and to walk in the freedom that Christ has won for us. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may be transformed into the image of your Son. May we always remember the price that was paid for our redemption and live a life that reflects your glory, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-29.versiculo: Galatians 5:13 KJV: "For, brethren, ye have been called unto liberty; only use not liberty for an occasion to the flesh, but by love serve one another."
2026-01-29.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in Galatians 5:13, reminds us of the core essence of Christian freedom. We have been called to liberty, a freedom from the bondage of sin, from the law's condemnation, and ultimately, freedom to serve God. However, this liberty is not a license to indulge in selfish desires, to gratify the flesh. Instead, Paul urges us to use this freedom to serve one another in love. This is a powerful paradox: true freedom is found not in self-indulgence, but in self-giving. It's easy to misinterpret liberty as a chance to do as we please, to prioritize our own desires above all else. But Paul warns against this, knowing that such actions will ultimately lead to spiritual ruin. The call to serve one another in love is a call to humility, to compassion, and to a selfless commitment to the well-being of others. It challenges us to see our freedom not as an escape from responsibility, but as an opportunity to live out the Gospel in practical ways, demonstrating the love of Christ to the world. This verse reminds us that our freedom is meant to be a tool for building up the body of Christ, for edifying and supporting one another, and for reflecting God's grace in our interactions.

para_meditar.texto: If the Son therefore shall make you free, ye shall be free indeed.
Being then made free from sin, ye became the servants of righteousness.
As free, and not using your liberty for a cloke of maliciousness, but as the servants of God.

2026-01-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of freedom found in Christ Jesus. Help me to understand and embrace this liberty, not as an opportunity for self-gratification, but as a call to serve others in love. Grant me the strength to resist the temptations of the flesh and to instead prioritize the needs of those around me. Fill my heart with compassion and humility, that I may reflect your grace in all my actions. Guide me to use my freedom to build up the body of Christ, to encourage and support my brothers and sisters in faith. Help me to be a servant, not just in word, but in deed, always seeking to honor you in all that I do. Give me wisdom to discern the true meaning of freedom and to live a life that glorifies you. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-01-30.versiculo: Romans 8:31 KJV: "What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us?"
2026-01-30.reflexion: Romans 8:31 is a powerful declaration of faith and security in Christ. It presents a fundamental question: If God, the Almighty Creator of the universe, is on our side, who can truly stand against us? The answer is implicit and resounding: no one. This verse encapsulates the core truth of the Christian experience – that we are not alone in our struggles. We are not left to fend for ourselves in a hostile world. We have the ultimate ally, the one who holds all power and authority. This truth should transform our perspective. When challenges arise, when doubts creep in, when the world seems to be against us, we can hold fast to this promise. We can find comfort in knowing that God's love and protection are unwavering. We are more than conquerors through Him who loved us. This verse is not a guarantee of an easy life, but it is a promise of victory in the face of adversity. It calls us to trust in God's power and sovereignty, knowing that He works all things together for good to those who love Him, to those who are the called according to His purpose.
