Seeking them first means placing God at the center of our lives, allowing His values and principles to guide our decisions and actions. This isn't a passive endeavor; it's an active pursuit. It involves prayer, studying the Scriptures, and striving to live a life that reflects God's love and grace. The promise that 'all these things shall be added unto you' is a powerful assurance. 'These things' refer to our basic necessities – food, clothing, and shelter – the worries that often plague us. God doesn't promise that life will be without challenges, but He does promise to provide for those who seek Him first. This verse encourages us to shift our focus from material concerns to spiritual ones, trusting that God will take care of us. It’s a reminder that our true security and fulfillment are found in our relationship with Him.

para_meditar.texto: Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.
Trust in the LORD with all thine heart; and lean not unto thine own understanding. In all thy ways acknowledge him, and he shall direct thy paths.
I have been young, and now am old; yet have I not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread.

2026-03-02.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the beautiful promise in Matthew 6:33. I confess that I often get caught up in the worries of this world, and I find myself focusing on the things that don't truly matter. Help me, Lord, to seek Your kingdom and Your righteousness first. Grant me the strength and the wisdom to prioritize my relationship with You above all else. Guide my thoughts, actions, and decisions, so that they may reflect Your will. Help me trust in Your provision and to release my anxieties to you, knowing that You care for me. Give me a heart that is grateful for all Your blessings. Fill me with Your peace, and help me to live a life that glorifies Your name. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-03.versiculo: Mark 8:34 KJV: "And when he had called the people unto him with his disciples also, he said unto them, Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me."
2026-03-03.reflexion: Today's verse, Mark 8:34, is a powerful call to discipleship. Jesus, gathering the crowd and his disciples, lays down the foundational requirements for following Him. He doesn't sugarcoat the cost; instead, He presents a stark reality: deny yourself, take up your cross, and follow me. "Deny yourself" speaks to a fundamental shift in our priorities. It's about relinquishing control of our own desires, ambitions, and self-centeredness. It's recognizing that our lives are no longer our own, but belong to Christ. "Take up your cross" refers to the willingness to endure hardship, suffering, and even persecution for the sake of the Gospel. The cross symbolizes the ultimate sacrifice and the willingness to embrace the shame and pain that may come with identifying with Christ. Finally, "follow me" is a simple yet profound command. It means to imitate Jesus, to walk in His footsteps, to live a life patterned after His teachings and example. This is not a suggestion, but a mandate for anyone who claims to be a follower of Christ. It’s a call to a life of radical surrender, unwavering commitment, and intentional discipleship.

para_meditar.texto: Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
And he said to them all, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me.

But what things were gain to me, those I counted loss for Christ. Yea doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ.

2026-03-03.oracion: Lord, help me to fully understand the implications of Mark 8:34. Grant me the strength and the willingness to deny myself, to lay down my own desires, and to embrace the cross that You have given me to bear. Give me the courage to face any challenges or hardships that may come my way as I strive to follow You. Help me to prioritize Your will above my own, and to live a life that is pleasing to You. I pray that I may be a true disciple, walking in Your footsteps and reflecting Your love and grace to all those I encounter. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be empowered to live a life of radical surrender and unwavering commitment to You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-04.versiculo: James 5:15-16 KJV: "And the prayer of faith shall save the sick, and the Lord shall raise him up; and if he have committed sins, they shall be forgiven him. Confess your faults one to another, and pray one for another, that ye may be healed. The effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much."
2026-03-04.reflexion: Today's passage from James offers a powerful testament to the efficacy of prayer and the importance of community in our spiritual lives. James highlights the role of faith in healing, emphasizing that the 'prayer of faith shall save the sick.' This isn't just a superficial plea; it's a profound act of trust in God's power and mercy. The verse also acknowledges the spiritual dimension of healing, stating that sins may be forgiven. This underscores the interconnectedness of our physical and spiritual well-being. Furthermore, James calls us to confess our faults to one another and pray for each other. This is a crucial act of vulnerability and accountability within the Christian community. By confessing our sins, we release the burden of guilt and shame, and by praying for each other, we bear one another's burdens, fostering healing and growth. The final statement, 'The effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much,' reminds us that a righteous life, coupled with passionate prayer, is a powerful force for good in the world. This passage encourages us to cultivate a life of faith, confession, and fervent prayer, knowing that God hears and answers.

para_meditar.texto: Again I say unto you, That if two of you shall agree on earth as touching any thing that they shall ask, it shall be done for them of my Father which is in heaven.

And this is the confidence that we have in him, that, if we ask any thing according to his will, he heareth us: And if we know that he hear us, whatsoever we ask, we know that we have the petitions that we desired of him.
Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.

2026-03-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts filled with faith and gratitude. We thank you for the promise of healing, both physical and spiritual, through the power of prayer. We confess our faults to you and to each other, seeking forgiveness and cleansing. Help us to cultivate a spirit of humility and vulnerability, that we may bear one another's burdens and pray fervently for those in need. Grant us the strength to live righteous lives, marked by unwavering faith and passionate prayer. Guide us to seek Your will in all things, knowing that You hear our prayers and answer according to Your perfect plan. We pray for healing in every area of our lives, and for the strength to persevere in faith. We lift up those who are sick and suffering, asking for Your divine touch to bring them comfort and wholeness. May Your love and grace abound in our lives, and may we be a light to others. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-05.versiculo: John 14:16-17 KJV: "And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you another Comforter, that he may abide with you for ever; Even the Spirit of truth; whom the world cannot receive, because it seeth him not, neither knoweth him: but ye know him; for he dwelleth with you, and shall be in you."
2026-03-05.reflexion: In John 14:16-17, Jesus promises His disciples the gift of the Holy Spirit, referred to as the Comforter. This promise is a beacon of hope, especially as Jesus prepares to leave them physically. The Comforter, or Advocate, is not just a replacement for Jesus' physical presence, but a continuation of His work. The Holy Spirit is the 'Spirit of truth,' who will guide believers into all truth. The world, unable to perceive the spiritual realm, cannot receive the Holy Spirit. However, for those who know and believe in Jesus, the Spirit will dwell within them. This indwelling is a personal and intimate relationship with God, offering comfort, guidance, and empowerment to live a life pleasing to Him. This passage underscores the profound spiritual connection available to believers, a relationship that transcends physical limitations and empowers us to face the challenges of life with divine support and truth. The promise of the Holy Spirit is a testament to God's unwavering love and care for His children, even when facing separation or trials.

para_meditar.texto: But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dwell in you. Now if any man have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.

But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, and in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth.

2026-03-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the precious gift of the Holy Spirit. Thank you for sending the Comforter to dwell within me, guiding me into all truth and providing comfort in times of need. I pray for a deeper understanding of the Spirit’s presence in my life. Help me to be more sensitive to His leading and to yield to His will in all things. Grant me the strength to resist temptation, to walk in love, and to bear the fruit of the Spirit in my daily life. Open my eyes to see Your work in and through me, and to be a vessel of Your love and grace to others. I ask for the wisdom to discern the truth and to live a life that honors You. Fill me with Your Spirit, Lord, and empower me to live a life that brings glory to Your name, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-06.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 13:4-7 KJV: "Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up, Doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil; Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth; Beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things."
2026-03-06.reflexion: Today's passage, 1 Corinthians 13:4-7, paints a vivid picture of love, a love that transcends mere emotion and becomes a way of life. The Apostle Paul beautifully describes love as patient, kind, and devoid of envy or boastfulness. It's a love that doesn't seek its own interests, isn't easily angered, and doesn't dwell on wrongs. Instead, it rejoices in truth. This love is resilient; it bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, and endures all things. This is the essence of God's love for us, exemplified by Jesus Christ. It's a call to emulate this divine love in our interactions with others. It challenges us to examine our hearts and actions, to see if our love aligns with this profound description. Are we patient with those who frustrate us? Are we kind even when we are wronged? Do we rejoice in the truth, even when it's difficult? Let us strive to embody this love daily, allowing it to shape our thoughts, words, and deeds.

para_meditar.texto: A new commandment I give unto you, That ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another.
Let love be without dissimulation. Abhor that which is evil; cleave to that which is good.
And above all things have fervent charity among yourselves: for charity shall cover the multitude of sins.

2026-03-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of love, a love that surpasses all understanding. Help me to understand and embody the characteristics of love as described in Your Word. Grant me patience when I am tested, kindness in my interactions, and the ability to rejoice in truth. Remove any envy, pride, or selfishness that hinders me from loving others as You love me. Fill my heart with Your love so that it may overflow into the lives of those around me. Give me strength to bear all things, believe all things, hope all things, and endure all things. Guide me to love as Jesus loved, selflessly and sacrificially. Help me to reflect Your love in every aspect of my life. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-07.versiculo: 1 John 4:1 KJV: "Beloved, believe not every spirit, but try the spirits whether they are of God: because many false prophets are gone out into the world."
2026-03-07.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 John 4:1, is a crucial call to discernment. It reminds us that not every influence, teaching, or voice we encounter comes from God. The Apostle John urges us, as believers, to test or 'try' the spirits—meaning to evaluate the source of messages and teachings to determine if they are truly from God. This is not a call to suspicion, but to careful examination. The world is filled with diverse voices, many of which may seem appealing or even compelling. False prophets, those who speak falsely in the name of God, are a constant threat. They can lead us astray with deceptive teachings, twisting the truth of the Gospel. Discernment is a spiritual gift, nurtured by prayer, study of Scripture, and seeking the guidance of the Holy Spirit. It requires us to compare what we hear with the established truths of God's Word. Are the teachings consistent with the character of God? Do they align with the teachings of Jesus Christ? Do they promote love, grace, and truth? Only by diligently testing the spirits can we protect ourselves from deception and walk faithfully in the truth of God.

para_meditar.texto: The simple believeth every word: but the prudent man looketh well to his going.
Prove all things; hold fast that which is good.
Beware of false prophets, which come to you in sheep's clothing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.

2026-03-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today seeking Your guidance in discernment. The world is full of voices, and I pray for the wisdom to distinguish truth from falsehood. Grant me the ability to test every spirit, to carefully examine the teachings and influences in my life. Help me to compare everything I hear with Your Word, and to recognize when something is not aligned with Your character and truth. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, so that I may be sensitive to Your promptings and walk in the path of righteousness. Protect me from deceptive teachings and false prophets. Strengthen my faith and help me to remain steadfast in the truth of Your Gospel. Guide me to seek Your will in all things, and to live a life that honors You. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-08.versiculo: Matthew 11:28-30 KJV: "Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart: and ye shall find rest unto your souls. For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light."
2026-03-08.reflexion: This passage from Matthew offers a profound invitation to those burdened by the weight of life. Jesus, in His infinite compassion, calls out to those who are weary and overloaded, promising rest. The 'labour' and 'heavy laden' represent the struggles, anxieties, and trials that weigh us down. These burdens can be anything from physical ailments and financial woes to emotional distress and spiritual emptiness. Jesus doesn't promise an easy life, but He does promise rest – a deep, abiding peace that surpasses understanding. He then invites us to 'take His yoke upon us' and 'learn of Him.' The yoke, in biblical times, was a device used to connect animals to a task, symbolizing obedience and partnership. Learning from Jesus means adopting His character of meekness and lowliness of heart. It means submitting to His will and following His example of love, compassion, and humility. His yoke is not a restrictive burden, but rather an easy one, and His burden is light, because it is supported by His strength and grace. This passage is a testament to the comforting nature of Christ and the promise of finding true peace in Him, even amidst life's challenges. It is a call to surrender and find solace in the loving embrace of our Savior.

para_meditar.texto: The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.

Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God. And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.
Let us therefore come boldly unto the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help in time of need.

2026-03-08.oracion: Dear Lord Jesus, I come before You today, acknowledging the burdens I carry. I am weary and heavy laden, and I long for the rest that You promised. I surrender my anxieties, my fears, and my struggles to You. Help me to take Your yoke upon me, to learn from You, and to walk in Your ways. Grant me the meekness and lowliness of heart that You exemplified. Fill me with Your peace, which surpasses all understanding, and help me to trust in Your strength and grace. Guide me to find solace in Your presence and to experience the lightness of Your burden. Thank You for Your unwavering love and compassion. I commit my life to you, and ask for your guidance and strength. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-09.versiculo: Hebrews 13:14 KJV: "For here have we no continuing city, but we seek one to come."
2026-03-09.reflexion: The profound truth of Hebrews 13:14 reminds us of our transient sojourn on this earth. We, as believers, are not meant to find our ultimate fulfillment or lasting home here. This world, with all its allure and challenges, is not our final destination. The verse urges us to look beyond the temporal, to yearn for the eternal city, the one that is to come. This understanding should shape our perspective and actions. It encourages a detachment from the things of this world, a willingness to prioritize spiritual treasures over material possessions. We are called to live as pilgrims and strangers, recognizing that our true citizenship is in heaven. This perspective allows us to embrace suffering and hardship with a different lens, knowing that they are temporary and that they pale in comparison to the glory that awaits us. It also motivates us to invest in the Kingdom of God, in spreading the Gospel, and in building up treasures that will last for eternity. Let us live with the expectation of a future hope, eagerly awaiting the arrival of our eternal home, where we will dwell with God forever.

para_meditar.texto: For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ:
Dearly beloved, I beseech you as strangers and pilgrims, abstain from fleshly lusts, which war against the soul;
And I John saw the holy city, new Jerusalem, coming down from God out of heaven, prepared as a bride adorned for her husband.

2026-03-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the reminder in Hebrews 13:14 that this world is not our final home. Help us to keep our eyes fixed on the eternal city, the one You have prepared for us. Grant us the wisdom to live as pilgrims and strangers on this earth, prioritizing Your Kingdom and investing in things that last. Give us strength to resist the allure of the temporal and to embrace suffering with the hope of eternal glory. Fill our hearts with a yearning for Your presence and a longing for the day when we will dwell with You forever. Strengthen our faith, increase our hope, and ignite our love for You and for others. Guide us daily to live lives that reflect our true citizenship in heaven. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-10.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 5:21 KJV: "For he hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousness of God in him."
2026-03-10.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Corinthians 5:21, is a cornerstone of the Gospel. It speaks of a magnificent exchange: Christ, who knew no sin, became sin for us. This is not just a statement of fact, but a profound declaration of God's love and justice. He took our sin upon Himself, bearing the full weight of our separation from Him. In doing so, He made it possible for us to be made the righteousness of God in Him. This doesn't mean we earn righteousness; it means we are clothed in Christ's righteousness through faith. This is a gift, a grace, something we could never achieve on our own. Think about the implications: He traded places with us. He took our penalty, and we receive His perfection. This isn't just forgiveness; it's a transformation. We are no longer defined by our sin but by His righteousness. This verse calls us to reflect on the immensity of God's sacrifice and the incredible privilege we have in Christ. It is a call to live a life worthy of this gift, striving to walk in the newness of life He has given us, and to be a light to others.

para_meditar.texto: Even the righteousness of God which is by faith of Jesus Christ unto all and upon all them that believe: for there is no difference:
Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us: for it is written, Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree:
And be found in him, not having mine own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through the faith of Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith:

2026-03-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are overwhelmed by Your love and grace. Thank You for sending Your Son, Jesus Christ, to become sin for us, that we might become the righteousness of God in Him. We confess our sin and shortcomings, and we thank You for the forgiveness and transformation that come through faith in Jesus. Help us to understand more deeply the magnitude of Your sacrifice and to live a life worthy of the gift of righteousness we have received. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to walk in the newness of life. May we reflect Your light to those around us, sharing the good news of Your love and salvation. We ask all this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-11.versiculo: Luke 14:11 KJV: "For whosoever exalteth himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted."
2026-03-11.reflexion: Today's verse from Luke 14:11 offers a profound lesson on humility and its ultimate reward. Jesus, in His wisdom, highlights a fundamental truth about the human condition: the pursuit of self-exaltation leads to abasement, while the path of humility leads to exaltation. The world often encourages us to strive for recognition, to climb the ladder of success, and to boast of our achievements. Yet, Jesus challenges this perspective. He suggests that true greatness is found not in self-promotion, but in selflessness and a willingness to serve others. When we humble ourselves, we acknowledge our dependence on God and recognize the value of others. This posture of humility opens our hearts to receive God's grace and allows Him to work in and through us. It is in the act of serving, loving, and putting others before ourselves that we truly reflect the character of Christ. This doesn't mean we should shy away from our talents or hide our gifts. Rather, it means we should use them to glorify God and to bless those around us, always with a spirit of humility and gratitude. The promise of exaltation is not a guarantee of worldly success, but a promise of eternal reward and a deeper connection with God.

para_meditar.texto: The fear of the Lord is the instruction of wisdom; and before honour is humility.
Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves.
Humble yourselves in the sight of the Lord, and he shall lift you up.

2026-03-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts open to Your teachings. We confess our tendency to seek praise and recognition, and we ask for Your forgiveness. Help us to embrace humility, to put others before ourselves, and to serve with a spirit of love and gratitude. Grant us the strength to resist the allure of self-exaltation and to seek Your will in all that we do. May we find our joy in serving You and in glorifying Your name. Fill us with Your grace, that we may reflect the character of Christ in our lives. Guide us to walk in humility, knowing that You are the source of all good things. We thank you for your love and your promises. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-12.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 5:18-19 KJV: "And all things are of God, who hath reconciled us to himself by Jesus Christ, and hath given to us the ministry of reconciliation; To wit, that God was in Christ, reconciling the world unto himself, not imputing their trespasses unto them; and hath committed unto us the word of reconciliation."
2026-03-12.reflexion: Today's passage from 2 Corinthians 5:18-19 offers a profound understanding of our relationship with God and our purpose in the world. We are reminded that the initiative for reconciliation comes from God Himself. Through Jesus Christ, He has bridged the gap created by sin, bringing us back into fellowship with Him. This reconciliation is not just a passive act; it is an active ministry entrusted to us. We are not simply recipients of God's grace; we are ambassadors of reconciliation. We are given the privilege and responsibility to share the good news of forgiveness and restoration. God's plan is to reconcile the whole world to Himself, and He uses us as His instruments. This means that we have a vital role in sharing the gospel, demonstrating God's love, and urging others to be reconciled to Him. The passage emphasizes that God does not hold our trespasses against us. This is a testament to His boundless mercy and grace. Understanding this truth should transform our lives, inspiring us to live in gratitude, extend forgiveness to others, and actively participate in the ministry of reconciliation. Let us embrace this calling with humility, boldness, and a deep desire to see others experience the transformative power of God's love.

para_meditar.texto: For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son, much more, being reconciled, we shall be saved by his life.
For he is our peace, who hath made both one, and hath broken down the middle wall of partition between us;
And, having made peace through the blood of his cross, by him to reconcile all things unto himself; by him, I say, whether they be things in earth, or things in heaven.

2026-03-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for Your incredible love and grace. Thank You for reconciling us to Yourself through Jesus Christ. We are humbled by the privilege of being called Your children and being given the ministry of reconciliation. Help us to understand the depth of Your forgiveness and to extend that forgiveness to others. Grant us the boldness and the wisdom to share the good news of Your love with those around us. Open our hearts to the needs of the lost and equip us to be effective ambassadors for Your Kingdom. May we live each day with gratitude, seeking to reflect Your love in all that we say and do. Guide us to be instruments of peace and reconciliation in a world that desperately needs Your touch. We pray for opportunities to share the gospel and to see lives transformed by Your grace. We commit ourselves to Your service, trusting in Your power to work through us. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-13.versiculo: Romans 10:9-10 KJV: "That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved. For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness; and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation."
2026-03-13.reflexion: Today's verses, Romans 10:9-10, lay the foundation of our salvation. They clearly articulate the two essential components: belief in the heart and confession with the mouth. The passage emphasizes that salvation isn't earned through works, but received through faith in Jesus Christ. To confess Jesus as Lord is to acknowledge His divine authority and surrender our lives to Him. This confession must be born from a sincere belief that God raised Jesus from the dead, confirming His victory over sin and death. This belief, rooted in the heart, is what leads to righteousness. It's not just a mental assent, but a deep-seated conviction that transforms our lives. The confession that follows is the outward expression of this inner transformation, the proclamation of our faith to the world. It is through this combined act of believing and confessing that we obtain salvation. This isn't a one-time event, but a continuous process of acknowledging Jesus as Lord and allowing our lives to be molded by His teachings. It is a call to a life lived in faith, obedience, and witness.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved.

That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

2026-03-13.oracion: Dear Lord, thank You for the gift of salvation, made possible through the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Help me to continually strengthen my belief in my heart, allowing it to guide my thoughts, words, and actions. Grant me the courage to confess my faith openly and without reservation, so that others may see Your light shining through me. Help me to live a life that honors You, reflecting Your love and grace in all that I do. Fill me with the Holy Spirit, enabling me to walk in righteousness and to be a witness for Your Kingdom. Guide my steps, and give me the strength to overcome any obstacles that may come my way. Thank You for Your unwavering love and for the promise of eternal life, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-14.versiculo: Hebrews 1:3 KJV: "Who being the brightness of his glory, and the express image of his person, and upholding all things by the word of his power, when he had by himself purged our sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high;"
2026-03-14.reflexion: Hebrews 1:3 offers a breathtaking glimpse into the very nature of Jesus Christ. He is not merely a prophet or a teacher; He is the radiant brightness of God's glory, the exact representation of God's being. This implies a complete and perfect reflection of God's character, attributes, and essence. Furthermore, the verse highlights Christ's active role in creation and redemption. He upholds all things by the word of His power, demonstrating His divine authority and control over the universe. The most profound act described is the purging of our sins. This is the core of the Gospel message. Through His sacrifice, Jesus cleansed us from the stain of sin, offering forgiveness and reconciliation with God. Finally, the verse concludes with the image of Jesus sitting at the right hand of the Majesty on high, signifying His completed work, His triumph over sin and death, and His eternal reign. This position is one of honor, authority, and intercession for believers. Understanding Hebrews 1:3 strengthens our faith, inspiring us to worship and trust in the all-powerful, all-loving Savior.

para_meditar.texto: And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth.
Who is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of every creature:
Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name:

2026-03-14.oracion: Lord, we come before You in awe and reverence, acknowledging the majesty of Jesus Christ, the brightness of Your glory and the express image of Your person. Thank You for upholding all things by the word of Your power, for the sacrifice that purged our sins and brought us into fellowship with You. We praise You for the completed work on the cross, for the victory over sin and death. We are grateful for the privilege of being reconciled to You through Jesus. Help us to live lives that reflect His glory, and to always remember His sacrifice. Grant us wisdom to understand the depths of Your love and grace. Guide us to fully trust in Him and to live lives that honor You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-15.versiculo: Romans 8:14 KJV: "For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God."
2026-03-15.reflexion: Today's verse, Romans 8:14, is a powerful declaration of our identity in Christ. It reveals a fundamental truth: those who are guided by the Spirit of God are, without a doubt, children of God. This isn't merely a suggestion, but a defining characteristic. It highlights the central role of the Holy Spirit in our lives. To be 'led' by the Spirit implies a willingness to follow His guidance, to be sensitive to His promptings, and to allow Him to shape our thoughts, words, and actions. This is not a passive experience; it requires active participation in the life of faith. We must be willing to submit to His will and to trust in His wisdom, even when the path ahead is unclear. The promise is clear: If we are led by the Spirit, we are recognized as sons and daughters of God. This brings immense comfort, assurance, and a deep sense of belonging. It is a privilege and a responsibility. We are called to live lives that reflect the character of our Father, bearing witness to His love and grace in a world that desperately needs it. Let us strive daily to be more attuned to the Spirit's leading, trusting that He will guide us into all truth and righteousness.

para_meditar.texto: This I say then, Walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh.

Howbeit when he, the Spirit of truth, is come, he will guide you into all truth: for he shall not speak of himself; but whatsoever he shall hear, that shall he speak: and he will shew you things to come.
Teach me to do thy will; for thou art my God: thy spirit is good; lead me into the land of uprightness.

2026-03-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the gift of Your Holy Spirit, who guides and directs our lives. We acknowledge our need for Your guidance and ask for Your help in being more sensitive to His leading. Help us to discern Your voice amidst the noise of the world and to walk in accordance with Your will. Grant us the strength to resist the temptations of the flesh and to embrace the path of righteousness. Open our hearts to receive Your wisdom and understanding, and empower us to live lives that honor You. May we be ever mindful of our identity as children of God, reflecting Your love and grace in all that we do. Thank You for the promise that those who are led by Your Spirit are indeed Your children. We surrender our lives to You, trusting in Your perfect plan. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-16.versiculo: Luke 24:6-7 KJV: "He is not here, but is risen: remember how he spake unto you when he was yet in Galilee, Saying, The Son of man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and the third day rise again."
2026-03-16.reflexion: The empty tomb and the angels' declaration in Luke 24:6-7 are the very heart of the Christian faith. "He is not here, but is risen." These words shatter the despair of the disciples and offer the promise of eternal life. The angels then remind them of Jesus' previous teachings, specifically his predictions of his death and resurrection. This is crucial. Jesus didn't just stumble into resurrection; it was the culmination of a divine plan. He knew the suffering that awaited him, the betrayal, the crucifixion, and yet, he chose to endure it all for our salvation. The angels' words are a call to remember, to reflect on the words of Jesus, to understand that his death was not a defeat, but a victory over sin and death. This verse is a powerful reminder of the fulfillment of prophecy and the unwavering love of God. It encourages us to look beyond our present circumstances, to trust in the promises of God, and to live with the hope that comes from knowing that Jesus conquered death and lives eternally. This passage encourages us to study the scriptures, to find the prophecies that tell us about Jesus, and to believe in the power of his resurrection, which guarantees us eternal life.

para_meditar.texto: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
And that he was buried, and that he rose again the third day according to the scriptures:
Jesus said unto her, I am the resurrection, and the life: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live:

2026-03-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the glorious truth of the resurrection of Jesus Christ. Thank you for the empty tomb, a testament to your power and love. Help us to remember the words of Jesus, to understand the depth of his sacrifice, and to live with the hope of eternal life. Grant us the faith to believe in his resurrection, to trust in your promises, and to live a life worthy of the calling. Give us strength to share this good news with others, that they too may come to know the saving grace of Jesus. Open our hearts and minds to receive your word, and to be transformed by the power of the Holy Spirit. Guide us to a deeper understanding of your word, and help us to remember that Jesus is not here, but is risen. May we always put our trust in you, and may your love and mercy fill our lives. We thank you for your unwavering love and sacrifice, and we praise your holy name. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-17.versiculo: Revelation 1:8 KJV: "I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending, saith the Lord, which is, and which was, and which is to come, the Almighty."
2026-03-17.reflexion: Today's verse, Revelation 1:8, is a powerful declaration of God's eternal nature and absolute authority. It introduces the Lord as 'Alpha and Omega,' the first and the last, encompassing all of existence. This title speaks to God's sovereignty over time and creation. He is not just a God of the past or the future, but the eternal 'I AM,' present in every moment. The phrase 'which is, and which was, and which is to come' emphasizes His unchanging nature, a stark contrast to the fleeting nature of the world around us. The title 'Almighty' (Pantokrator in Greek) further underscores God's supreme power and dominion. This verse offers profound comfort and assurance. In a world filled with uncertainty and change, we can find solace in the knowledge that God is in control. His sovereignty extends over all things, and His plans will ultimately prevail. This is a call to trust in Him completely, to rely on His strength, and to live our lives with a perspective rooted in His eternal purpose. Knowing that the Almighty is with us empowers us to face challenges with courage and live with hope.

para_meditar.texto: Who hath wrought and done it, calling the generations from the beginning? I the Lord, the first, and with the last; I am he.
Before the mountains were brought forth, or ever thou hadst formed the earth and the world, even from everlasting to everlasting, thou art God.
Jesus Christ the same yesterday, and to day, and for ever.

2026-03-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts filled with awe and reverence. We praise You for being the Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end, the Almighty God. Thank You for Your eternal nature and unchanging character. We acknowledge Your sovereignty over all things and trust in Your perfect plan. Help us to remember that You are always with us, guiding and protecting us. Grant us the wisdom to discern Your will and the strength to live according to Your truth. Fill us with Your peace and help us to face each day with unwavering faith, knowing that You hold the future in Your hands. Empower us to share Your love with others and to point them to You, the source of all hope and salvation. We ask all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-18.versiculo: John 10:10 KJV: "The thief cometh not, but for to steal, and to kill, and to destroy: I am come that they might have life, and that they might have it more abundantly."
2026-03-18.reflexion: John 10:10 is a powerful verse that encapsulates the very essence of the Christian faith. It starkly contrasts the intentions of the enemy (the thief) with the purpose of Jesus Christ. The thief, representing Satan, comes to steal, kill, and destroy. His mission is one of ruin, bringing spiritual death and robbing us of the joy and fullness of life. In contrast, Jesus comes to offer life, and not just any life, but life more abundantly. This 'abundant life' is not just about physical well-being, but a life overflowing with purpose, peace, joy, and a deep connection with God. It's a life characterized by spiritual vitality, resilience in the face of adversity, and the fulfillment of God's calling. Jesus offers a life that transcends earthly limitations, a life that is eternal in its significance. This verse reminds us that we have a choice: to live under the dominion of the thief, or to embrace the abundant life offered by Jesus. This abundant life is found in knowing Him, in following His teachings, and in allowing Him to be the Lord of our lives. It’s a life of freedom, love, and unwavering hope.

para_meditar.texto: In him was life; and the life was the light of men.
For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.

I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.

2026-03-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the gift of life, and especially for the abundant life You offer through Jesus Christ. We acknowledge that the enemy seeks to steal, kill, and destroy, but we choose to turn away from his darkness and embrace Your light. Help us to recognize and resist the schemes of the thief, and to cling to the promises of a life filled with purpose, peace, and joy. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may live each day in the fullness of Your grace and love. Guide us to walk in the path of righteousness, allowing Your life to flow through us to bless others. Grant us wisdom and discernment to choose life, and to live it abundantly, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-19.versiculo: Hebrews 13:15-16 KJV: "By him therefore let us offer the sacrifice of praise to God continually, that is, the fruit of our lips giving thanks to his name. But to do good and to communicate forget not: for with such sacrifices God is pleased."
2026-03-19.reflexion:
Today's passage from Hebrews calls us to a life of continuous praise and active service. Verse 15 urges us to offer the 'sacrifice of praise to God continually.' This isn't just about singing hymns in church; it's about cultivating a heart overflowing with gratitude, expressing thanks to God in every circumstance, and letting our words reflect His glory. We are called to make praise a lifestyle, not just a Sunday activity. 

Furthermore, verse 16 expands on this by connecting our worship with practical acts of love. We are instructed not to forget 'to do good and to communicate'. This means actively seeking opportunities to help others, sharing our resources, and living generously. This isn't about earning God's favor; it's about responding to His grace. Doing good and sharing with others is a natural outpouring of a grateful heart. It is a sacrifice that pleases God. The implication is clear: our worship is incomplete without a corresponding commitment to loving our neighbor. True worship is a holistic expression of faith that encompasses both our words of praise and our actions of service.

para_meditar.texto: Offer unto God thanksgiving; and pay thy vows unto the most High:

Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things.
And the King shall answer and say unto them, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my brethren, ye have done it unto me.

2026-03-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, I thank you for this day and for the reminder of how to live a life that pleases you. Help me to offer you the sacrifice of praise continually, through the words of my mouth and the gratitude in my heart. Guide me to see the needs of those around me and to act with generosity and compassion. Open my eyes to opportunities to do good, to share what I have, and to demonstrate your love to others. Give me a heart that is both thankful and giving, reflecting your grace in all I do. Strengthen me to live a life of true worship, expressed in both praise and service. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-20.versiculo: Matthew 5:44-45 KJV: "But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you; That ye may be the children of your Father which is in heaven: for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust."
2026-03-20.reflexion: Today's verses from Matthew challenge us to embrace a radical love, a love that transcends the boundaries of familiarity and comfort. Jesus commands us to love our enemies, those who actively oppose us, curse us, and persecute us. This is not a suggestion; it is a command. This kind of love is not based on feeling, but on a deliberate act of the will, mirroring the unconditional love God has for us. It is a reflection of His character. God does not withhold His blessings, the sun and the rain, from the wicked. He extends grace to all. We, as His children, are called to do the same. Loving our enemies demonstrates that we are truly children of God, reflecting His nature and bearing witness to the transformative power of the Gospel. This is a call to action, to consciously choose to love, bless, and pray for those who may seem undeserving. It is in these acts of love that we truly display the character of Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Bless them which persecute you: bless, and curse not.
But I say unto you which hear, Love your enemies, do good to them which hate you, Bless them that curse you, and pray for them which despitefully use you.
Who, when he was reviled, reviled not again; when he suffered, he threatened not; but committed himself to him that judgeth righteously.

2026-03-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, help me to embody the love of Christ today. Grant me the strength to love my enemies, to bless those who curse me, and to pray for those who persecute me. Remove any bitterness or resentment from my heart, and replace it with Your boundless grace and compassion. Help me to see others through Your eyes, recognizing their value and their need for Your love. Give me the courage to act in ways that reflect Your character, even when it is difficult. Guide me to extend kindness and forgiveness to all, just as You have extended it to me. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, so that I may be a true reflection of Your love in the world. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-21.versiculo: Philippians 4:8 KJV: "Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things."
2026-03-21.reflexion: Today's verse, Philippians 4:8, is a powerful call to mental discipline. Paul urges us to focus our thoughts on things that are true, honest, just, pure, lovely, and of good report. In a world filled with negativity, distractions, and deceit, this is a challenging but essential practice for the believer. It's about cultivating a mindset that aligns with God's character and His will for our lives. We are not simply to avoid thinking about negative things; we are actively to *think on* the positive attributes Paul describes. This requires intentionality. It means consciously choosing what we allow into our minds through the media we consume, the conversations we have, and the thoughts we entertain. It's a battle for our minds, a battle that, when fought with the Spirit's guidance, leads to peace and a deepening relationship with Christ. By meditating on these virtuous qualities, we invite the presence of God to fill our thoughts, shaping our character and guiding our actions. This is not just about feeling good; it's about living a life that reflects the beauty and truth of the Gospel.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
Let the words of my mouth, and the meditation of my heart, be acceptable in thy sight, O LORD, my strength, and my redeemer.
Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.

2026-03-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today, seeking Your guidance in the ongoing battle for my mind. I confess that I often allow thoughts that are not true, honest, or pure to enter my mind. I ask for Your help to cast down these imaginations and every high thing that exalts itself against the knowledge of God. Fill my mind with thoughts that are pleasing to You, thoughts of truth, honesty, justice, purity, loveliness, and good report. Help me to be diligent in guarding my heart and mind, so that the issues of my life may be aligned with Your will. Give me the strength to resist the temptations of the world and to renew my mind daily through Your Word and the power of the Holy Spirit. Help me to fix my thoughts on You and Your goodness, allowing Your peace to reign in my heart. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-22.versiculo: Colossians 1:15-17 KJV: "Who is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of every creature: For by him were all things created, that are in heaven, and that are in earth, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones, or dominions, or principalities, or powers: all things were created by him, and for him: And he is before all things, and by him all things consist."
2026-03-22.reflexion: Today's verses in Colossians paint a breathtaking portrait of Jesus Christ. They declare Him to be the exact image of the invisible God, the firstborn of all creation. This speaks not just to His preeminence, but to His divine nature, revealing the unseen God to us. Consider the implications: if Jesus is the image of God, then looking at Jesus is like looking at God Himself. Furthermore, these verses proclaim that all things were created by Him and for Him. This includes everything we see and everything we cannot see. The vastness of the universe, the intricate workings of the earth, the invisible realm of spiritual beings – all were brought into existence through Jesus. This emphasizes His role as the ultimate creator and sustainer. He is before all things, meaning He existed before creation, and by Him all things hold together. This speaks to His power, His authority, and His constant presence in the universe. This passage calls us to revere Jesus, to acknowledge His authority, and to live lives that reflect His glory, for He is the source and sustainer of all.

para_meditar.texto: All things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made that was made.

Who being the brightness of his glory, and the express image of his person, and upholding all things by the word of his power, when he had by himself purged our sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high;
Thou art worthy, O Lord, to receive glory and honour and power: for thou hast created all things, and for thy pleasure they are and were created.

2026-03-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts filled with awe and wonder, contemplating the majesty of Your Son, Jesus Christ. We thank You for revealing Yourself to us through Him, the image of the invisible God. Help us to see Jesus in all things, to recognize His creative power, and to live in obedience to His will. Grant us the wisdom to understand that all things were created by Him and for Him. Give us the strength to surrender our lives to His Lordship, allowing Him to be the center of all we do. May we reflect His glory in our thoughts, words, and actions. We pray for a deeper understanding of His grace and love, and a renewed commitment to live a life that honors Him. We ask all this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-23.versiculo: 1 Timothy 6:12 KJV: "Fight the good fight of faith, lay hold on eternal life, whereunto thou art also called, and hast professed a good profession before many witnesses."
2026-03-23.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in his letter to Timothy, urges a call to arms, not of flesh and blood, but of the spirit. He commands us to “fight the good fight of faith.” This isn't a battle against external enemies, but an internal struggle against doubt, fear, and the temptations of the world. It is a constant striving to remain steadfast in our belief in Jesus Christ, to live according to His teachings, and to resist the allure of sin. The phrase “lay hold on eternal life” is a powerful directive. It's not a passive waiting for salvation, but an active pursuit of it. We are called to grasp onto the promise of eternal life with both hands, to make it our priority, and to live in a way that reflects our hope in it. The “good profession before many witnesses” reminds us of the responsibility that comes with faith. We are witnesses to the goodness of God, and our lives should reflect this. Our actions, words, and character should be a testament to the transformative power of the Gospel. This verse calls us to be active participants in our faith, to fight for it, and to live it out boldly for all to see. It is a call to a life of purpose, dedication, and unwavering commitment to Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Wherefore seeing we also are compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us,

Only let your conversation be as it becometh the gospel of Christ: that whether I come and see you, or else be absent, I may hear of your affairs, that ye stand fast in one spirit, with one mind striving together for the faith of the gospel;
I have fought a good fight, I have finished my course, I have kept the faith:

2026-03-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the strength and guidance found in Your Word. Today, I pray for the courage to fight the good fight of faith, to resist the temptations that seek to pull me away from You. Help me to hold fast to the promise of eternal life, and to live a life that honors You. Grant me the boldness to profess my faith before others, that my life might be a witness to Your goodness and grace. Give me the wisdom to discern Your will and the strength to follow it, day by day. Help me to lay aside every weight and sin that so easily besets me, that I may run with perseverance the race marked out for me. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may live a life worthy of the calling I have received. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-24.versiculo: Romans 15:4 KJV: "For whatsoever things were written aforetime were written for our learning, that we through patience and comfort of the scriptures might have hope."
2026-03-24.reflexion: Today's verse reminds us of the enduring power of Scripture. The Apostle Paul, in Romans 15:4, emphasizes that the Old Testament, and by extension the entire Bible, serves as a source of learning for us. The purpose of these ancient writings wasn't merely to record history, but to guide us, to teach us, and to shape our understanding of God and His will. The phrase "written aforetime" signifies that the scriptures are timeless; their wisdom and lessons are just as relevant now as they were when first penned. The key to unlocking the treasures of the Bible is found in "patience and comfort of the scriptures." We need patience to study diligently, to wrestle with difficult passages, and to allow the Holy Spirit to illuminate our understanding. The scriptures offer comfort in times of trouble, providing hope when we feel despair. They remind us of God's faithfulness, His love, and His unwavering presence in our lives. Through the scriptures, we find the hope that sustains us through life's challenges, the hope that anchors our faith, and the hope that points us to the eternal promises of God. Let us embrace the wisdom of the scriptures, allowing them to guide our lives and to fill us with hope.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.

For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.
All scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness:

2026-03-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of your Word. Thank you for the scriptures that give us wisdom, guidance, and hope. Help us to approach the Bible with patience and a seeking heart, eager to learn from the stories, the prophecies, and the teachings within its pages. Grant us understanding as we read, that we may grasp the truths that will transform our lives. Comfort us in times of sorrow, and strengthen our faith in times of doubt. May we find hope in your promises, and may your Word illuminate our path, guiding us closer to you. Help us to apply the lessons we learn to our daily lives, that we may be a reflection of your love and grace. We ask all these things, trusting in your faithfulness, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-25.versiculo: John 15:1 KJV: "I am the true vine, and my Father is the husbandman."
2026-03-25.reflexion: Today's verse, John 15:1, unveils a profound truth: Jesus declares Himself to be the true vine, and God the Father, the husbandman. This imagery paints a vivid picture of our relationship with Christ and the Father. The vine represents Jesus, the source of life and sustenance. We, as believers, are the branches, utterly dependent on Him for our spiritual well-being. The husbandman, God, lovingly tends to the vine, pruning and caring for it so that it may bear fruit. This pruning process, though sometimes painful, is essential for our growth. It represents the trials and tribulations that refine our faith and draw us closer to Christ. We are called to abide in Him, to remain connected to the source of life. This abiding requires conscious effort—prayer, Bible reading, and obedience to His Word. Just as a branch detached from the vine withers and dies, so too will our spiritual lives suffer if we are not intimately connected to Jesus. We must cultivate a deep and abiding relationship with Him, allowing Him to be the center of our lives, the source of our strength, and the foundation of our hope. This is not merely a metaphor; it is a call to action: to live a life rooted in Christ, bearing fruit that glorifies the Father.

para_meditar.texto: I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.
He that dwelleth in the secret place of the most High shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty.
I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.

2026-03-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the profound imagery of the vine and the branches. Thank you, Jesus, for being the true vine, the source of life, and for the Father's loving care as the husbandman. Help me to abide in You, to remain connected to You in every aspect of my life. Grant me the strength to endure the pruning, knowing that it is for my growth and fruitfulness. Guide me to cultivate a deeper relationship with You through prayer, Bible study, and obedience to Your Word. Help me to bear fruit worthy of Your name, and to glorify You in all that I do. May my life reflect Your love and grace, and may I always be rooted in You. May I always recognize my dependence on You and live a life that honors You. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-26.versiculo: Matthew 4:19 KJV: "And he saith unto them, Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men."
2026-03-26.reflexion: Matthew 4:19 is a powerful invitation, a call to discipleship that echoes through the ages. Jesus, having begun His ministry, doesn't offer a complex theological treatise; He offers a simple, yet profound command: "Follow me."  He doesn't promise an easy life, but a transformative one. He promises to make them "fishers of men."  This wasn't just a job description; it was a declaration of purpose. The disciples were to leave their familiar lives, their livelihoods, and their comfort zones to become instruments in God's redemptive plan. The act of fishing, a common occupation then, becomes a metaphor for evangelism.  It speaks of drawing people out of the depths of sin and despair, into the light of the Gospel.  This verse challenges us to consider our own response to Christ’s call.  Are we willing to leave behind our own nets, our own pursuits, and follow Him? Are we ready to become fishers of men, sharing the good news of salvation with others?  It reminds us that following Jesus is not passive; it requires action, commitment, and a willingness to engage with the world around us. It's a call to a life of purpose, a life of impacting eternity.

para_meditar.texto: And Jesus said unto them, Come ye after me, and I will make you to become fishers of men.

Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you, and ordained you, that ye should go and bring forth fruit, and that your fruit should remain: that whatsoever ye shall ask of the Father in my name, he may give it you.
Now then we are ambassadors for Christ, as though God did beseech you by us: we pray you in Christ's stead, be ye reconciled to God.

2026-03-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the clear and compelling call of Jesus in Matthew 4:19. Thank You for the invitation to follow You, and for the promise of transformation. Help me to be obedient to this call, to lay down my own pursuits and embrace the purpose You have for my life. Grant me the courage to share the Gospel with others, to be a fisher of men, drawing them towards Your love and grace. Give me the boldness to speak the truth in love, and to be a light in the darkness. Help me to be sensitive to the leading of the Holy Spirit and to trust in Your guidance. Equip me with the words to speak and the love to share. May I be a faithful witness to Your saving power, bringing glory to Your name, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-27.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 13:1-3 KJV: "Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal. And though I have the gift of prophecy, and understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and though I have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing. And though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing."
2026-03-27.reflexion: Today's passage, 1 Corinthians 13:1-3, eloquently reveals the supremacy of love. Paul paints a vivid picture, illustrating that even the most impressive spiritual gifts and acts of service are rendered meaningless without love. He begins by comparing speaking in tongues, a highly esteemed gift, to the hollow sounds of a noisy instrument if not motivated by love. He then moves on to prophecy, understanding of mysteries, and even faith that can move mountains, emphasizing that these are all in vain without love. Finally, he considers acts of selflessness, such as giving away possessions and enduring martyrdom, and concludes that even these heroic deeds are worthless without love. This passage challenges us to examine our motivations. Are we driven by a desire for recognition, power, or self-gratification? Or are our actions rooted in genuine love for God and for others? True love, as described in the following verses of this chapter, is patient, kind, and selfless. It is the foundation upon which all other virtues are built. Let us strive to cultivate this love in our hearts, allowing it to permeate every aspect of our lives, and thus make our actions truly meaningful and pleasing to God.

para_meditar.texto: A new commandment I give unto you, That ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another.
Let love be without dissimulation. Abhor that which is evil; cleave to that which is good.
He that loveth not knoweth not God; for God is love.

2026-03-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today, humbled by the profound message of love in Your Word. We confess that we often fall short of loving others as You have loved us. We are quick to judge, slow to forgive, and sometimes driven by selfish desires. Forgive us, Lord, and cleanse our hearts. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may experience Your perfect love and allow it to overflow into our interactions with others. Help us to be patient, kind, and compassionate, bearing with one another in love. Grant us the wisdom to discern Your will and the strength to act in accordance with it. Guide us to love our neighbors as ourselves, and to show Your love to a world desperately in need of it. We pray for the grace to prioritize love above all else, that our lives may be a reflection of Your glory, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-28.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 5:7 KJV: "(For we walk by faith, not by sight:)"
2026-03-28.reflexion:
Today's verse, 2 Corinthians 5:7, calls us to a life governed by faith, not by what we can see. This is a profound statement, a cornerstone of the Christian walk. It acknowledges the inherent limitations of our human perspective. We are often tempted to rely on our senses, on tangible evidence, on what we can physically experience. But faith transcends the realm of the visible. It is a trust in the unseen, a conviction in the promises of God, even when circumstances seem to contradict them. 

Walking by faith means trusting in God's character, His love, His power, and His plan, even when the path ahead is unclear or challenging. It's about believing in the eternal realities of heaven, the forgiveness of sins, and the hope of resurrection. It's about living in the present with the assurance that God is working all things together for good, for those who love Him. This requires a deliberate choice to shift our focus from the temporary to the eternal, from the visible to the invisible. It requires a daily commitment to prayer, to studying God's Word, and to seeking His guidance in all aspects of our lives. It’s a journey, not a destination, a continual process of learning to trust and rely on God's promises, even when we cannot see the outcome.

para_meditar.texto: Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.
For we are saved by hope: but hope that is seen is not hope: for what a man seeth, why doth he yet hope for?
Trust in the Lord with all thine heart; and lean not unto thine own understanding.

2026-03-28.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today acknowledging our weakness and our tendency to rely on our own understanding and what we can see. We confess that we often struggle to walk by faith, allowing the circumstances of life to cloud our vision and shake our trust. Lord, help us to see beyond the immediate, to fix our eyes on the eternal realities of your kingdom. Grant us the grace to trust in your promises, even when we cannot see the outcome. Strengthen our faith, Lord, and teach us to lean on you with all our hearts. Fill us with your peace, which surpasses all understanding, and help us to walk confidently in the path you have set before us. Give us the courage to live by faith, not by sight, trusting in your unwavering love and faithfulness. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-03-29.versiculo: 2 Timothy 2:15 KJV: "Study to shew thyself approved unto God, a workman that needeth not to be ashamed, rightly dividing the word of truth."
2026-03-29.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Timothy 2:15, calls us to diligent study. It's a command, not a suggestion. We are to "study to shew thyself approved unto God." This isn't about academic achievement or intellectual prowess; it's about the condition of our hearts before God. The goal is to be "a workman that needeth not to be ashamed," a person who can stand before God without embarrassment. This comes from rightly dividing the word of truth. This means understanding the Bible accurately, contextually, and with discernment. It's about knowing the intent of the author, the historical context, and the overarching narrative of Scripture. It's about applying the teachings to our lives. The process is not passive; it demands work. It requires effort, discipline, and a willingness to learn and be corrected. It's a call to actively engage with the Word of God, allowing it to shape our minds, hearts, and actions. It's about seeking truth with sincerity and humility, recognizing our dependence on the Holy Spirit for understanding. Let us dedicate ourselves to this vital task, so we may be found faithful and approved by God.

para_meditar.texto: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.

For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.
But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.

2026-03-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today with a desire to understand your Word more deeply. I acknowledge my need for your guidance and wisdom as I study. Grant me a teachable heart and a discerning mind, that I may rightly divide the word of truth. Help me to see beyond the surface, to grasp the true meaning and application of your teachings. Remove any pride or arrogance that might hinder my understanding. Fill me with the Holy Spirit, that I may be guided into all truth. Give me the strength and discipline to dedicate myself to this important task, that I may grow in faith and become a workman approved by you. 2026-03-31.versiculo: 1 John 5:20 KJV: "And we know that the Son of God is come, and hath given us an understanding, that we may know him that is true, and we are in him that is true, even in his Son Jesus Christ. This is the true God, and eternal life."

We, as believers, are called to be servants, not masters. Our role is to serve others for Jesus' sake, to facilitate their connection with Him, and to guide them toward a deeper understanding of His grace and truth. This is not always easy. However, Paul's words remind us that the true reward comes not from earthly praise, but from the joy of seeing lives transformed by the Gospel. Wrath, a sudden burst of uncontrolled anger, can damage both ourselves and those around us. Anger, when unaddressed, festers into resentment, while clamour, the loud and disruptive expression of our discontent, further fractures community. Evil speaking, the gossip and slander that tears down others, is a direct violation of the commandment to love our neighbor. And at the root of it all lies malice, the deliberate intent to cause harm. Paul's call to 'put away' these things is not merely a suggestion; it is a command. It requires a conscious effort, a daily dying to self, and a reliance on the Holy Spirit to cultivate the fruits of gentleness, kindness, and forgiveness. This is a journey of transformation, a path toward becoming more like Christ, who bore our sins and offered forgiveness even from the cross.

We are instructed to "prove all things," urging us to examine and evaluate every aspect of our beliefs, actions, and the influences around us. This is not a passive acceptance of what we are told, but an active engagement with the truth. We must scrutinize, test, and analyze everything, measuring it against the standard of God's Word. 

Following this vital process of discernment, we are commanded to "hold fast that which is good." This is not just about identifying what is good, but clinging to it, embracing it, and making it an integral part of our lives. It calls for a steadfast commitment to the truth, to righteousness, and to the principles of our faith. This is about the strength of our conviction. 

Finally, we are admonished to "abstain from all appearance of evil." This goes beyond merely avoiding evil acts; it extends to abstaining from anything that even has the appearance of evil. It is a call for vigilance, for sensitivity to the Holy Spirit's guidance, and for a commitment to living a life above reproach. We are to be careful in our actions and in the image we project, ensuring that our lives reflect the light of Christ and avoid any association with darkness. In a world saturated with compromise and moral ambiguity, this instruction is a powerful reminder of the high standard to which we are called to live. It is a call to be discerning, to hold fast to the good, and to avoid even the appearance of evil, allowing the Holy Spirit to lead us in all things.

2026-04-09.versiculo: 1 John 4:9-10 KJV: "In this was manifested the love of God toward us, because that God sent his only begotten Son into the world, that we might live through him. Herein is love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and sent his Son to be the propitiation for our sins."
