Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.

2026-04-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, I thank you for the resurrection of Jesus Christ and for the new life I have in Him. Help me, Lord, to truly live as one who has been raised with Christ. Give me the strength to actively seek the things that are above, to set my affections on the eternal realities of Your kingdom. Help me to resist the temptations of the world and to prioritize my relationship with You. Guide my thoughts, my desires, and my actions to align with Your will. Fill me with the joy and peace that comes from knowing You, and help me to live a life that honors You in all I do. I pray for a heart that is constantly seeking You, a mind that is focused on Your truth, and a life that reflects Your love. Transform me, Lord, from the inside out, that I may be a vessel fit for Your glory, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-12.versiculo: Colossians 2:8 KJV: "Beware lest any man spoil you through philosophy and vain deceit, after the tradition of men, after the rudiments of the world, and not after Christ."
2026-04-12.reflexion: Today's verse, Colossians 2:8, serves as a crucial warning against being led astray by deceptive philosophies and worldly traditions. Paul urges us to be vigilant, lest we be 'spoiled' – robbed of our spiritual inheritance and relationship with Christ. The 'philosophy and vain deceit' he speaks of refers to ideas and teachings that contradict the truth of the Gospel. These can be subtle, appearing attractive and insightful, but ultimately leading away from the core message of salvation through Jesus Christ. The 'tradition of men' and 'rudiments of the world' are the human-made systems and principles that prioritize worldly values over the teachings of Christ. These can manifest in various forms, such as cultural norms, societal pressures, and intellectual trends. The danger lies in prioritizing these over the ultimate truth found in Christ. To stay firmly rooted in Christ, we must actively discern what aligns with His teachings and reject what does not. This requires a constant engagement with scripture, prayer, and fellowship with other believers. We must cultivate a mind that is transformed by the Word of God and a heart that is devoted to Him. Only then can we avoid being 'spoiled' and remain steadfast in our faith, grounded in the truth of Jesus Christ.

para_meditar.texto: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
For the preaching of the cross is to them that perish foolishness; but unto us which are saved it is the power of God.
Be not carried about with divers and strange doctrines. For it is a good thing that the heart be established with grace; not with meats, which have not profited them that have been occupied therein.

2026-04-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with a humble heart, seeking your guidance and wisdom. We thank you for the warning in Colossians 2:8, and we pray for discernment to recognize and resist the deceptive philosophies and worldly influences that seek to pull us away from you. Help us to be vigilant in our thoughts and actions, constantly testing everything against the truth of your Word. Grant us the strength to stand firm in our faith, rooted in the love and grace of Jesus Christ. Open our hearts to receive your truth and help us to seek your will above all else. Surround us with fellow believers who will encourage and support us in our journey. Protect us from the distractions of the world and help us to focus on your kingdom. We pray for a renewed commitment to studying your Word, praying continually, and seeking your presence in every aspect of our lives, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-13.versiculo: 1 Timothy 3:16 KJV: "And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, seen of angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory."
2026-04-13.reflexion: Today’s verse, 1 Timothy 3:16, unveils a profound truth: the mystery of godliness. This mystery isn't a secret kept from humanity, but a truth revealed through the person of Jesus Christ. The verse encapsulates the essence of the Gospel. God, in His infinite love, chose to manifest Himself in human flesh. He lived a perfect life, was justified by the Holy Spirit, and bore witness to the divine nature. Angels, heavenly beings, witnessed His glory. This divine revelation was then preached to the Gentiles, extending salvation beyond the Jewish people. This message of hope and redemption was believed throughout the world, and ultimately, Jesus was received into glory. This verse reminds us of the magnitude of God's plan for salvation. It is a call to marvel at the miracle of the incarnation, the power of the resurrection, and the promise of eternal life. Let us embrace the mystery of godliness, allowing it to shape our lives and draw us closer to the God who became man for us.

para_meditar.texto: And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth.
And declared to be the Son of God with power, according to the spirit of holiness, by the resurrection from the dead:

Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name: That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

2026-04-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, we approach Your throne with hearts full of gratitude and awe. We thank You for the profound mystery of godliness, for the revelation of Your love through Jesus Christ. We marvel at His manifestation in the flesh, His perfect life, and His ultimate sacrifice for our sins. Open our hearts to fully grasp the magnitude of Your grace. Help us to preach the Gospel with boldness, to share the good news with those who have yet to hear. May we live lives that reflect Your glory, lives that are filled with the Holy Spirit, and lives that point others towards Your Son. Grant us the wisdom to understand Your Word, and the strength to walk in Your ways. We pray for those who are struggling, for those who are lost, and for all those who seek You. Guide us, protect us, and use us to spread Your message of hope and salvation, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-14.versiculo: Mark 9:35 KJV: "And he sat down, and called the twelve, and saith unto them, If any man desire to be first, the same shall be last of all, and servant of all."
2026-04-14.reflexion: The words of Jesus in Mark 9:35 are a profound challenge to the human desire for recognition and power. In a world obsessed with status and achievement, Christ flips the script, declaring that true greatness lies in humility and service. He doesn't dismiss the ambition to be 'first', but redefines it. The path to true leadership, according to Jesus, is not through dominance or self-promotion, but through selflessness and service. This verse calls us to examine our hearts. Are we striving for positions of authority to be seen, or to serve? Are we willing to embrace the role of a servant, even when it means being last? The key is not in avoiding leadership, but in leading with the heart of a servant. This requires a conscious decision to prioritize the needs of others above our own, to be willing to get our hands dirty, and to be content with a position of obscurity if it means serving others more effectively. This is a radical concept, one that goes against the grain of human nature, but it is the very foundation of true Christian living and the path to genuine spiritual fulfillment. It is in serving others that we truly find ourselves and reflect the heart of Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves.
Even as the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.
If I then, your Lord and Master, have washed your feet; ye also ought to wash one another's feet. For I have given you an example, that ye should do as I have done to you.

2026-04-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, help me to understand the true meaning of greatness as defined by Your Son, Jesus Christ. I confess that I often struggle with pride and the desire for recognition. Forgive me for the times I have sought to be served rather than to serve. Grant me the humility to embrace the role of a servant, to put the needs of others before my own, and to find joy in serving. Give me a heart that is compassionate and willing to reach out to those in need. Help me to be a light in the world, reflecting the love and grace of Jesus in all that I do. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be empowered to live a life of service and selflessness, and to truly follow in the footsteps of Christ. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-15.versiculo: Matthew 16:18-19 KJV: "And I say also unto thee, That thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my church; and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it. And I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven."
2026-04-15.reflexion: Today's passage from Matthew 16:18-19 offers profound insights into the foundation and authority of the Church. Jesus declares that He will build His Church upon the 'rock,' understood by many to be Peter's confession of faith that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of the living God. This rock-solid foundation ensures that the gates of hell, the forces of evil, will not overcome it. The Church, empowered by this foundation, is then given the keys of the kingdom of heaven. This signifies the authority to declare what is bound or loosed, to make pronouncements about sin and forgiveness, and to administer the sacraments. This passage emphasizes the power and responsibility entrusted to the Church. We are called to be steadfast in our faith, to build upon the foundation of Jesus Christ, and to actively participate in the work of the Kingdom. This is a call to recognize the authority given to us and to live in accordance with the principles of heaven, striving to bind and loose in ways that reflect God's will. It is a reminder of the powerful role we play in spreading the gospel and establishing God's kingdom on earth.

para_meditar.texto: And are built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the chief corner stone;

2026-04-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today, thankful for the foundation of faith that You have provided through Your Son, Jesus Christ. We acknowledge the power of Your Church and the authority You have bestowed upon it. Grant us the wisdom to build our lives upon this solid rock, to be steadfast in our faith, and to participate actively in Your Kingdom work. Help us to use the gifts and authority You have given us to spread the Gospel, to bind what needs to be bound, and to loose what needs to be loosed, always according to Your will. Guide us to live in accordance with Your principles, and to be beacons of hope and truth in a world that desperately needs You. Strengthen us in our commitment to serve You, and help us to be effective instruments of Your love and grace. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-16.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 5:17 KJV: "Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new."
2026-04-16.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Corinthians 5:17, offers a profound declaration of spiritual transformation. It speaks of a radical shift in identity and existence for those who are 'in Christ.' The phrase 'new creature' (or 'new creation') signifies a complete renewal, a spiritual rebirth that transcends our earthly limitations. It's not merely a superficial change, but a fundamental alteration of our very essence. The 'old things' represent our former lives, marked by sin, separation from God, and the struggles of the flesh. These things, the verse assures us, 'are passed away.' This implies a definitive leave-taking, a letting go of the burdens and bondages of our past. The 'behold, all things are become new' is an exclamation of wonder and awe. Everything is transformed. Our perspective, our desires, our relationships, and our very purpose are all renewed. This isn't just a promise for the future; it's a present reality for those who are in Christ. It is a call to embrace this new identity, to walk in the light of God's grace, and to live a life that reflects the transformative power of the Gospel. This verse invites us to constantly assess whether we are truly living in this new creation, actively rejecting the 'old things' and embracing the 'new' life that God has given us.

para_meditar.texto: Therefore we are buried with him by baptism into death: that like as Christ was raised up from the dead by the glory of the Father, even so we also should walk in newness of life.

I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.

That ye put off concerning the former conversation the old man, which is corrupt according to the deceitful lusts; And be renewed in the spirit of your mind; And that ye put on the new man, which after God is created in righteousness and true holiness.

2026-04-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the incredible gift of new life in Christ Jesus. Thank You that when we come to You, we are made new, our sins are forgiven, and the old things pass away. Help me to fully embrace my new identity in You. Grant me the strength to continually put off the old self and to walk in the newness of life. Help me to see the world through Your eyes, to love as You love, and to live a life that glorifies Your name. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be transformed daily into the image of Jesus Christ. Guide me in all my ways, and give me the wisdom to make choices that honor You. I pray that I may be a light in this world, sharing the good news of Your grace and redemption with others. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-17.versiculo: 1 Peter 3:15 KJV: "But sanctify the Lord God in your hearts: and be ready always to give an answer to every man that asketh you a reason of the hope that is in you with meekness and fear:"
2026-04-17.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Peter 3:15, calls us to a life of preparedness and reverence. It urges us to 'sanctify the Lord God in your hearts,' which means to set apart Christ as holy in our thoughts, actions, and attitudes. This is the foundation of our witness. The verse then instructs us to 'be ready always to give an answer' to those who inquire about the hope we have. This isn't just about having the right answers; it's about living a life that reflects the hope we profess. The 'meekness and fear' mentioned are crucial components. Meekness signifies humility and gentleness, allowing us to share our faith with compassion, understanding, and respect, even when faced with opposition. 'Fear' here is not a terror of God, but a reverential awe that leads us to approach our witness with humility and a deep awareness of the gravity of sharing the Gospel. We are called to be prepared, not just with facts, but with a life that demonstrates the transformative power of Christ, ready to share the reason for the hope that dwells within us, always with gentleness and respect.

para_meditar.texto: For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek.
Let your speech be alway with grace, seasoned with salt, that ye may know how ye ought to answer every man.

In all things shewing thyself a pattern of good works: in doctrine shewing uncorruptness, gravity, sincerity, Sound speech, that cannot be condemned; that he that is of the contrary part may be ashamed, having no evil thing to say of you.

2026-04-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today, seeking your guidance and strength. Help me to sanctify you in my heart, to make you the center of my thoughts, words, and deeds. Grant me the courage to be ready always to share the hope that I have found in you. Fill me with meekness, that I may speak with gentleness and understanding, and with reverence for your presence in my life. Give me the wisdom to answer those who question my faith in a way that honors you and draws them closer to you. Empower me to live a life that reflects your love and grace, so that others may see Christ in me. Guide me and lead me in all my ways, so that I may be a faithful witness for You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-18.versiculo: Romans 5:5 KJV: "And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us."
2026-04-18.reflexion: Today's verse from Romans 5:5 offers a profound insight into the Christian life, linking hope, the love of God, and the indwelling of the Holy Spirit. It assures us that hope, built upon the foundation of God's love, will never disappoint. This is because God's love is not a mere concept; it is a tangible reality, poured out into our hearts by the Holy Spirit. This shedding abroad is a continuous act, a constant flow of divine affection that permeates our being. The Holy Spirit acts as the conduit, the agent of this love, making it accessible to us. This love conquers fear, doubt, and despair. It enables us to withstand trials and tribulations, knowing that we are loved unconditionally. It reminds us that we are not alone in our struggles, but are empowered by the very presence of God within us. By embracing this love, we are transformed, our hearts filled with a joy and peace that surpasses understanding. Let us continually open our hearts to receive the outpouring of God's love through the Holy Spirit, allowing hope to flourish within us and transforming us into vessels of His grace.

para_meditar.texto: And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity.
For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith,

2026-04-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the profound love you have poured out into our hearts through the Holy Spirit. We acknowledge that our hope is not in ourselves, but in your unfailing love. Help us to continually open our hearts to receive the fullness of your love, allowing it to transform us from the inside out. Give us the strength to overcome any fear or doubt, knowing that we are loved unconditionally. Fill us with the joy and peace that surpasses all understanding, so that we may reflect your love to others. May we be witnesses to your grace and mercy in all that we do. Guide us to live a life worthy of your calling, filled with faith, hope, and love. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-19.versiculo: Acts 5:29 KJV: "Then Peter and the other apostles answered and said, We ought to obey God rather than men."
2026-04-19.reflexion: Today's verse, Acts 5:29, resonates with a timeless truth: the ultimate allegiance of a believer lies with God. The apostles, facing persecution and threats from the religious authorities, boldly declared their unwavering commitment to obeying God above all else. This wasn't a casual statement; it was a declaration of faith, a testament to their priorities. The context is crucial. They were commanded to stop preaching the Gospel, a message they believed was divinely mandated. Their response highlights the core of Christian discipleship: a willingness to suffer, to endure, and even to face death, rather than compromise their faith. It speaks to the courage required to stand firm in the face of opposition, to prioritize the will of God over the dictates of men. This verse challenges us to examine our own lives. Are we willing to choose obedience to God, even when it's unpopular, inconvenient, or even dangerous? Do we prioritize God's Word and His commandments above the expectations and pressures of the world? It calls us to a life of intentionality, a life lived in accordance with the principles of the Kingdom of God, regardless of the consequences. It is a reminder that our ultimate reward is not earthly acclaim, but the eternal favor of our Heavenly Father.

para_meditar.texto: No man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.
So that we may boldly say, The Lord is my helper, and I will not fear what man shall do unto me.

2026-04-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts humbled by the boldness of the apostles. Grant us the same courage and unwavering faith that they possessed. Help us to prioritize Your will above all else, to obey Your commands, and to stand firm in the truth, even when faced with adversity. Strengthen us to resist the temptations of the world and to seek Your guidance in every decision we make. Fill us with the Holy Spirit, so that we may be empowered to live lives that honor You. Give us the wisdom to discern Your voice and the strength to follow Your path, no matter the cost. Help us to be witnesses of Your love and grace in a world that desperately needs You. We ask for Your protection and guidance as we strive to live according to Your will, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-20.versiculo: Luke 6:36 KJV: "Be ye therefore merciful, as your Father also is merciful."
2026-04-20.reflexion: The call to be merciful, as outlined in Luke 6:36, is not merely a suggestion, but a divine imperative. It's a reflection of God's very nature, a call to emulate the boundless compassion and forgiveness that He extends to us. The verse encourages us to not only feel empathy but to actively demonstrate mercy in our actions. This means extending grace, overlooking offenses, and offering help to those in need, just as God does for us. It requires us to move beyond our own self-interest and to consider the suffering of others. It challenges us to break down the walls of judgment and prejudice, and to treat others with the same kindness and understanding that we desire for ourselves. Practicing mercy can be difficult, especially when we feel wronged or when others are undeserving in our eyes. Yet, it is in these moments that the true test of our faith lies. By striving to be merciful, we are not only honoring God but also cultivating a heart that is more like His. We are becoming vessels of His love and grace in a world desperately in need of both.

para_meditar.texto: And be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you.
Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.
Put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindness, humbleness of mind, meekness, longsuffering;

2026-04-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for your boundless mercy and grace. We are humbled by your unwavering love and forgiveness, and we recognize our need for your mercy every day. Help us to cultivate hearts that reflect your compassion. Grant us the strength to overcome our own selfishness and to extend kindness and understanding to those around us, especially those who are difficult to love. Guide us to forgive as we have been forgiven, to show mercy even when it is challenging, and to be a beacon of your love in a world that desperately needs it. Let our actions be a testament to your mercy, and may we be instruments of your grace. Empower us to live a life of mercy, reflecting your image in all that we do. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-21.versiculo: Romans 10:4 KJV: "For Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth."
2026-04-21.reflexion:
Today's verse, Romans 10:4, is a pivotal statement about the relationship between the law and righteousness. It declares that Christ is the 'end of the law'. This doesn't mean Christ abolished the law in its entirety, but rather that He is the fulfillment and ultimate goal of the law. The law, in its various commandments and rituals, pointed towards Christ. It revealed humanity's need for a savior and foreshadowed the perfect righteousness that could only be found in Him. 

For those who believe, Christ becomes the source of righteousness. We are no longer judged by our ability to perfectly keep the law, which is an impossible standard for fallen humanity. Instead, through faith in Christ, we are imputed with His righteousness. This is a free gift, a declaration of being 'right' in God's eyes, not based on our works, but on His grace. This understanding brings immense freedom and joy. It releases us from the burden of striving for perfection under the law and allows us to embrace a relationship with God built on love, grace, and unwavering faith in Jesus Christ. We are called to live a life guided by the principles of the law, but empowered by the Spirit, and motivated by love for God and others, not by fear of punishment.

para_meditar.texto: Wherefore the law was our schoolmaster to bring us unto Christ, that we might be justified by faith.
Think not that I am come to destroy the law, or the prophets: I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.
And be found in him, not having mine own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through the faith of Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith:

2026-04-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the gift of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank You that He is the end of the law for righteousness for all who believe. Help us to understand the depth of Your grace and the freedom that comes from being justified by faith. May we live each day with a heart filled with gratitude and a desire to follow Your will. Grant us wisdom to discern Your truth and strength to walk in Your ways. May we always remember that it is through Christ alone that we have access to You. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, guiding our thoughts, words, and actions. We commit our lives to You, trusting in Your love and provision. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-22.versiculo: Matthew 25:31-36 KJV: "When the Son of man shall come in his glory, and all the holy angels with him, then shall he sit upon the throne of his glory: And before him shall be gathered all nations: and he shall separate them one from another, as a shepherd divideth his sheep from the goats: And he shall set the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on the left. Then shall the King say unto them on his right hand, Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world: For I was an hungred, and ye gave me meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink: I was a stranger, and ye took me in: Naked, and ye clothed me: I was sick, and ye visited me: I was in prison, and ye came unto me."
2026-04-22.reflexion: Matthew 25:31-36 paints a vivid picture of the final judgment, where the King separates the sheep from the goats based on their actions towards the least of these. This passage isn't just about a future event; it's a call to action for the present. It challenges us to examine our lives and how we treat those around us. The King identifies himself with the hungry, the thirsty, the stranger, the naked, the sick, and the imprisoned. This reveals the profound connection between our faith and our deeds. True faith, as demonstrated by the sheep, manifests itself in acts of compassion and service. It's not enough to simply believe; we are called to actively love and care for others. This passage underscores the importance of practical Christianity, where faith is expressed through tangible actions. It reminds us that our eternity is not determined by what we say, but by how we live, and how we treat those in need. It urges us to seek opportunities to serve, to give, and to show mercy to those around us, as a reflection of the love we have received from Christ.

para_meditar.texto: He that hath pity upon the poor lendeth unto the Lord; and that which he hath given will he pay him again.

What doth it profit, my brethren, though a man say he hath faith, and have not works? can faith save him? If a brother or sister be naked, and destitute of daily food, And one of you say unto them, Depart in peace, be ye warmed and filled; notwithstanding ye give them not those things which are needful to the body; what doth it profit? Even so faith, if it hath not works, is dead, being alone.

But whoso hath this world's good, and seeth his brother have need, and shutteth up his bowels of compassion from him, how dwelleth the love of God in him? My little children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue; but in deed and in truth.

2026-04-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the clear instruction given in Matthew 25. Help us to recognize Christ in the faces of those who are suffering, those who are in need. Grant us the compassion and the resources to actively serve and care for the hungry, the thirsty, the stranger, the naked, the sick, and the imprisoned. Open our eyes to see the opportunities to show kindness and mercy in our daily lives. Give us the strength to act on our faith, to make a tangible difference in the world around us. May our actions reflect the love of Christ and the hope of the gospel. Guide us to be faithful stewards of all that you have given us, so that we may inherit the kingdom prepared for us. We pray for the grace to live a life that honors you in all we do, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-23.versiculo: Luke 15:7 KJV: "I say unto you, that likewise joy shall be in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over ninety and nine just persons, which need no repentance."
2026-04-23.reflexion: Today's passage from Luke 15:7 speaks to the immeasurable joy in heaven over one sinner who repents. This verse, part of a larger narrative about lost things being found, reveals the heart of God. He doesn't rejoice in the righteousness of those who believe they need no repentance, but in the turning of a single soul back to Him. The parable underscores the value God places on each individual. The ninety-nine righteous represent those who, in their own eyes, are already within the fold. Yet, the focus isn't on them; it's on the one lost sheep, the one lost coin, the prodigal son. This is because every soul is precious in God's sight. It challenges us to look beyond our own perceived righteousness and to embrace the lost with the same compassion and joy that God does. We are called to be agents of His love, extending grace and mercy, celebrating every moment of repentance and restoration. This verse is a call to action, urging us to seek out the lost, to rejoice in their return, and to remember that the kingdom of heaven is not just for the righteous, but for those who recognize their need for a Savior.

para_meditar.texto: Let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts: and let him return unto the Lord, and he will have mercy upon him; and to our God, for he will abundantly pardon.
Have I any pleasure at all that the wicked should die? saith the Lord God: and not that he should return from his ways, and live?
The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance.

2026-04-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are humbled by the profound love and joy you express over every soul that turns to You. Help us to see others through Your eyes, with compassion and understanding. Open our hearts to the lost, and give us the courage to share the Gospel with those who need to hear it. Grant us the wisdom to celebrate every step towards repentance and the strength to support those who are struggling. May we rejoice with the angels in heaven when a sinner turns to You. Help us to be instruments of Your grace and mercy, reflecting Your love in all that we do. Guide us in our daily walk, that we may be a source of encouragement and hope to those around us. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-04-24.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 8:9 KJV: "For ye know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that, though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor, that ye through his poverty might be rich."
2026-04-24.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Corinthians 8:9, unveils the profound grace of our Lord Jesus Christ. It speaks of a voluntary act of unimaginable selflessness. Jesus, who possessed all the riches of heaven, chose to become poor for our sake. He embraced poverty, not for His own gain, but that we, through His sacrifice, might inherit eternal riches. This isn't merely about financial prosperity; it speaks to a spiritual wealth – the abundant life found in Christ. It's a life of forgiveness, redemption, and eternal hope. Jesus's poverty demonstrates the depth of His love and the extent to which He was willing to go to bridge the gap between humanity and God. His act of emptying Himself serves as a powerful reminder of the humility and generosity that should characterize our own lives. We are called to emulate His example, to be generous with what we have, and to prioritize the spiritual well-being of others. This verse challenges us to examine our hearts and to consider how we are using the resources, both material and spiritual, that God has entrusted to us. Are we living in a way that reflects the sacrificial love of Christ?

2026-04-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are humbled by the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank you for His willingness to become poor, that we might be made rich in every way. Grant us a heart of compassion, that we may be moved to give to those in need, both materially and spiritually. Guide us to seek treasures in heaven, rather than earthly possessions. Open our eyes to see opportunities to serve others and to share the good news of salvation. Strengthen us to be faithful stewards of all that You have given us. 2026-04-25.versiculo: 1 Peter 2:9-10 KJV: "But ye are a chosen generation, a royal priesthood, an holy nation, a peculiar people; that ye should shew forth the praises of him who hath called you out of darkness into his marvellous light: Which in time past were not a people, but are now the people of God: which had not obtained mercy, but now have obtained mercy."
2026-04-25.reflexion: Today's passage, 1 Peter 2:9-10, is a powerful declaration of identity for every believer. We are not just ordinary individuals; we are a chosen generation, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a peculiar people. This is not a description of our inherent worth, but a testament to God's grace and election. He has called us out of the darkness of sin and into His marvelous light. Before Christ, we were not His people, but now, through His sacrifice, we are. We were once without mercy, but now we have obtained it. This understanding should transform our lives. We are called to show forth the praises of Him who has called us. This means actively living out our faith, sharing the Gospel, and demonstrating the love of Christ to those around us. We are a peculiar people, set apart for God's purposes. This calling demands a commitment to holiness, a willingness to serve, and a desire to live a life worthy of the Gospel. Let us embrace our identity in Christ and live each day reflecting His glory.

2026-04-26.versiculo: Galatians 5:22-23 KJV: "But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, Meekness, temperance: against such there is no law."
2026-04-26.reflexion: Today's passage from Galatians offers a profound glimpse into the essence of a life guided by the Holy Spirit. The 'fruit of the Spirit' described in these verses is not a list of actions, but rather a manifestation of the transformed character that the Spirit produces within us. Love, the cornerstone, is not merely an emotion but an active choice to seek the good of others. Joy, a deep-seated contentment, transcends circumstances, finding its source in the presence of God. Peace, a tranquility that surpasses understanding, guards our hearts and minds. Longsuffering, or patience, is the ability to endure hardship and delay without losing hope. Gentleness, or kindness, reflects a heart softened by grace, while goodness reflects a life characterized by virtue. Faith, the unwavering trust in God, is the foundation upon which we build our lives. Meekness, a humble spirit, recognizes our dependence on God, and temperance, or self-control, is the ability to master our desires and passions. These qualities are not attainable through our own efforts, but are a direct result of our connection with the Holy Spirit. To cultivate these fruits, we must surrender to the Spirit's leading, allowing Him to shape us into the image of Christ. It is a daily process of yielding, praying, and trusting, knowing that the Spirit's work in us will always produce the character of Christ.

2026-04-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the beautiful and transformative power of the Holy Spirit. 2026-04-27.versiculo: Philippians 3:7-8 KJV: "But what things were gain to me, those I counted loss for Christ. Yea doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ."
2026-04-27.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in Philippians 3:7-8, presents a radical perspective on the value of earthly achievements and possessions. He reveals that what he once considered gains—his pedigree, religious standing, and legalistic righteousness—he now regards as loss for the sake of Christ. This transformation stems from the surpassing value of knowing Christ Jesus his Lord. Paul understood that true riches lie not in worldly accolades but in the 'excellency of the knowledge' of Christ. He willingly relinquished everything to gain this knowledge and to win Christ. The word 'dung' is a strong term, signifying utter worthlessness, emphasizing the complete reevaluation of his priorities. Paul's example challenges us to examine our own values. Are we clinging to things that hinder our pursuit of Christ? Do we prioritize temporal achievements over spiritual growth? This passage encourages us to make a conscious decision to count all things as loss, so that we may truly gain Christ and all that comes with Him, including eternal life. It’s a call to radical discipleship, where our greatest treasure is the knowledge of our Lord and Savior.

2026-04-28.versiculo: Colossians 3:23 KJV: "And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as to the Lord, and not unto men;"
2026-04-28.reflexion:
Today's verse, Colossians 3:23, is a powerful call to action, a reminder that our work should be a form of worship. Paul urges us to perform all our tasks 'heartily,' with genuine enthusiasm and devotion, 'as to the Lord, and not unto men.' This isn't just about doing a good job to impress our bosses or peers. It's about recognizing that every action, no matter how mundane, is an opportunity to serve God. 

Consider the implications. Whether we are cleaning, working in an office, or raising children, we are called to do it with excellence, not for human approval, but for the glory of God. This perspective transforms the ordinary into the sacred. It infuses our daily lives with purpose and meaning. When we work with this mindset, we are not just employees, students, or parents; we are ambassadors of Christ, reflecting His character in all that we do. This verse challenges us to examine our motivations. Are we driven by a desire for recognition or by a desire to please God? Let's strive to live out Colossians 3:23, pouring our hearts into every task, seeing each action as a way to honor and serve our Lord.

para_meditar.texto: Commit thy works unto the LORD, and thy thoughts shall be established.

2026-04-29.versiculo: Acts 10:43 KJV: "To him give all the prophets witness, that through his name whosoever believeth in him shall receive remission of sins."
2026-04-29.reflexion: Today's verse, Acts 10:43, is a powerful summary of the Gospel. It declares that all the prophets bore witness to Jesus, and that through His name, everyone who believes in Him will receive forgiveness of sins. This verse is a cornerstone of the Christian faith, highlighting the central role of Jesus Christ in salvation. The prophets of old, from Moses to the later writers, all pointed towards the coming Messiah. Their prophecies, filled with anticipation, found their fulfillment in Jesus. They foretold His life, death, and resurrection. The key phrase, 'whosoever believeth in him', underscores the universality of God's grace. It's not limited by ethnicity, social status, or any other human construct. It's available to all who place their faith in Jesus. 'Shall receive remission of sins' is the glorious promise. Remission means the complete removal of sin, both its guilt and its penalty. This is not something we can earn; it is a free gift offered through Jesus' sacrifice. It's a transformative power, changing our relationship with God and our lives. It’s a call to trust, to believe, and to receive the abundant grace offered through Jesus. This verse encourages us to share this good news with others, so they too can experience the life-changing forgiveness and freedom found in Christ.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.

2026-04-30.versiculo: Romans 3:23 KJV: "For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God."
2026-04-30.reflexion: Romans 3:23 presents a stark and universal truth: every single human being has fallen short of God’s glory. This verse is a cornerstone of the Gospel, laying the foundation for the good news of salvation. The phrase "all have sinned" is inclusive; it leaves no one exempt. From the moment we are born, we are born into a fallen world, inheriting a sinful nature. This inherent sinfulness manifests in various ways – through our thoughts, words, and deeds – leading us to stray from God’s perfect standard. The consequence of this sin is that we “come short of the glory of God.” This means we are separated from God, unable to fully reflect His character, and destined for eternal separation. However, understanding this truth is crucial because it highlights our desperate need for a Savior. It underscores the magnitude of God’s grace and mercy, which is offered freely to all who believe. This verse is not meant to condemn, but to reveal our shared brokenness and direct us towards the only solution: the redemptive work of Jesus Christ. It's a call to humility, acknowledging our need for forgiveness and embracing the path to reconciliation with God.

Open our hearts to receive Your love and forgiveness, and help us to reflect Your glory in all that we do. Guide us to live in a way that brings glory to Your name. We humbly ask for Your guidance, Your wisdom, and Your unwavering love, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-01.versiculo: Hebrews 7:25 KJV: "Wherefore he is able also to save them to the uttermost that come unto God by him, seeing he ever liveth to make intercession for them."
2026-05-01.reflexion: Today's verse, Hebrews 7:25, offers a profound assurance of salvation and the unending advocacy of Christ. It declares that Jesus is able to save completely those who come to God through Him. This 'uttermost' salvation encompasses not just initial forgiveness but also the ongoing preservation and sanctification of believers. The passage highlights the eternal nature of Christ's priesthood and His continuous intercession on our behalf. He 'ever liveth to make intercession for them,' a powerful testament to His unwavering commitment to our spiritual well-being. This verse emphasizes that our salvation is not a one-time event but a continuous process, secured by the eternal ministry of Jesus. His constant intercession ensures that we are kept and sustained, shielded from the ultimate consequences of sin. It offers a comforting perspective, reminding us that we have an advocate, a mediator who pleads our case before the Father. This is a promise of hope, a guarantee of our security in Christ, and a constant reminder of God's boundless grace and mercy. We are called to trust in Him, to approach God through Him, and to find refuge in His eternal intercession.

2026-05-02.versiculo: John 4:23-24 KJV: "But the hour cometh, and now is, when the true worshippers shall worship the Father in spirit and in truth: for the Father seeketh such to worship him. God is a Spirit: and they that worship him must worship him in spirit and in truth."
2026-05-02.reflexion: Today's passage from John offers profound insight into the nature of true worship. Jesus declares that the time is now for worship that transcends physical location and ritual. He emphasizes that the Father seeks those who worship Him in spirit and in truth. This is not merely about following external practices, but about a deep, internal connection with God. To worship in spirit means to engage with God from the depths of our being, our hearts and minds fully focused on Him. It requires a willingness to be led by the Holy Spirit, to allow Him to guide our thoughts, actions, and desires. To worship in truth means to worship in accordance with God's revealed will, as found in His Word. It means acknowledging His character, His sovereignty, and His grace. It is about honesty and authenticity, casting aside hypocrisy and pretense. This passage challenges us to examine our own worship. Are we merely going through the motions, or are we truly connecting with God on a spiritual level? Are we seeking to know Him more intimately, to understand His truth, and to live in obedience to His Word? Let us strive to become true worshippers, offering to God the devotion of our spirit and the integrity of our truth.

2026-05-03.versiculo: Revelation 21:1 KJV: "And I saw a new heaven and a new earth: for the first heaven and the first earth were passed away; and there was no more sea."
2026-05-03.reflexion: Today's verse, Revelation 21:1, unveils a breathtaking vision of the future. John, the apostle, sees a new heaven and a new earth, a complete renewal. The old order, marked by sin and suffering, is gone. The passing away of the first heaven and earth signifies a cosmic reset, a cleansing of all that is marred by the fall. The absence of the sea is symbolic; in ancient times, the sea represented chaos and separation. Its disappearance suggests a realm of perfect peace and unity, where all things are made new. This vision is not just a promise of a future state; it's a call to live in the present with the hope of that future. We are called to anticipate this new reality, to align our lives with the values of the Kingdom of God, and to live with the anticipation of a world where righteousness dwells. This verse gives us a glimpse of our eternal home, a place free from the pain and sorrow that plague our current existence, a place where God dwells with His people and wipes away every tear.

2026-05-04.versiculo: Mark 9:23 KJV: "Jesus said unto him, If thou canst believe, all things are possible to him that believeth."
2026-05-04.reflexion: Today's verse, Mark 9:23, is a powerful declaration of the transformative power of faith. It speaks directly to the core of our spiritual journey, reminding us that believing is the key to unlocking the seemingly impossible. The context of this verse is particularly poignant. A father, desperate for his demon-possessed son's healing, approaches Jesus. His faith is wavering, and he expresses his doubt, stating, "If thou canst do any thing, have compassion on us, and help us." Jesus, in response, doesn't dismiss the father's plea but focuses on the fundamental issue: his faith. He reframes the situation, emphasizing that the ability to heal isn't the question; the true question is whether the father believes. The verse then offers a profound truth: "If thou canst believe, all things are possible to him that believeth." This isn't just a promise; it’s a principle. It suggests that faith isn’t merely a passive acceptance but an active force, a conviction that moves mountains, heals the sick, and opens doors. It challenges us to examine our own faith, to ask ourselves if we truly believe in the power of God to work in our lives, regardless of the circumstances. The call to believe is a call to trust, to surrender our doubts, and to embrace the limitless possibilities that God offers to those who put their faith in Him.

2026-05-05.versiculo: Philippians 4:19 KJV: "But my God shall supply all your need according to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus."
2026-05-05.reflexion: Philippians 4:19 is a powerful declaration of God's unwavering provision. It's not just a promise of meeting our immediate needs, but a pledge of supplying all our needs – a comprehensive provision that encompasses every aspect of our lives. The key lies in the phrase, 'according to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus.' This highlights the boundless nature of God's resources, which are not limited by earthly constraints. His glory, His character, and His infinite capacity are the source of this provision. We are reminded that this provision flows to us through Christ Jesus, our mediator and the one who makes us heirs to God's grace. This verse encourages us to trust in God's ability to provide, even when circumstances seem challenging. It calls us to shift our focus from our anxieties and worries to the abundant riches of God's grace, knowing that He will always be faithful to His promises. It is a reminder that our needs are met not just by God's power, but by His character, His love, and His unending grace, offered freely to us through Christ Jesus.

2026-05-06.versiculo: James 2:8 KJV: "If ye fulfil the royal law according to the scripture, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself, ye do well:"
2026-05-06.reflexion: Today's verse, James 2:8, calls us to the essence of the Christian life: love. It highlights the 'royal law' – the command to love our neighbor as ourselves. This isn't just a suggestion; it's a mandate that, when fulfilled, brings us into alignment with God's will. The phrase 'thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself' is not merely about being kind; it's about empathy, compassion, and actively seeking the well-being of others. It's about seeing the image of God in every person, regardless of their background, status, or actions. When we truly love our neighbor, we are fulfilling the law in its entirety. This requires us to examine our hearts, to identify and overcome prejudices, and to extend grace and forgiveness. It means being present in their lives, offering support, and sharing the love of Christ. This call to love is not always easy, but it is the foundation upon which our faith is built. It is through our love for others that the world will see the transformative power of the gospel. Let us strive to live out this royal law daily, and to reflect the love of Christ in all that we do. Let us remember that our actions speak louder than words, and that our love for others is a testament to our love for God.

Grant us the grace to see others through Your eyes, to recognize their needs, and to offer them the same compassion and kindness that You have shown us. Give us the strength to overcome our prejudices and to extend grace and forgiveness to those around us. May our actions reflect Your love in all that we do, and may we be a beacon of Your light in the world. Guide us in fulfilling the royal law, not just in word, but in deed. Help us to love as Jesus loved, sacrificially and unconditionally. We pray for the strength to live out this commandment daily, transforming our relationships and our communities. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-07.versiculo: Mark 16:15 KJV: "And he said unto them, Go ye into all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature."
2026-05-07.reflexion: Today’s verse, Mark 16:15, is a powerful commission from our Lord Jesus Christ. He commands us, His followers, to go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature. This is not a suggestion; it's a mandate, a call to action. The scope of this command is vast: 'all the world' encompasses every nation, every tribe, every tongue. 'Every creature' means all people, regardless of their background, status, or beliefs. This verse challenges us to step outside our comfort zones and share the good news of salvation through Jesus Christ. It reminds us that the gospel is not just for us; it's for everyone. We are called to be witnesses, to proclaim the truth of the gospel through our words and actions. This requires boldness, faith, and a willingness to love and serve others. It's a call to intentional evangelism, to seek out opportunities to share the hope we have in Christ. It's also a reminder of the urgency of the gospel. Time is precious, and the world desperately needs to hear the message of salvation. Let us embrace this commission with a renewed passion, recognizing that we are ambassadors for Christ, tasked with sharing the greatest news the world has ever known.

para_meditar.texto: Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost:

But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, and in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth.

2026-05-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the precious gift of the gospel and for the command to share it with the world. Help us to be faithful witnesses, to be bold in our proclamation, and to love others as you love us. Give us opportunities to share the good news with those around us, both near and far. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, empowering us to speak the truth in love and to live out the message of salvation in our daily lives. Grant us a heart of compassion for the lost and a desire to see all people come to know you. Strengthen our faith and help us to overcome any fear or hesitation that may hold us back. May your name be glorified through our obedience to your commission. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-08.versiculo: 2 Thessalonians 3:10 KJV: "For even when we were with you, this we commanded you, that if any would not work, neither should he eat."
2026-05-08.reflexion: Today's verse from 2 Thessalonians 3:10 speaks a clear and direct message about the importance of diligence and work. The Apostle Paul, in his instruction to the Thessalonians, emphasizes that idleness is unacceptable within the Christian community. This wasn't just a suggestion; it was a command, a directive based on the principle of mutual responsibility and the dignity of labor. Paul's words reflect the inherent value God places on work, not just as a means to an end, but as an integral part of our lives. He recognized the potential for idleness to lead to disorder and dependence, hindering both individual and communal growth. By stating that those who refuse to work should not eat, Paul underscores the practical implications of this principle. It’s a call to self-sufficiency and responsible living, reminding us that our actions have consequences, both for ourselves and for those around us. This verse challenges us to examine our own attitudes towards work and productivity. Are we diligent in our efforts, contributing to the well-being of ourselves and others? Or are we tempted by laziness and dependence? Embracing the spirit of this verse means finding purpose in our daily tasks, whether they are great or small, and recognizing that through our labor, we can honor God and serve our fellow man.

para_meditar.texto: He becometh poor that dealeth with a slack hand: but the hand of the diligent maketh rich.
Let him that stole steal no more: but rather let him labour, working with his hands the thing which is good, that he may have to give to him that needeth.

2026-05-08.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the gift of work and for the opportunities you give us to serve you through our labor. We confess that we often struggle with laziness and a lack of diligence. Forgive us for the times we have been idle and for the times we have not given our best effort. Help us to embrace the spirit of hard work and to find purpose in our daily tasks. Grant us the strength to be productive and to contribute to the well-being of those around us. May our work be a reflection of your glory, and may we always strive to be faithful stewards of the gifts and talents you have given us. Guide us to use our time wisely and to seek opportunities to serve others through our actions. Help us to remember that our work is not just about earning a living, but about honoring you in all that we do. We pray all this in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-09.versiculo: Hebrews 13:5 KJV: "Let your conversation be without covetousness; and be content with such things as ye have: for he hath said, I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee."
2026-05-09.reflexion: Today's verse, Hebrews 13:5, is a powerful reminder of God's unwavering presence and provision in our lives. It calls us to live a life free from the grasping grip of covetousness, the insatiable desire for more, and encourages us to be content with what we have. This contentment is not born of apathy or laziness, but rather of a deep trust in God's faithfulness. The promise, "I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee," is the bedrock of our security. It is a promise that transcends circumstances, a promise that holds true in times of abundance and in times of scarcity. This verse challenges us to examine our hearts. Are we constantly striving for more, or are we grateful for what God has already given? Are we chasing after material possessions, or are we seeking a deeper relationship with Him? The key is to cultivate a heart of gratitude and to find our satisfaction in God's love and provision. When we truly believe that God is with us, always, the things of this world lose their power to captivate us. We can then live with a peaceful contentment, knowing that we are complete in Him and that He will always provide for our needs.

para_meditar.texto: Not that I speak in respect of want: for I have learned, in whatsoever state I am, therewith to be content.

2026-05-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the promise of your constant presence in my life. I confess that I often struggle with covetousness, always desiring more than I have. Remind me daily that you will never leave me nor forsake me. Grant me the wisdom to discern between my needs and my desires. Help me to focus on the eternal things and to seek your kingdom above all else. Strengthen my faith and fill me with your peace. Help me to trust in your guidance and provision. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-10.versiculo: Jude 1:24-25 KJV: "Now unto him that is able to keep you from falling, and to present you faultless before the presence of his glory with exceeding joy, To the only wise God our Saviour, be glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and ever. Amen."
2026-05-10.reflexion: Jude 1:24-25 offers a breathtaking glimpse into the security and glory that awaits believers. This passage is not merely a promise; it is a declaration of God's unwavering power and love. The phrase, "Now unto him that is able to keep you from falling," assures us that our salvation is secure in His hands. We are not left to our own devices, struggling to maintain our faith. Rather, God actively protects and preserves us. The promise of being presented "faultless before the presence of his glory with exceeding joy" is a source of immense comfort and hope. It reminds us that the blemishes of sin, the struggles of this earthly life, will not prevent us from experiencing the fullness of God's presence. This will be a moment of unparalleled joy, a moment of complete restoration and redemption.  The doxology that follows, praising God as "the only wise God our Saviour," reinforces the foundation of our faith.  We are called to give Him all the glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and forever. This passage should fill us with gratitude and inspire us to live lives that reflect His glory, trusting in His ability to keep us and looking forward with eager anticipation to the day we stand before Him, faultless and filled with joy.

2026-05-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are humbled by the assurance of Your steadfast love and protection. Grant us the grace to trust in Your power, to live lives that honor You, and to eagerly anticipate the joy of that glorious day. Help us to see the world through your eyes, and to be a light to those around us. May we reflect your glory in all that we do, giving You all the praise and honor. We praise You for Your wisdom, Your power, and Your saving grace. We commit ourselves to You, trusting in Your loving care and guidance, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-11.versiculo: Revelation 1:7 KJV: "Behold, he cometh with clouds; and every eye shall see him, and they also which pierced him: and all kindreds of the earth shall wail because of him. Even so, Amen."
2026-05-11.reflexion: The opening verses of Revelation paint a dramatic picture of the return of Christ. Revelation 1:7 is a powerful declaration of His second coming, a moment of unparalleled revelation and judgment. The verse emphasizes the visibility of Christ's return: 'every eye shall see him'. This is not a secret or hidden event; it is a public display of divine power and glory. The inclusion of 'they also which pierced him' highlights the personal and universal nature of this event. Those who rejected and crucified Him will witness His return, facing the consequences of their actions. The phrase 'all kindreds of the earth shall wail' underscores the profound impact of this event. It speaks to the sorrow, remorse, and fear that will grip those who have not embraced Christ's offer of salvation. This verse serves as a stark reminder of the consequences of rejecting the Gospel and the importance of living a life of faith and repentance. It also reminds us of the certainty of Christ's return, urging us to be prepared, watching and waiting for His glorious appearing. The concluding phrase, 'Even so, Amen,' is a heartfelt affirmation of faith and anticipation, a prayer of agreement and longing for the fulfillment of God's promises.

Strengthen our faith, deepen our love for You, and increase our hope in the fulfillment of Your promises. Give us wisdom to understand the times and to seek Your will in all things. We ask for Your guidance in discerning the signs of the times and the courage to stand firm in our faith. May we be found faithful when Christ returns, rejoicing in His presence for all eternity. We commit our lives into Your hands, trusting in Your unwavering love and faithfulness, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-12.versiculo: Galatians 6:2 KJV: "Bear ye one another's burdens, and so fulfil the law of Christ."
2026-05-12.reflexion: Today's verse, Galatians 6:2, calls us to a profound act of love and service: bearing one another's burdens. This isn't merely a suggestion; it's a fulfillment of the law of Christ. The 'burdens' can be physical, emotional, spiritual, or any weight that another person carries. It's about empathy, compassion, and a willingness to step into the struggles of others and offer support. This passage challenges us to look beyond our own concerns and actively seek ways to alleviate the suffering of those around us. This includes listening, offering practical help, providing encouragement, and praying for those in need. The 'law of Christ' is the law of love, and by bearing one another's burdens, we are demonstrating that love in a tangible way. It is a call to active participation in the lives of others, understanding that we are all connected and share a common humanity. It’s a reminder that we are not meant to walk alone, but to support and encourage each other in our journey of faith, helping each other to carry the load, and living out the love of Christ in our daily lives.

Give us hearts that are willing to listen, hands that are ready to help, and words that offer comfort and hope. Remind us that we are all part of one body, and when one suffers, we all suffer. Guide us to fulfill the law of Christ by loving and serving one another. Help us to be instruments of your peace, bringing comfort and strength to those in need. Let your love shine through us, so that others may see your grace and mercy. 2026-05-13.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 9:24 KJV: "Know ye not that they which run in a race run all, but one receiveth the prize? So run, that ye may obtain."
2026-05-13.reflexion: The Apostle Paul, in 1 Corinthians 9:24, employs a powerful analogy of a race to challenge believers to strive for spiritual excellence. He reminds us that in a physical race, many run, but only one wins the prize. However, in the Christian life, the race is different; all who run with perseverance and faith can receive the ultimate prize: eternal life. This verse encourages us to run with purpose, discipline, and a focused determination. It speaks to the importance of striving, not just participating. It calls us to examine our spiritual lives, to identify the areas where we may be lagging, and to make a conscious effort to improve. We are called to run the race of faith with diligence, avoiding the distractions and temptations that hinder our progress. The 'prize' is not simply a reward at the end, but a continual journey of growth and transformation. It involves actively pursuing a deeper relationship with God, obedience to His word, and a life that reflects His character. This verse is a call to action, a reminder that our lives are not lived in vain; they are a race with eternal implications, and the prize is within our grasp.

Give us the focus to keep our eyes fixed on you, the prize, and the finish line. Help us to press forward with perseverance, fighting the good fight, finishing our course, and keeping the faith. Guide us to live lives that honor you, and to pursue a deeper relationship with you, day by day. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, so we may run with endurance the race that is set before us, striving for the ultimate reward of eternal life, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-14.versiculo: Revelation 21:4 KJV: "And God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes; and there shall be no more death, neither sorrow, nor crying, neither shall there be any more pain: for the former things are passed away."
2026-05-14.reflexion: Today's verse, Revelation 21:4, paints a breathtaking picture of the New Jerusalem, a city prepared for those who love God. It speaks of a time when suffering will be eradicated. No more tears, death, sorrow, crying, or pain. Imagine a world completely devoid of the heartache that plagues us in this fallen world. This verse is a promise, a glimpse into the eternal state, where God Himself will dwell with His people, and every tear will be wiped away. It’s a comfort for those who grieve, a promise of healing for the brokenhearted, and a beacon of hope for the weary. The 'former things' refer to the current reality of sin, suffering, and mortality. They 'passed away' because they are replaced by a new creation, a realm of perfect peace and joy. This is not just a future hope; it is a present reality in the life of every believer who has received Jesus Christ. We can find strength in the knowledge that our present sufferings are temporary, and the glory that awaits us is eternal and far outweighs them. Let this vision of a tearless eternity motivate us to live faithfully, to share the Gospel, and to long for the day when we will experience the fullness of God's presence.

Remind us daily that the sufferings of this world are temporary and that the glory that awaits us is eternal. Help us to share this hope with others, that they may also experience the peace and joy of knowing You. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-15.versiculo: Acts 9:3-6 KJV: "And as he journeyed, he came near Damascus: and suddenly there shined round about him a light from heaven: And he fell to the earth, and heard a voice saying unto him, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? And he said, Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest: it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks. And he trembling and astonished said, Lord, what wilt thou have me to do? And the Lord said unto him, Arise, and go into the city, and it shall be told thee what thou must do."
2026-05-15.reflexion: The encounter on the road to Damascus is a pivotal moment in the life of Saul, later known as Paul. This passage, Acts 9:3-6, describes a dramatic transformation. Saul, a zealous persecutor of Christians, is struck down by a heavenly light and hears the voice of Jesus. This wasn't a gentle nudge; it was a blinding revelation that shattered Saul's world. The immediate impact is profound. He is humbled, falling to the ground, and his initial response is one of genuine inquiry, asking, 'Who art thou, Lord?' This reveals a willingness to acknowledge a higher power, a turning point from his previous arrogance. Jesus's response is equally striking, identifying Himself with the very people Saul was persecuting. This revelation underscores the deep connection between Christ and His followers. The phrase 'it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks' highlights the futility of fighting against God's will. Saul's response, 'Lord, what wilt thou have me to do?' is the ultimate expression of surrender and obedience. This marks the beginning of his transformation, demonstrating the power of God to change even the most hardened hearts. It's a reminder that God's grace is available to all, regardless of their past.

Give me the strength to obey your commands, to embrace the new life you offer, and to live a life pleasing to you. Remove the blinders that prevent me from seeing your glory and understanding your purpose for my life. Guide my steps, and lead me on the path of righteousness, so that I may be a vessel of your love and a testament to your power. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-16.versiculo: Mark 6:31 KJV: "And he said unto them, Come ye yourselves apart into a desert place, and rest a while: for there were many coming and going, and they had no leisure so much as to eat."
2026-05-16.reflexion: Today's verse, Mark 6:31, offers a profound insight into the life and ministry of Jesus and the demands placed upon Him and His disciples. It reveals a crucial need for rest and respite, a principle often overlooked in our own busy lives. Jesus, despite His immense power and divine calling, recognized the necessity of withdrawing to a quiet place. The text tells us that they had 'no leisure so much as to eat,' highlighting the relentless pace of their ministry. This exhaustion wasn't just physical; it was also emotional and spiritual. The constant demands of the crowds, the healings, the teachings, and the pressure to perform must have taken their toll. Jesus, in His wisdom, understood this and provided a remedy: 'Come ye yourselves apart...and rest a while.' This wasn't a sign of weakness but a demonstration of strength, a recognition that rest is essential for sustained effectiveness. The call to 'come ye yourselves apart' is a personal invitation to each of us. We, too, are often overwhelmed by the demands of life, whether in our work, families, or ministries. We are bombarded by information and expectations. Jesus' example reminds us that we must prioritize our physical, mental, and spiritual well-being. We must seek times of solitude and rest, not just to recharge our batteries, but to reconnect with God and find renewal for the journey ahead. It's a call to listen to our bodies and souls, and to make space for God's presence in our lives. Take time today to rest, reflect, and reconnect with the Lord.

para_meditar.texto: Be still, and know that I am God: I will be exalted among the heathen, I will be exalted in the earth.

Grant me the wisdom to discern the demands that are truly important and the courage to say no to those that drain my energy. Renew my strength and fill me with your peace. Teach me to trust in Your provision and to find my rest in You. Help me to remember that I am not alone, and that You are always with me. Thank you for your love and grace, and for the gift of rest. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-17.versiculo: Revelation 22:20 KJV: "He which testifieth these things saith, Surely I come quickly. Amen. Even so, come, Lord Jesus."
2026-05-17.reflexion: The final verses of Revelation offer a powerful and poignant conclusion to the biblical narrative. Revelation 22:20 encapsulates the fervent longing for Christ's return, a sentiment that should resonate deeply within every believer. The declaration, "Surely I come quickly," is a promise of hope and assurance. It reminds us that the Lord's return is imminent, a truth that should shape our daily lives. The response, "Amen. Even so, come, Lord Jesus," is not merely a passive acceptance but an active invitation. It is a prayer born from a heart yearning for the culmination of God's redemptive plan, the restoration of all things. This verse challenges us to cultivate an active expectancy, to live in the light of His promise, and to prepare ourselves for His arrival. The 'Amen' is an affirmation of faith, a seal upon the truth of God's Word. It is a call to action, urging us to live lives of holiness, witness, and prayer. We are reminded that our hope is not in earthly things, but in the promise of His coming. Let us, therefore, live with a heart that cries out, "Come, Lord Jesus!"

2026-05-18.versiculo: Acts 4:12 KJV: "Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved."
2026-05-18.reflexion: The apostle Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, boldly proclaimed the truth before the Sanhedrin: salvation is found in no other name but Jesus Christ. This powerful declaration reverberates through the ages, challenging the pluralistic notions of salvation prevalent in our world. Acts 4:12 is a cornerstone of Christian faith, a testament to the unique and exclusive nature of Christ's redemptive work. It asserts that Jesus is the only way to reconciliation with God. This verse underscores the urgency of sharing the Gospel, for it is through Christ alone that humanity can escape the consequences of sin and experience eternal life. The exclusivity of salvation in Christ does not negate God's love for all people; rather, it highlights the profound sacrifice He made in sending His Son. This truth compels us to examine our own hearts and ensure that our trust is solely placed in Jesus. Are we proclaiming this truth with boldness and conviction, or are we hesitant to share the good news? Let us embrace the exclusivity of Christ, not as a barrier to others, but as a pathway to true and lasting freedom for all who believe.

We pray for those who are searching for truth, that they may find it in Jesus. We dedicate our lives to serving You and spreading Your word. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-05-19.versiculo: 1 Peter 3:8-9 KJV: "Finally, be ye all of one mind, having compassion one of another, love as brethren, be pitiful, be courteous: Not rendering evil for evil, or railing for railing: but contrariwise blessing; knowing that ye are thereunto called, that ye should inherit a blessing."
2026-05-19.reflexion: Today's passage from 1 Peter 3:8-9 calls us to a higher standard of conduct, one rooted in unity, compassion, and love. Peter implores us to be of 'one mind,' reflecting the unity found in Christ. This unity is not just about agreement on doctrines, but a shared sense of empathy and understanding. We are to have 'compassion one of another,' feeling the pain and burdens of those around us. Love, as brethren, should be the hallmark of our interactions, a love that transcends superficiality and embraces genuine care. Furthermore, we are called to be 'pitiful,' showing mercy and kindness, and 'courteous,' demonstrating respect and consideration in all our dealings. The most challenging aspect of this passage is the instruction not to 'render evil for evil, or railing for railing.' This goes against our natural inclination to retaliate when wronged. Instead, Peter encourages us to 'bless,' to offer words of grace and kindness even in the face of adversity. This radical response stems from our calling to 'inherit a blessing.' By choosing to love and bless others, we align ourselves with God’s will and open ourselves to His blessings. This is not an easy path, but it is the path of Christ, and it is the path to true peace and joy.

para_meditar.texto: Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good.
