Grant me the strength to resist temptation and to embrace the righteousness and holiness that is mine in Christ Jesus. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may walk in the newness of life. Help me to live in accordance with Your will, and to reflect Your character in all that I do. Guide me in this journey of transformation, and help me to grow more like Jesus every day. I pray for the grace to walk in truth and love, to be a light in the world. Help me to die to self and live for You. I commit my life to You, asking for Your guidance and strength, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-11.versiculo: Matthew 19:26 KJV: "But Jesus beheld them, and said unto them, With men this is impossible; but with God all things are possible."
2026-06-11.reflexion:
Today's verse, Matthew 19:26, offers a powerful message of hope and unwavering faith. Jesus, addressing the disciples' astonishment at the difficulty of salvation, declares that while human limitations restrict us, nothing is impossible with God. This truth strikes at the heart of our doubts and anxieties. We often face situations that seem insurmountable – broken relationships, health challenges, financial struggles, or spiritual battles. We look at these circumstances and, like the disciples, feel overwhelmed by the sheer impossibility of overcoming them. 

However, Jesus' words remind us of the infinite power and boundless grace of God. He doesn't dismiss our struggles; He acknowledges the reality of our limitations. But He immediately elevates our perspective, shifting our focus from our own perceived inadequacies to the limitless possibilities that exist within God's realm. This verse is not just a statement of fact; it is an invitation to trust. It's a call to release our control, surrender our fears, and embrace the reality that God's power transcends all human understanding. It encourages us to approach every challenge with the unwavering belief that, through Him, all things are possible. This is not a promise of an easy journey, but a guarantee of divine support and the ultimate triumph of faith.

para_meditar.texto: I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
And Jesus looking upon them saith, With men it is impossible, but not with God: for with God all things are possible.
Behold, I am the Lord, the God of all flesh: is there any thing too hard for me?

2026-06-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today recognizing our limitations and the challenges that weigh heavily upon us. We acknowledge that many things seem impossible in our own strength. Yet, we are reminded of Your infinite power and boundless grace, as declared in Matthew 19:26. We place our trust in You, knowing that with You, all things are possible. Help us to release our fears and surrender our control, embracing the reality of Your divine support. Grant us the faith to believe that, through You, we can overcome any obstacle. Strengthen our hearts and minds, filling us with the hope and assurance that we are never alone. Guide us in every decision and action, that we may live in accordance with Your will. Thank you for your unwavering love and your promise to always be with us, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-12.versiculo: John 16:33 KJV: "These things I have spoken unto you, that in me ye might have peace. In the world ye shall have tribulation: but be of good cheer; I have overcome the world."
2026-06-12.reflexion: John 16:33 is a profound declaration from Jesus, a comforting promise spoken amidst the impending trials and tribulations that His disciples, and by extension all believers, would face. He acknowledges the reality of suffering in the world, stating plainly that we *will* have tribulation. This is not a suggestion, but a certainty. Yet, within this stark truth, Jesus offers two powerful gifts: peace and encouragement. He assures us that we can find peace *in Him*. This peace is not the absence of trouble, but a deep, abiding tranquility that transcends our circumstances. It is a peace that the world cannot give, nor can it take away. Furthermore, Jesus commands us to "be of good cheer." This is not a mere platitude; it is a call to a confident hope, a joyful resilience rooted in the ultimate victory He has already achieved. "I have overcome the world" is the triumphant declaration that underpins everything. It means that sin, death, and the powers of darkness have been defeated. It means that we, who are in Christ, are on the winning side. We can face the storms of life with courage, knowing that the battle has already been won and that our ultimate destiny is secure in His love and grace.

para_meditar.texto: Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us.
I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
Casting all your care upon him; for he careth for you.

2026-06-12.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the promise of peace and the strength to endure in the midst of trials. Lord, the world can be a difficult place, and we face many challenges. Help us to remember that You have overcome the world. Grant us the peace that surpasses all understanding, a peace that comes from knowing You. Give us the courage to be of good cheer, knowing that we are victorious in You. Help us to cast all our cares upon You, trusting in Your love and protection. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may live with hope and joy, even when surrounded by suffering. Help us to walk in Your victory and to share Your peace with others. Guide us, strengthen us, and keep us steadfast in our faith. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-13.versiculo: Luke 11:28 KJV: "But he said, Yea rather, blessed are they that hear the word of God, and keep it."
2026-06-13.reflexion:
Today's verse, Luke 11:28, offers a profound perspective on true blessedness. While acknowledging the initial woman's praise of Jesus' mother, Christ pivots the focus to a deeper truth: the blessedness that comes from hearing and keeping the Word of God. This isn't merely about intellectual understanding; it is about an active engagement with scripture. To 'hear' implies attentive listening, allowing the Word to penetrate our hearts and minds. To 'keep' suggests a commitment to putting the teachings into practice, shaping our lives according to God's will. 

This verse challenges us to move beyond simply knowing the Bible to actively living it. It's a call to action, reminding us that true blessing isn't found in superficial admiration or fleeting moments of excitement, but in the consistent application of God's principles in our daily lives. It is in the quiet moments of obedience, the persistent efforts to live a life that honors God, that we truly experience His blessing. This verse encourages us to cultivate a lifestyle rooted in faith, obedience, and a deep love for God's Word, recognizing that this is where true and lasting blessedness resides.

para_meditar.texto: Wherewithal shall a young man cleanse his way? by taking heed thereto according to thy word.
But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.

And it shall come to pass, if thou shalt hearken diligently unto the voice of the Lord thy God, to observe and to do all his commandments which I command thee this day, that the Lord thy God will set thee on high above all nations of the earth:

2026-06-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the gift of your Word, a lamp unto our feet and a light unto our path. Help us, Lord, to not only hear your Word but to truly understand it, to cherish it, and to live by it. Grant us the wisdom and strength to keep your commandments, to be doers of your Word, and to walk in the path of righteousness. Open our hearts to receive your truth, and empower us to reflect your love and grace in all that we do. Guide us to live lives that are pleasing to you and bring glory to your name. We pray for a deeper understanding of your will for our lives and for the courage to obey. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, so that we may be faithful witnesses of your love and grace. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-14.versiculo: James 1:2-4 KJV: "My brethren, count it all joy when ye fall into divers temptations; Knowing this, that the trying of your faith worketh patience. But let patience have her perfect work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing."
2026-06-14.reflexion: Today's passage from James challenges us to embrace trials with joy. This isn't a call for a superficial happiness, but a deep-seated joy that stems from understanding God's purpose in our suffering. James reminds us that trials, or temptations as he calls them, are not random misfortunes, but opportunities for growth. He reveals a process: when we encounter trials, they test our faith. This testing doesn't destroy faith, but rather refines it, like gold purified by fire. The outcome of this testing is patience, a steadfastness that allows us to endure hardship without losing heart. The ultimate goal of this process is spiritual maturity. God allows us to experience difficulties so that we can become 'perfect and entire, wanting nothing.' This doesn't mean we will be without needs or desires, but that we will be complete in Christ, lacking nothing essential for our spiritual well-being. This passage calls us to view trials not as punishments, but as opportunities to deepen our faith and experience the fullness of God's grace.

para_meditar.texto: And not only that, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope.

In all this you greatly rejoice, though now for a little while you may have had to suffer grief in all kinds of trials. These have come so that the proven genuineness of your faith—of greater worth than gold, which perishes even though refined by fire—may result in praise, glory and honor when Jesus Christ is revealed.
No discipline seems pleasant at the time, but painful. Later on, however, it produces a harvest of righteousness and peace for those who have been trained by it.

2026-06-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the trials that come into my life. Help me to see them not as burdens, but as opportunities to grow closer to You. Grant me the joy to embrace these challenges, knowing that You are working in me to produce patience, character, and hope. Help me to trust in Your perfect plan, even when I don't understand the circumstances. Give me the strength to persevere, knowing that You are refining my faith and making me complete in You. Fill me with Your peace and guide me every step of the way. Help me to be mindful of the trials in the lives of others, and to offer encouragement and support. Grant me the wisdom to see Your hand at work in every situation. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-15.versiculo: 1 Thessalonians 1:9-10 KJV: "For they themselves shew of us what manner of entering in we had unto you, and how ye turned to God from idols to serve the living and true God; And to wait for his Son from heaven, whom he raised from the dead, even Jesus, which delivered us from the wrath to come."
2026-06-15.reflexion: Today's passage from 1 Thessalonians paints a vivid picture of the Thessalonians' transformation. Paul celebrates their turning away from the emptiness of idolatry and embracing the living God. This wasn't just a change of belief; it was a complete reorientation of their lives. They abandoned the pursuit of fleeting pleasures and false gods, choosing instead to serve the true God. This act of turning is a powerful reminder of the grace available to all. It speaks of a journey from darkness to light, from futility to purpose. Furthermore, the passage highlights their eager anticipation for the return of Jesus. This wasn't a passive waiting; it was an active, hopeful expectancy. They understood that Jesus' resurrection was not just a historical event, but the foundation of their hope for deliverance from the wrath to come. This understanding fueled their faith and shaped their lives. We, too, are called to turn away from idols, whatever form they may take in our lives – materialism, pride, or any other distraction that keeps us from God. We must serve the living God, not just with our words, but with our actions. And we are to live in eager anticipation of Christ's return, allowing this hope to shape our choices and motivate our service.

para_meditar.texto: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ:
Looking for that blessed hope, and the glorious appearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ;

2026-06-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the transformative power of your grace. Help us to turn away from the idols that seek to capture our hearts and minds. Grant us the strength to serve you with our whole being, to live in obedience to your will, and to seek you in all that we do. Fill us with the same eager anticipation that the Thessalonians had, for the return of your Son, Jesus Christ. May this hope shape our daily lives and inspire us to share the good news with others. Help us to live lives worthy of your calling, reflecting your love and grace to the world. Thank you for the promise of deliverance from the wrath to come. We commit our lives to you, seeking to honor you in everything. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-16.versiculo: Hebrews 12:6-7 KJV: "For whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom he receiveth. If ye endure chastening, God dealeth with you as with sons; for what son is he whom the father chasteneth not?"
2026-06-16.reflexion: Today's passage from Hebrews reminds us of a profound truth about God's love: it is expressed not only through blessings and comfort, but also through correction and discipline. Verse 6 tells us that the Lord chastens those He loves, and scourges every son He receives. This might seem harsh at first glance, but it's a testament to the depth of God's parental care. He doesn't leave us to wander aimlessly; He guides, corrects, and molds us into the image of His Son, Jesus Christ.  The purpose of this discipline is not punishment, but rather refinement. It's like a loving father who corrects his child, not out of anger, but out of a desire to see them grow and flourish. Verse 7 clarifies this further: if we endure the chastening, we are treated as sons. This means we are part of His family, recipients of His inheritance, and heirs to His Kingdom. This understanding calls for a shift in perspective. Instead of viewing trials and tribulations as curses, we should see them as opportunities for growth, refining our faith and drawing us closer to God. Embrace the discipline, for it is a sign of His love and a pathway to spiritual maturity.

para_meditar.texto: My son, despise not the chastening of the Lord; neither be weary of his correction: For whom the Lord loveth he correcteth; even as a father the son in whom he delighteth.

And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience; And patience, experience; and experience, hope: And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us.

My brethren, count it all joy when ye fall into divers temptations; Knowing this, that the trying of your faith worketh patience. But let patience have her perfect work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing.

2026-06-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for your boundless love and for the ways you choose to reveal it to us. We acknowledge that your love is not only expressed through blessings, but also through the trials and tribulations that shape us and mold us. Help us to embrace the chastening that comes our way, understanding that it is a sign of your fatherly care. Grant us the strength to endure, the wisdom to learn from our experiences, and the faith to trust in your perfect plan, even when we don't understand it. Help us to see beyond the immediate challenges and to recognize the opportunities for growth and refinement that lie within them. Fill us with patience, hope, and a deeper understanding of your unwavering love. We pray for the grace to be more like Christ, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-17.versiculo: Matthew 1:1 KJV: "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham."
2026-06-17.reflexion: Today, we begin at the very beginning, with the genealogy of Jesus Christ. Matthew 1:1 is not just a line of names; it's a bridge connecting the Old Testament promises with the New Testament fulfillment. This verse immediately grounds Jesus in history, linking Him to the lineage of David, the king, and Abraham, the father of faith. It declares that Jesus is not just a divine figure; He is also human, part of the story of God’s people. The phrase 'the son of David' speaks of kingship and the promise of a Messiah who would reign forever. 'The son of Abraham' emphasizes the covenant God made with Abraham, promising to bless all nations through his seed. This verse sets the stage for the entire Gospel of Matthew, highlighting Jesus as the promised Messiah, the rightful King, and the fulfillment of God's covenant. It reminds us that our faith is rooted in history, in the faithfulness of God to His promises, and in the remarkable story of redemption that began long ago and continues to unfold through Jesus Christ.

para_meditar.texto: And I will bless them that bless thee, and curse him that curseth thee: and in thee shall all families of the earth be blessed.

And when thy days be fulfilled, and thou shalt sleep with thy fathers, I will set up thy seed after thee, which shall proceed out of thy bowels, and I will establish his kingdom. He shall build an house for my name, and I will stablish the throne of his kingdom for ever.
Now to Abraham and his seed were the promises made. He saith not, And to seeds, as of many; but as of one, And to thy seed, which is Christ.

2026-06-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, as we begin this journey through the Gospel of Matthew, we are reminded of Your faithfulness. Thank You for the lineage of Jesus, for connecting Him to the promises of old and the hope of the future. Help us to understand the significance of this genealogy, to see the tapestry of Your love and redemption woven throughout history. Grant us wisdom and discernment as we study Your Word, that we may recognize Jesus as the promised Messiah, the King of kings, and the Lord of lords. Fill our hearts with gratitude for the sacrifice He made for us and guide us to live a life worthy of His calling. May we always remember that we are blessed through the seed of Abraham, through Jesus Christ. We give you all praise and glory, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-18.versiculo: Galatians 6:7-8 KJV: "Be not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap. For he that soweth to his flesh shall of the flesh reap corruption; but he that soweth to the Spirit shall of the Spirit reap life everlasting."
2026-06-18.reflexion: Today's scripture serves as a stark reminder of the immutable laws of the spiritual realm. We are warned, 'Be not deceived.' This is a call to vigilance, a plea to discern truth from falsehood, and to recognize the consequences of our choices. God is not mocked; He sees all, knows all, and will hold us accountable for our actions. The principle of sowing and reaping is fundamental to understanding this. What we plant in our lives, whether good or evil, will inevitably bear fruit. Sowing to the flesh, indulging in worldly desires and selfish pursuits, leads to corruption – decay, disappointment, and ultimately, spiritual death. However, sowing to the Spirit, nurturing our faith, cultivating righteousness, and living in accordance with God's will, yields eternal life. This is a promise of abundant life, a life filled with the fruits of the Spirit: love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance. Let us therefore examine our lives, identifying the seeds we are planting. Are we cultivating a harvest of corruption or a harvest of eternal life? Let us choose wisely, for the harvest we reap will determine our eternal destiny.

para_meditar.texto: The wicked worketh a deceitful work: but to him that soweth righteousness shall be a sure reward.
For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.
But this I say, He which soweth sparingly shall reap also sparingly; and he which soweth bountifully shall reap also bountifully.

2026-06-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today seeking guidance and wisdom. Help me to understand the profound truth of sowing and reaping, and to apply it to my daily life. Grant me the discernment to recognize the seeds I am planting, and to choose carefully what I allow to take root in my heart and mind. Help me to resist the temptations of the flesh, and to cultivate a life that is pleasing to you. Fill me with your Spirit, that I may sow to the Spirit and reap the blessings of eternal life. Give me the strength to persevere in righteousness, knowing that the harvest will be abundant. Thank you for your grace and mercy. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-19.versiculo: Mark 7:20-23 KJV: "And he said, That which cometh out of the man, that defileth the man. For from within, out of the heart of men, proceed evil thoughts, adulteries, fornications, murders, Thefts, covetousness, wickedness, deceit, lasciviousness, an evil eye, blasphemy, pride, foolishness: All these evil things come from within, and defile the man."
2026-06-19.reflexion: Today's passage from Mark 7 confronts us with a stark truth: the source of our defilement lies not in external things, but within our hearts. Jesus clarifies that it is the inner condition of man that truly matters. It's not the food we eat, but the thoughts, intentions, and desires that originate from our hearts that ultimately determine our spiritual state. This passage lays bare a litany of sins – evil thoughts, adulteries, fornications, murders, thefts, covetousness, wickedness, deceit, lasciviousness, an evil eye, blasphemy, pride, foolishness. These are not just isolated acts, but manifestations of a corrupt heart. This is a call to introspection. We must examine the wellspring of our actions. Are our hearts aligned with God's will? Do we harbor secret sins, hidden resentments, or unchecked desires? This passage challenges us to seek a transformation that goes beyond outward appearances and delves into the depths of our inner being. It's a reminder that true cleanliness comes from a renewed heart, cleansed by the grace of God.

para_meditar.texto: Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
Create in me a clean heart, O God; and renew a right spirit within me.
For out of the heart proceed evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, blasphemies:

2026-06-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today humbled by the truth revealed in Your Word. We confess that our hearts are often prone to wander, to harbor thoughts and desires that are not pleasing to You. Forgive us for the evil that originates within us: the unkind thoughts, the selfish ambitions, the hidden resentments. Purify our hearts, Lord, and create in us a clean spirit. Help us to guard our hearts with diligence, to fill them with Your love, Your truth, and Your grace. Grant us the strength to resist temptation, to choose righteousness over sin, and to walk in the path of Your holiness. Give us the courage to confront the darkness within and to seek Your light in every aspect of our lives. Guide us to reflect your love and grace to all those around us, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-20.versiculo: James 1:22 KJV: "But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves."
2026-06-20.reflexion: Today's verse from James challenges us to move beyond passive listening and become active practitioners of God's Word. It’s easy to sit in church, nod in agreement, and even feel inspired by the sermon. However, James reminds us that true faith manifests itself in action. Simply hearing the word of God is not enough; we must *do* what it says. This means applying biblical principles to our daily lives, making choices that reflect our faith, and embodying the teachings of Jesus Christ. It's a call to honesty with ourselves. Are we truly living out what we believe, or are we deceiving ourselves into thinking that mere knowledge of the scriptures is sufficient? The danger lies in the self-deception—believing we are spiritual when our actions contradict our words. This verse encourages us to examine our lives, identify areas where we are falling short, and actively seek to align our behavior with the will of God. It’s a call to action, a reminder that genuine faith is a life lived, not just a lecture listened to.

para_meditar.texto: Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven.
And why call ye me, Lord, Lord, and do not the things which I say?
They profess that they know God; but in works they deny him, being abominable, and disobedient, and unto every good work reprobate.

2026-06-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today with a humble heart, acknowledging my tendency to be a hearer of your word and not always a doer. Forgive me for the times when I have allowed self-deception to cloud my judgment, and when my actions have not fully reflected my faith. Grant me the strength and the courage to put your teachings into practice in every aspect of my life. Help me to be mindful of your Word, not just on Sundays, but in every moment of every day. Guide me to live a life that glorifies you through my actions, my words, and my thoughts. Give me a heart that is eager to obey your commands and a spirit that is willing to serve you faithfully. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-21.versiculo: James 4:8 KJV: "Draw nigh to God, and he will draw nigh to you. Cleanse your hands, ye sinners; and purify your hearts, ye double minded."
2026-06-21.reflexion: Today's verse, James 4:8, is a powerful call to action, a direct invitation to intimacy with God. It's not merely a suggestion; it's a promise. 'Draw nigh to God, and he will draw nigh to you.' This reciprocal relationship is the cornerstone of a vibrant faith. We are challenged to initiate the connection. To 'draw nigh' requires intentionality, a deliberate seeking of God's presence. This can manifest in prayer, in studying His Word, in acts of service, or simply in quiet contemplation of His goodness. But James doesn't stop there; he adds a crucial caveat: 'Cleanse your hands, ye sinners; and purify your hearts, ye double minded.' This underscores the importance of repentance and a sincere desire to live a life pleasing to God. We must acknowledge our shortcomings, turn away from sin, and strive for a single-minded devotion to Him. The 'double minded' are those who waver in their commitment, torn between the world and God. True closeness with God demands a wholehearted dedication, a willingness to surrender our will to His. It is a journey of cleansing and purification, a constant striving toward holiness, fueled by the promise of God's reciprocal nearness. Let us heed this call today, and experience the transforming power of drawing near to God.

para_meditar.texto: But as for me, it is good for me to draw near to God: I have put my trust in the Lord GOD, that I may declare all thy works.
But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
Let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience, and our bodies washed with pure water.

2026-06-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before You today with a heart that desires to draw near to You. I acknowledge my shortcomings and my need for Your grace. I ask for Your forgiveness for the times I have strayed and for the times my heart has been divided. Help me to cleanse my hands and purify my heart, that I may be wholly devoted to You. Grant me the strength to resist temptation and the wisdom to discern Your will. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may experience Your presence in every aspect of my life. Help me to seek You diligently, to pray without ceasing, and to walk in obedience to Your Word. Thank You for Your promise to draw near to those who draw near to You. I long for a deeper relationship with You, a relationship built on faith, trust, and love. Guide me and keep me close to You, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-22.versiculo: Luke 19:10 KJV: "For the Son of man is come to seek and to save that which was lost."
2026-06-22.reflexion: Luke 19:10 presents a profound statement about the very purpose of Jesus' earthly ministry. He came not merely to preach, teach, or perform miracles, but to actively seek and rescue those who were lost. This verse underscores the heart of God, a heart of relentless pursuit and unwavering love for humanity. The 'lost' encompasses all of us, separated from God by sin and in need of redemption. This verse challenges us to reflect on the depth of God's love, a love that would compel Him to leave the glories of heaven and descend to earth to seek us out. It also calls us to action. If Jesus came to seek and save the lost, then we, as His followers, are called to participate in that same mission. We are to be instruments of His grace, extending His hand of love and sharing the good news of salvation with those around us. This is not just a passive invitation; it is an active pursuit, a deliberate effort to reach out to the broken, the hurting, and the spiritually adrift. It reminds us that evangelism is not just a duty, but a reflection of the very heart of God.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners; of whom I am chief.

2026-06-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for sending Your Son, Jesus, to seek and save the lost. Thank You for the incredible love that drove Him to come to earth and redeem us. Help us to understand the depth of this love and to be filled with compassion for those who are still lost, wandering in darkness and separated from You. Give us the courage to share the Gospel with boldness and love, that others may come to know Your saving grace. Open our eyes to the needs around us and empower us to be Your hands and feet, seeking out those who are far from You. Grant us wisdom and discernment in our interactions, and help us to reflect Your love in every word and deed. Guide us in our mission to share the good news of salvation. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-23.versiculo: Galatians 5:16 KJV: "This I say then, Walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh."
2026-06-23.reflexion: Today's verse, Galatians 5:16, provides a pivotal instruction for the Christian life: "Walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh." This is not merely a suggestion, but a command, a pathway to freedom from the constant battle against our sinful nature. Walking in the Spirit is an active choice, a deliberate decision to align our thoughts, actions, and desires with the guidance and power of the Holy Spirit. The 'lust of the flesh' refers to the desires that stem from our fallen human nature – those cravings for sin, selfishness, and worldly pleasures that war against our souls. By walking in the Spirit, we empower ourselves to resist these desires. The Spirit provides the strength, wisdom, and discernment needed to overcome temptation and live a life pleasing to God. This is not a passive process; it requires diligent prayer, Bible study, and fellowship with other believers. It also involves a conscious effort to cultivate the fruits of the Spirit – love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance (Galatians 5:22-23). As we focus on these qualities, the desires of the flesh diminish, and we experience the freedom and abundant life that Christ offers.

para_meditar.texto: For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit the things of the Spirit.

What? know ye not that your body is the temple of the Holy Ghost which is in you, which ye have of God, and ye are not your own? For ye are bought with a price: therefore glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are God's.
And be not drunk with wine, wherein is excess; but be filled with the Spirit;

2026-06-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today seeking your guidance and strength. I acknowledge my struggles with the desires of the flesh and the temptations that constantly surround me. I pray that you would fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I might walk in your ways and resist the pull of sin. Help me to cultivate the fruits of the Spirit in my life – love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control. Grant me the wisdom to discern your will and the courage to obey it. Help me to be mindful of your presence throughout my day and to lean on your strength in every situation. Guide my thoughts, words, and actions, that they may be pleasing to you. I surrender my life to you, asking that you would reign supreme in my heart and mind. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-24.versiculo: John 5:24 KJV: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that heareth my word, and believeth on him that sent me, hath everlasting life, and shall not come into condemnation; but is passed from death unto life."
2026-06-24.reflexion: Today's verse, John 5:24, offers a profound promise and a clear pathway to eternal life. Jesus declares that those who hear His word and believe in the Father, who sent Him, already possess eternal life. This isn't a future hope; it's a present reality. The believer has 'passed from death unto life'. This transition signifies a complete transformation, a shift from spiritual death, characterized by separation from God, to a vibrant, intimate relationship with Him. The verse also assures us that we 'shall not come into condemnation'. This means we are no longer under the judgment of God. Our sins are forgiven, and we are reconciled to Him through faith in Jesus Christ. This is the core of the Gospel message: hearing and believing. It's not just about intellectual assent; it's about receiving Jesus' words into our hearts, trusting in His sacrifice, and living in accordance with His teachings. This verse serves as a powerful reminder of the security we have in Christ and the abundant life He offers to all who believe.

para_meditar.texto: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.
For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
These things have I written unto you that believe on the name of the Son of God; that ye may know that ye have eternal life, and that ye may believe on the name of the Son of God.

2026-06-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible gift of eternal life, promised in Your Word. Thank you, Jesus, for Your sacrifice that allows us to escape condemnation and experience life in its fullness. Help me to hear Your word with an open heart, to believe in Your truth, and to live a life that honors You. Guide me daily to walk in the light of Your grace, to be transformed by Your love, and to share the good news with others. Grant me the wisdom and strength to live a life that reflects Your character and glorifies Your name. Help me to remember the promise of everlasting life and to live each day with hope and anticipation of Your return. I commit my life to You, trusting in Your unchanging love and grace. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-25.versiculo: Matthew 20:26-28 KJV: "But it shall not be so among you: but whosoever will be great among you, let him be your minister; And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant: Even as the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many."
2026-06-25.reflexion: Today's passage from Matthew challenges our understanding of greatness. Jesus upends the worldly definition, where power and prestige are sought after. Instead, He presents a radical vision: true greatness is found in service. This is not just a suggestion; it's the core of His ministry and the example He left for us. The disciples, like us, often struggled with this concept. They sought positions of honor and authority, missing the point entirely. Jesus, however, consistently demonstrated a life of humility, reaching out to the marginalized and the downtrodden. He washed the feet of His disciples, a task usually reserved for servants, and ultimately gave His life as a ransom for many. This act of selflessness is the ultimate expression of service.  We are called to follow this example, to prioritize the needs of others over our own ambitions.  It is a call to become ministers and servants, not to seek to be ministered unto. This passage reminds us that true leadership in the Kingdom of God is characterized by a servant heart, a willingness to humble ourselves, and a commitment to serving others, just as Christ served us.

para_meditar.texto: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves. Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others.
If I then, your Lord and Master, have washed your feet; ye also ought to wash one another's feet. For I have given you an example, that ye should do as I have done to you.
For even the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.

2026-06-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the profound example of Jesus Christ. We confess our tendency to seek our own glory and to desire positions of power and recognition. Help us to see true greatness as You define it – in service, humility, and selflessness. Give us a servant's heart, a willingness to put the needs of others before our own.  Grant us the strength to resist the temptations of pride and ambition, and to embrace the path of service that leads to true fulfillment. Help us to emulate Jesus in our daily lives, reaching out to those in need, and offering our time, talents, and resources to further Your Kingdom.  We pray for the strength to live a life of ministry, to bless others, and to reflect Your love in all that we do.  In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-06-26.versiculo: John 12:24 KJV: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, Except a corn of wheat fall into the ground and die, it abideth alone: but if it die, it bringeth forth much fruit."
2026-06-26.reflexion: Today's verse, John 12:24, is a profound and powerful teaching from Jesus about the nature of life, death, and spiritual fruitfulness. He uses the analogy of a grain of wheat.  A single grain, if it remains alone, retains its solitary existence. However, if it falls into the ground and 'dies'—that is, it is buried and undergoes the process of decay—it then brings forth a harvest, a multitude of new grains.  This illustrates a fundamental truth about the Christian life:  true life, abundant fruit, and lasting impact come through sacrifice, humility, and self-denial.  Jesus, knowing His own impending death, was speaking of His own sacrifice.  His death would lead to the salvation of many, bearing the 'fruit' of a redeemed humanity.  We, too, are called to a life of dying to self.  This means setting aside our own desires, ambitions, and comfort for the sake of others and for the glory of God.  It is in the surrender of our lives that we find true life, a life that bears fruit for eternity.  Just as the grain of wheat must die to produce a harvest, so must we embrace a willingness to sacrifice, to suffer, and to serve, understanding that these acts are the seeds of spiritual growth and eternal reward.

2026-06-27.versiculo: Ephesians 2:4-5 KJV: "But God, who is rich in mercy, for his great love wherewith he loved us, Even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, (by grace ye are saved;)"
2026-06-27.reflexion: Today's passage from Ephesians 2:4-5 offers a profound glimpse into the heart of God. It begins with the magnificent 'But God,' a phrase that immediately shifts our perspective from the darkness of our condition to the overwhelming light of His grace. We are reminded that we were once 'dead in sins,' a state of spiritual lifelessness and separation from God. This is a stark reality that underscores the magnitude of God's intervention. His love is not a casual affection; it is a 'great love'—a love so immense that it transcends our unworthiness. It is this love, coupled with His 'rich mercy,' that moved Him to act on our behalf. God didn't wait for us to become worthy; He initiated the process of salvation. He 'quickened us together with Christ,' bringing us to life, giving us new spiritual vitality through our union with Him. The parenthetical statement, 'by grace ye are saved,' encapsulates the core truth of the Gospel. Salvation is not earned through our efforts; it is a free gift, a testament to God's unmerited favor. This understanding should fill us with gratitude and humility, prompting us to live lives that reflect the transformative power of His grace. Let us embrace the love, mercy, and grace that define our relationship with God, and strive to live each day in accordance with the new life He has given us.

2026-06-28.versiculo: Ephesians 4:29 KJV: "Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth, but that which is good to the use of edifying, that it may minister grace unto the hearers."
2026-06-28.reflexion: Today's verse from Ephesians 4:29 challenges us to examine the words that flow from our mouths. The Apostle Paul instructs us to avoid 'corrupt communication' – words that are harmful, negative, or deceitful. Instead, we are called to speak words that are 'good to the use of edifying,' meaning words that build up, encourage, and strengthen. This isn't merely about avoiding bad language; it's about actively choosing words that bring grace to those who hear them. Think about the impact of your words. Do they tear down or build up? Do they spread bitterness or grace? This verse calls us to be intentional in our speech, recognizing that our words have the power to bless or to curse. It's a call to cultivate a heart of kindness and compassion, which will naturally overflow into our conversations. Let us strive to be vessels of grace, using our words to minister to the needs of others and reflect the love of Christ in all that we say. This requires self-control, a renewed mind, and a dependence on the Holy Spirit to guide our tongues.

Help me to reflect your character in every conversation, choosing words that bring life and hope. 2026-06-29.versiculo: Philippians 2:9-11 KJV: "Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name: That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father."
2026-06-29.reflexion: Today's passage, Philippians 2:9-11, offers a profound glimpse into the ultimate exaltation of Jesus Christ. This is not merely a reward for His earthly ministry, but a testament to His divine nature and the completion of the Father's plan. The act of bowing the knee and confessing Jesus as Lord is not a passive acceptance, but an active recognition of His sovereignty and ultimate authority. It speaks of a universal acknowledgement, a moment when every creature, from the angels in heaven to those dwelling in the depths of the earth, will confess His Lordship. This passage challenges us to examine our own hearts. Do we truly acknowledge Jesus as Lord? Does His name elicit reverence and obedience in our lives? Are we willing to bow our hearts and minds to His will, allowing Him to reign supreme in every aspect of our being? This is not just a future prophecy, but a present reality, a call to live lives of worship and devotion, reflecting the glory of God the Father.

2026-06-30.versiculo: Matthew 8:26-27 KJV: "And he saith unto them, Why are ye fearful, O ye of little faith? Then he arose, and rebuked the winds and the sea; and there was a great calm. But the men marvelled, saying, What manner of man is this, that even the winds and the sea obey him!"
2026-06-30.reflexion: The account in Matthew 8:26-27 vividly portrays the disciples' fear and Jesus' immediate and powerful response. We see the disciples, experienced fishermen, terrified by a storm that threatened to capsize their boat. Their fear reflects a lack of faith, a forgetting of Jesus' presence and power. Jesus, in contrast, displays perfect composure, first rebuking their fear and then commanding the storm to cease. The result is a dramatic demonstration of His authority over nature, leading to the disciples' awe and wonder. This passage is a powerful reminder that our fears often stem from a lack of faith. We, like the disciples, can become overwhelmed by the storms of life – the challenges, uncertainties, and anxieties that threaten to capsize our peace. However, we must remember that Jesus is with us, and He has the power to calm any storm. His question, "Why are ye fearful, O ye of little faith?" echoes through the ages, challenging us to trust in His presence and power, even when the circumstances seem overwhelming. We must cultivate a faith that sees beyond the immediate threat and recognizes the ultimate authority of Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Fear thou not; for I am with thee: be not dismayed; for I am thy God: I will strengthen thee; yea, I will help thee; yea, I will uphold thee with the right hand of my righteousness.

2026-07-01.versiculo: John 8:32 KJV: "And ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free."
2026-07-01.reflexion: Today's verse, John 8:32, is a cornerstone of Christian understanding. It proclaims a profound truth: that knowing the truth sets us free. But what is this truth, and what kind of freedom are we talking about? In the context of John's Gospel, the truth is Jesus Christ Himself. He is the embodiment of truth, the Word made flesh. To know Him, to understand His teachings, to believe in His sacrifice, is to gain access to a freedom unlike any other. This freedom isn't merely the absence of physical chains; it's liberation from the bondage of sin, the chains of fear, and the burden of guilt. It's freedom from the relentless pursuit of worldly validation and the emptiness of a life lived apart from God. This verse challenges us to actively seek the truth. It calls us to delve into scripture, to pray for understanding, and to cultivate a relationship with Jesus. It’s a call to embrace the life He offers, a life of purpose, hope, and eternal significance. The freedom found in Christ is a gift, a promise, and a powerful reality for those who choose to know the truth.

Fill my heart with Your love and peace, that I may walk in the freedom that comes from knowing You. Strengthen my faith, and help me to share the truth with others, so that they too may experience the liberating power of Your grace. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-07-02.versiculo: Colossians 3:5 KJV: "Mortify therefore your members which are upon the earth; fornication, uncleanness, inordinate affection, evil concupiscence, and covetousness, which is idolatry."
2026-07-02.reflexion: Today's verse, Colossians 3:5, is a call to radical self-discipline and spiritual cleansing. Paul urges us to 'mortify' – to put to death – the earthly desires that war against our souls. This isn't a suggestion; it's a command. He lists specific areas to address: fornication, uncleanness, inordinate affection, evil concupiscence, and covetousness, declaring that covetousness is idolatry. These aren't just isolated sins; they are root causes that can corrupt our hearts and separate us from God. The 'members' Paul refers to are not just physical body parts, but rather the desires and tendencies within us that lead to sin. We must actively choose to starve these desires, to deprive them of their power. This requires a conscious effort, a daily crucifixion of the flesh. It's a process of spiritual warfare, where we must resist the temptations that arise from within and without. This verse provides a framework for self-examination and repentance. It reminds us that true freedom comes not just from knowing Christ, but from living in accordance with His teachings, actively choosing holiness over the allure of sin, and seeking to please God above all else.

2026-07-03.versiculo: 2 Timothy 4:2 KJV: "Preach the word; be instant in season, out of season; reprove, rebuke, exhort with all longsuffering and doctrine."
2026-07-03.reflexion:
The Apostle Paul, in his final letter to Timothy, delivers a powerful charge: "Preach the word." This command transcends mere instruction; it’s a call to action, a mandate to proclaim the Gospel in every circumstance. The phrase "be instant in season, out of season" emphasizes the urgency and consistency required. It means to seize every opportunity, whether convenient or challenging, to share the truth of God's word. This includes times of prosperity and times of adversity, times when the message is readily received and times when it is met with resistance. 

Furthermore, the verse details the methods of preaching. "Reprove, rebuke, exhort" highlights the necessity of addressing sin and error, correcting wrong beliefs, and encouraging believers to live according to God's will. This requires patience and gentleness, as indicated by "all longsuffering." The goal isn’t to condemn, but to guide others towards righteousness. The foundation for all these actions is "doctrine" – the sound teaching of God’s word. Without a firm grasp of biblical truth, our preaching will be ineffective and potentially harmful. As we reflect on this verse, let us examine our own commitment to sharing the Gospel. Are we ready to preach the word, regardless of the circumstances? Are we prepared to reprove, rebuke, and exhort with patience and love? Let us strive to be faithful witnesses, instant in season and out of season, always grounded in the truth of God's Word.

2026-07-04.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 5:20 KJV: "Now then we are ambassadors for Christ, as though God did beseech you by us: we pray you in Christ's stead, be ye reconciled to God."

The weight of this responsibility is immense; we are chosen to represent the King of Kings, pleading with others to reconcile with God. This isn't just a suggestion; it's a divine imperative. We are commissioned to share the good news, the message of reconciliation through Christ's sacrifice. The verse highlights the urgency of our task. God, through us, is imploring others to turn to Him. This underscores the love and grace of God, who desires that all be saved. As ambassadors, we must embody the character of Christ: love, compassion, humility, and truth. We are to be living examples of His grace, extending the invitation to reconciliation to all we encounter. The task requires boldness, yet also gentleness. It demands a deep understanding of the Gospel and a passionate desire for others to experience the transformative power of God's love. Let us embrace our role, faithfully representing Christ and actively pursuing the reconciliation of others to God.

Help us to be instruments of your peace and reconciliation, bringing glory to your name, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2026-07-05.versiculo: James 4:14 KJV: "Whereas ye know not what shall be on the morrow. For what is your life? It is even a vapour, that appeareth for a little time, and then vanisheth away."
2026-07-05.reflexion: The stark reality of James 4:14 confronts us with the fleeting nature of our existence. "What is your life?" James asks, and the answer is sobering: "It is even a vapour, that appeareth for a little time, and then vanisheth away." This verse serves as a potent reminder of our mortality and the urgency of living a life aligned with God's will. We are often consumed by the anxieties of tomorrow, planning and striving as if we have an eternity. But James calls us to a different perspective, one that acknowledges the brevity of our time on earth. The image of a vapor is particularly poignant. It appears briefly, a wisp in the air, before dissolving and disappearing. This should not lead us to despair, but rather to a deeper appreciation for each moment. It should compel us to prioritize what truly matters: our relationship with God, our love for others, and the pursuit of eternal treasures. We must use our time wisely, seeking to glorify God in all that we do, and preparing for the day when our earthly vapor vanishes. This understanding of our ephemeral existence should inspire us to live with intention, purpose, and a heart overflowing with gratitude for the gift of each breath.

2026-07-06.versiculo: Romans 13:8 KJV: "Owe no man any thing, but to love one another: for he that loveth another hath fulfilled the law."
2026-07-06.reflexion: Today's verse from Romans 13:8 challenges us to examine our debts, not just financial, but also those of the heart. Paul urges us to 'owe no man any thing, but to love one another.' This speaks to a fundamental truth: love is the ultimate debt, and it's one we can never fully repay. Love is the fulfillment of the law. When we genuinely love others, we are, in essence, keeping the commandments. This love isn't merely a feeling; it's an action, a commitment to putting the needs of others before our own. It encompasses kindness, forgiveness, patience, and selflessness. It compels us to treat others with respect, to offer help when needed, and to seek their well-being. Consider the ways you might be 'owing' someone love – perhaps a family member, a friend, or even a stranger. Are there unresolved conflicts that need reconciliation? Opportunities to show compassion that you've missed? The call to love is a daily invitation to grow closer to God, for He is love itself. Let us strive to fulfill this debt of love, making it the cornerstone of our interactions and the defining characteristic of our lives.

2026-07-07.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 3:11 KJV: "For other foundation can no man lay than that is laid, which is Jesus Christ."
2026-07-07.reflexion: Today's verse, 1 Corinthians 3:11, is a cornerstone of our faith. It unequivocally declares that Jesus Christ is the only foundation upon which we can build our lives and our spiritual houses. This is a powerful statement, cutting through the noise of the world and reminding us of the unchanging truth. The 'other foundation' the Apostle Paul speaks of refers to any attempt to build on anything other than Christ: our own achievements, worldly possessions, or the opinions of others. These are all fleeting and ultimately insufficient. Jesus Christ, however, is the solid rock, the eternal foundation that will never crumble. Building on Christ means aligning our lives with His teachings, seeking His will in all things, and trusting in His sacrifice for our salvation. It means making Him the center of our thoughts, words, and deeds. It requires a daily commitment to prayer, scripture reading, and fellowship with other believers. When we build our lives on this foundation, we are building for eternity. The storms of life may come, the winds of adversity may blow, but the house built on Christ will stand firm. This verse calls us to examine the foundations of our own lives. Are we building on Christ, or are we trying to construct our own flimsy structures? Let us choose today to lay down the things that cannot last and embrace the unshakeable foundation of Jesus Christ.

2026-07-08.versiculo: Ephesians 2:10 KJV: "For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them."
2026-07-08.reflexion: Today's verse reminds us of the profound truth of our identity in Christ. We are not merely products of chance or circumstance, but rather, we are God's "workmanship." The Greek word used here, "poiema," indicates a masterpiece, a work of art. This means that God, the ultimate artist, has crafted us with intention and purpose. He has created us "in Christ Jesus," signifying that our new life and identity are found in Him. The passage further explains that we are created "unto good works." These works are not a means of earning salvation, but rather, they are the natural outflow of our transformed lives. They are the evidence of our faith. God has "before ordained" these good works for us, which suggests that He has prepared a path for us to walk in, a path of purpose and significance. This should fill us with great joy and anticipation. We are not adrift, but rather, we are part of a divine plan, designed for good works that God has already prepared for us to accomplish. This understanding should empower us to live a life of purpose, seeking to embody the good works that God has ordained for us.
